docs.text: Hálcova World Compendium Welcome, traveler, to the Hálcova World Compendium. Within these pages lies a curated overview of a world shaped by unique laws, cultures, and mysteries. Here you will find glimpses into the forces that govern reality, the systems of magic and fate , the structures of society and governance , and the landscapes that form the stage for countless stories. This compendium is designed as a gateway—an introduction to the breadth and spirit of Hálcova. Each section offers a high-level perspective, inviting you to explore further while preserving the world's deeper secrets for discovery within. What Makes Hálcova Unique? Fate as a Tangible Force: In Hálcova, fate is not mere superstition—it's a woven, manipulable thread in the fabric of reality, shaping destinies and events through the mysterious Loom and the Sórscad . Magic Rooted in Metaphysics: Magic is governed by five distinct arts, each with its own metaphysical principles, limitations, and costs, making every act of sorcery a negotiation with the world's underlying structure. Living Languages and Cultures: Languages evolve, blend, and influence magic, while societies are shaped by unique governance , class , and religious systems that reflect the world's deep history. A World with Consequences: Every choice—magical, political, or personal—ripples outward, affecting not just individuals but the fate of entire nations and the metaphysical balance of the world. Secrets Intertwined with Discovery: Hálcova rewards curiosity; its greatest mysteries are hidden in plain sight, waiting for those who seek to unravel them. Begin your journey by selecting a topic from the main navigation above.

docs.text: Conlang Language Set: Halcova Selected Languages Role Language Reasoning Root Hungarian Rich vocabulary for abstract and visceral concepts. Agglutinative structure provides flexible roots. Unique among European languages—feels ancient and unfamiliar. Affix Arabic Distinct phonetic character. Tri-consonantal roots allow for varied affix extraction. Carries inherent weight and formality. Religious/mystical connotations fit dark fantasy. Mutation Scots Gaelic Soft mutations create flowing transformations. Celtic character adds otherworldly quality. Balances Hungarian's harshness with musicality. Language Character Overall Feel : Heavy, formal, weighty. Words feel like they carry consequence. Religious undertones without specific religious reference. Sounds like a language used for binding oaths, recording debts, naming the dead. Phonetic Tendencies : Hard consonants from Hungarian (k, t, sz, gy) Guttural sounds from Arabic (kh, q, gh) Soft mutations from Gaelic (bh→v, mh→v, ch→soft ch) Long vowels with accent marks for stress Syllable Patterns : Prefer 2-3 syllables for common words Longer forms preserved for formal/ritual use Compound words compress heavily Example Vocabulary Concept Root (Hungarian) Affix (Arabic) Combined Mutated (Gaelic) Molted Final Pronunciation Soul/Core lélek (soul) -ruh (spirit) lélekruh lèilecruh leilcruh Léilcrù LAY-il-croo Death halál -mawt (death) halálmawt halàlmabht halmabht Hálmaht HAHL-maht Binding kötés (binding) -qayd (chain) kötésqayd còiteiscaidh coitcaidh Cóitcai KOY-t-kai Flesh hús (meat) -lahm (flesh) húslahm hùislaimh huislaimh Húslaimh HOOSH-lav Fate sors -qadr (destiny) sorsqadr sorscadr sorscad Sórscad SOR-skad Affix Variations (Documented) To avoid repetitive endings, multiple affixes derived from Arabic for common concepts: Soul/Spirit Affixes -ruh (spirit) → -rù, -ru -nafs (self/soul) → -naf, -nav -qalb (heart/core) → -calb, -calv Death/End Affixes -mawt (death) → -maht, -mabht -fana (annihilation) → -fan, -fana -nihaya (end) → -niha, -nia Binding/Connection Affixes -qayd (chain) → -caidh, -cai -rabt (tie) → -rabht, -rav -'ahd (covenant) → -ahd, -àhd Body/Physical Affixes -lahm (flesh) → -laimh, -lav -jism (body) → -gism, -gis -jasad (corpse) → -jasad, -jas Fate/Path Affixes -qadr (destiny) → -cadr, -cad -nasib (fortune) → -nasiv, -nav -tariq (path) → -taric, -tar Mutation Rules (Gaelic-Based) Standard mutations applied during Step 3: Original Mutated Example k c kötés → còiteis p ph (f sound) — t th — b bh (v sound) halálmabht m mh (v sound) húslaimh g gh (silent/soft) — d dh (soft th) — s s (unchanged) sors → sors f fh (silent) — Vowel shifts : é → èi or éi ú → ùi or úi á → à or á (unchanged) o → o (unchanged) Usage Notes Formal vs. Common : Longer unmolted forms preserved for ritual, legal, and religious contexts. Molted forms for everyday speech. Compounds : When combining concepts, use the shorter affix variants and compress aggressively. Names : Personal names follow same construction but may use different affix sets to indicate family, profession, or origin. Loanwords : Concepts from other magic systems may retain more of their original structure to mark them as "foreign" to native speakers. This document serves as the foundation for all vocabulary creation in World A.

docs.text: Living Language: Contemporary Slang and Idioms of Hálcova Overview Language in Hálcova reflects and reinforces social structures. The formal High Hálcovan taught in schools and used in official contexts differs significantly from the living speech of streets, taverns, and homes. Slang, idioms, and vernacular expressions reveal how ordinary people understand and navigate their world—often subverting official meanings while using official vocabulary. This document catalogs contemporary informal language: the expressions pattern-privileged nobles use among themselves, the coded speech of criminals, the bitter humor of the constrained, and the regional variations that mark speakers' origins. Understanding this living language provides insight into Hálcovan culture beyond official pronouncements. Pattern-Related Slang The pattern system that structures society generates extensive vernacular vocabulary. General Pattern Terms Threadbare : Someone with severely constrained pattern status, used pejoratively. Implies poverty, limited rights, and low social position. "Don't trust him with the accounts—he's threadbare, desperate for any marks." Golden thread : A pattern-privileged individual. Can be neutral description or express envy/resentment depending on speaker's tone and context. "She's golden thread, born into the second ring. Never worked a day collecting Residue like us." Tangled : Confused, lost, or in complicated circumstances. References pattern threads becoming disordered. "I'm completely tangled on this contract—can't figure out who owes what to whom." Woven tight : Well-connected, powerful, secure in one's position. Implies strong pattern status and social relationships. "The magistrate's woven tight with the Crown—don't expect justice in his court." Loose end : An unreliable person, someone likely to cause problems. Also criminal slang for lowest-ranking members. "Keep your plans away from Marcus—he's a loose end waiting to unravel." Frayed : Damaged, broken, mentally unstable. Implies pattern degradation affecting behavior or capability. "She's been frayed since her son's Correction. Just stares at nothing." Smooth weave : Easy, uncomplicated, proceeding without problems. "The delivery went smooth weave—no inspections, no delays." Knotted up : In a complicated or difficult situation. When used about people, implies entanglement with problems. "The whole negotiation's knotted up now that they discovered the forgery." Cut from the cloth : Destined for something, pattern-determined to a particular fate. Often used ironically. "He's cut from the cloth for the arena—too stupid and aggressive for anything else." Reading the threads : Understanding a situation clearly, seeing truth beneath surface appearances. "She's reading the threads on this deal—knows exactly who's cheating whom." Status-Specific Terms Ring-jumper : Someone attempting to rise above their pattern-assigned status. Pejorative from pattern-privileged perspective, sometimes admiring from below. "Another ring-jumper caught with forged certificates. They never learn." Circle-bound : Stuck in one's assigned social position with no possibility of advancement. Resignation or complaint depending on context. "We're all circle-bound—born to this ring, die in this ring." Status-stink : The indefinable quality that reveals someone's true pattern status despite attempts to appear otherwise. "No matter how fine his clothes, you can smell the status-stink on him." Privilege-blind : Unable or unwilling to recognize advantages of pattern-privileged position. Common complaint from below. "The nobles are privilege-blind—think everyone can just buy their way out of trouble." Loom and Fate Idioms The Loom—the vast predictive apparatus underlying Hálcovan society—generates extensive idiomatic language. Fate Acceptance The Loom knows : Fate is inevitable, predetermined, beyond individual control. Can express genuine faith or bitter resignation. "Why fight it? The Loom knows what becomes of us." Following the pattern : Accepting fate, living according to what's been determined. Can be virtue (from Church perspective) or criticism (implying passivity). "He's just following the pattern—never questioned anything in his life." Loom's mercy : Expression of hope for favorable fate. "Loom's mercy we reach port before the storm hits." Against the weave : Fighting against fate, attempting impossible change. Usually implies futility. "Trying to save the condemned is against the weave—you'll only join them." Thread's end : Death approaching, fate concluding. "Old Márton's reached his thread's end. Won't see another harvest." New thread : A fresh start, rebirth, possibility of change. Somewhat subversive implication that fate might be altered. "Maybe the new posting will be a new thread—chance to become someone different." Observation and Scrutiny Attendance is watching : Be careful, you're being observed by those who track patterns. References the Attendance—operators of the Loom's monitoring functions. "Attendance is watching—keep your opinions about the Church quiet." Warden's eye : Under scrutiny by authorities, specifically pattern-enforcement. "He's been under Warden's eye since his brother's arrest. Every move watched." Loom's blind spot : Somewhere or something unmonitored, outside normal observation. Valuable knowledge for criminals and dissidents. "The warehouse is in the Loom's blind spot—even Attendance can't see what happens there." Thread-traced : Being tracked through pattern connections, unable to hide. "Once they thread-trace you, running's pointless. They'll find you anywhere." Seasonal References The five seasons shape temporal idioms: Fávarzach-mad : Crazy, unpredictable, chaotic. References the fifth season's disruption of normal patterns. "The market's gone Fávarzach-mad—prices changing by the hour." Évresá-green : Young, inexperienced, naive. References spring's new growth. "He's still Évresá-green, thinks hard work actually gets rewarded." Hórvam-cold : Emotionally distant, unfeeling, calculating. References winter's chill. "The magistrate's Hórvam-cold—don't expect sympathy." Fágvard-dark : Depressed, gloomy, pessimistic. References autumn's declining light. "She's been Fágvard-dark since the bankruptcy. Barely speaks." Szárnyév-bright : Optimistic, cheerful, perhaps naively positive. References summer's heat and light. "Still Szárnyév-bright about the venture? Wait until the bills arrive." Class-Based Slang Different social strata speak distinctly, using vocabulary that identifies their position. Pattern-Privileged Speech Nobility and wealthy pattern-privileged use terminology that reinforces their status: Beneath the weave : Lower classes, those below speaker's status. Dismissive. "Don't concern yourself with those beneath the weave—they have their place." Common thread : An ordinary person, someone without distinction. "He married a common thread—his family's still recovering from the scandal." Refined pattern : Cultured, educated, properly upper-class. "She displays a refined pattern—excellent education shows in everything she does." Proper threading : Correct behavior according to upper-class standards. "Proper threading requires acknowledging one's inferiors without engaging them." Unraveled : Socially ruined, reputation destroyed. Devastating for those dependent on social standing. "After the scandal, he's completely unraveled. No house will receive him." Patterned up : Married into or otherwise acquired higher status. "She patterned up nicely—husband's family is third ring." Working Class Speech Merchants, craftsmen, and laborers use different vocabulary: Marks and sparks : Money and trouble, the constants of working life. "It's all marks and sparks with him—chasing coin and running from problems." Coin-counter : A merchant, often derogatory when used by non-merchants. "The coin-counters raised prices again. They'll bleed us dry." Thread-puller : Someone who manipulates others for advantage. "Don't trust her—she's a thread-puller working every angle." Warden-bait : Risky behavior likely to attract enforcement attention. "Selling those texts is Warden-bait. You'll hang." Church-pocket : Someone who tithes heavily or displays excessive religious conformity. "He's a real Church-pocket—first at every service, loudest in every hymn." Guild-groveler : One who seeks favor from guild authorities at expense of fellow workers. "The guild-grovelers reported the extra moonlighting. Lost three of us our positions." Pattern-Constrained Speech Those with constrained status develop coded and bitter vocabulary: Golden bastards : Pattern-privileged individuals, hostile. "The golden bastards took our farm. Four generations, gone in a ruling." Warden-food : Someone likely to be Corrected or executed. "Keep your mouth shut or you're Warden-food." Free thread : Someone who has escaped pattern-constraint—legally through exceptional service, illegally through forgery or flight. Rare and admired. "They say he's a free thread now, living in the Reaches under a new name." Residue-bait : Someone likely to die soon, either through dangerous work or pattern-enforcement. Dark humor. "New workers are just Residue-bait. Half won't last the season." Loom-fucked : Doomed by fate, cursed by circumstances. Vulgar and common. "We're all Loom-fucked, born to this and dying to this." Certificate-dreaming : Hoping for improved status through legitimate means. Usually ironic. "Still certificate-dreaming? Nobody gets promoted out of the fifth ring." Hollow : Empty of pattern-control, free from observation. Either describes places outside monitoring or people who've escaped the system. "The mountain village is hollow—no Attendance, no Wardens, just people living." Regional Slang Regional identity shows in distinctive vocabulary. Heartlands The political and cultural center generates vocabulary that others often adopt: Fonvárs fancy : Pretentious, putting on airs, aspiring above one's station. Used throughout Hálcova about capital affectations. "Look at him with his Fonvárs fancy manners—still reeks of the farm." Crown's coin : Official, legitimate, properly authorized. "Make sure the shipment's Crown's coin—no unauthorized cargo." Market-mouth : Gossip, unreliable rumor, speculation. "Don't believe market-mouth—half of what they say is invented." Arena-ready : Tough, capable, ready for confrontation. "She's arena-ready—watched her break a man's arm without changing expression." Palace-pure : Something so refined or perfect it might belong in the Crown's residence. Can be genuine or ironic. "The embroidery's palace-pure—must have cost a fortune." Reaches Maritime culture produces distinctive vocabulary: Salt-sense : Practical wisdom, knowledge gained through experience rather than education. "He's got salt-sense about ships—formal training, no, but knows what works." Tide-turner : An opportunist, someone who changes positions with circumstances. "Politicians are all tide-turners—support whoever's winning." Harbor-rat : A smuggler, criminal, or generally disreputable dock worker. Can be pejorative or affectionate depending on context. "Half the harbor-rats in town owe me favors." League-legal : Technically permitted but ethically questionable. References the Reaches League's flexible standards. "The cargo's League-legal—don't ask what it is or where it's going." Storm-blessed : A lucky survivor, someone who's escaped danger through fortune. "She's storm-blessed—only survivor of three shipwrecks." Barnacled : Stuck in place, unable to move forward. "He's been barnacled in that position for fifteen years—never promoted, never fired." Reef-blind : Unable to see obvious dangers, navigating toward disaster. "The investors are reef-blind—can't see they're funding their own ruin." Vent Lands Technical and modified culture creates specialized vocabulary: Shaped : Modified by Flesh Shaping, often obvious enough to be visible. Can be neutral or derogatory. "The shaped workers do double production—and die in half the time." Consortium-clean : Officially approved by the Flesh Shaping Consortium, meeting their standards. "The modification's Consortium-clean—all proper documentation." Experiment : A risky venture with uncertain outcome. Also derogatory for people with unusual Flesh Shaping. "The new business is an experiment—might make fortune, might lose everything." Technical : Overly complicated, also a sarcastic excuse for unethical behavior. "He's being technical about the contract—meaning he's cheating us legally." Steam-headed : Obsessed with innovation, sometimes to the point of ignoring practical concerns. "Don't get steam-headed over the design—it has to actually work." Meat-wrong : Something deeply disturbing about a person or situation, especially regarding Flesh Shaping. "There's something meat-wrong about that place. The workers don't look right." Far Shelf Remote mountain culture maintains distinct vocabulary, some representing quiet resistance: Mountain-free : Independent, outside central control. "The highland villages are mountain-free—live by their own rules." Threadist : A resistance member or sympathizer. Self-identification among believers, accusation among opponents. "Half the village are Threadists—the other half pretend not to notice." Hollow : Empty of pattern-control, truly free. Core Threadist concept that's entered general speech. "She dreams of hollow places where the Loom can't reach." Saint's work : Resistance activity, actions supporting the Hollow Saints. Coded speech. "He's doing Saint's work in the city—don't ask details." Shelf-strong : Resilient, independent, able to survive hardship. "Shelf-strong people don't complain—they endure." Valley-soft : Weak, dependent on comforts, unable to handle difficulty. Insult. "The Crown's soldiers are valley-soft—one winter here would kill them." Profanity and Vulgarity Strong language reveals cultural preoccupations and boundaries. Common Profanity Loom-fucked : The most common strong profanity, implying fate has cursed someone or something. Extremely vulgar in formal contexts, casual in lower-class speech. "The whole deal's Loom-fucked from the start." Thread-shit : Worthless, meaningless, garbage. "That contract's thread-shit—not worth the paper." Warden's ass : Reference to authority figures, always derogatory. "Kiss the Warden's ass if you want, I won't." Church-cock : A religious hypocrite, particularly one who displays piety while acting immorally. Very vulgar, potentially dangerous if overheard by Church officials. "The bishop's a Church-cock—preaches poverty from his mansion." Residue-rot : Decay, corruption, something fundamentally spoiled. "There's Residue-rot through the whole organization." Pattern-piss : Nonsense, lies, worthless speech. "His promises are pattern-piss—never delivers." Curses and Maledictions Elsewhere take you : A curse wishing someone into the terrifying alternate reality. Moderate strength. "Elsewhere take you and your complaints." May your thread fray : Wishing someone ill fortune, pattern degradation. "May your thread fray, you cheating bastard." Correction's coming : Threat implying someone will face pattern-enforcement. "Keep talking and Correction's coming." Thread's end to you : Hostile farewell wishing death. Strong curse. "Thread's end to you and your family." Loom-forget you : Wishing someone erased from fate, unremembered. Particularly harsh. "Loom-forget you—you were never worth remembering." Romantic and Sexual Slang Intimate relationships generate euphemistic and direct vocabulary. Relationship Terms Threading : Courting, dating, pursuing romantic relationship. "They've been threading for months—wedding soon, probably." Woven together : Married, permanently committed. "Once you're woven together, there's no easy separation." Loose threads : Casual relationships without commitment. "He's got loose threads all over the city." Pattern-match : Compatible partners, people whose patterns suggest good romantic fit. "They're a perfect pattern-match—everyone says so." Knotted : Married, informal usage. "Got knotted last spring, first child coming soon." Unthreading : Divorce, separation, ending committed relationship. "They're unthreading—couldn't make it work." Tangled up : Romantically involved in complicated way, often with multiple people or inappropriate partners. "She's tangled up with her employer—going to end badly." Sexual Slang Night-weaving : Sexual activity, euphemistic. "They're night-weaving every chance they get." Elsewhere touch : Unusual sexual preferences, particularly those considered deviant. References Elsewhere's strangeness. "He's got an Elsewhere touch about him—likes things most wouldn't." Pattern-heat : Sexual attraction, desire. "The pattern-heat between them is obvious." Flesh trade : Prostitution, whether legal or illegal. "She works the flesh trade down by the docks." Shaped for pleasure : Someone modified by Flesh Shaping for sexual purposes. Usually exploitative context. "The pleasure houses in Vent Lands have workers shaped for pleasure—disturbing to most visitors." Criminal Slang The underworld maintains specialized vocabulary for operational security and group identity. Organizational Terms Silk work : Activity for the Silk Threads organization. "He's doing silk work now—good money, dangerous company." Coral run : A smuggling operation, particularly maritime. "The coral run went wrong—lost the cargo and two crew." Hollow business : Resistance activity, Hollow Saints work. "She's in hollow business—idealist, not in it for profit." Activity Terms Thread-cut : Murder. "The merchant got thread-cut for talking to Wardens." Pattern-slip : Forgery, particularly of pattern-certificates. "Quality pattern-slip costs five thousand marks minimum." Warden-dodge : Evading authorities, particularly pattern-enforcement. "He's been Warden-dodging for years—changes cities every few months." Residue-lift : Theft of Residue. "Residue-lift is death if they catch you—worth it if you don't." Clean weave : No criminal record, nothing connecting someone to illegal activity. "Need someone with a clean weave for the front operation." Knotted up : Arrested, imprisoned. Criminal usage of common idiom. "He got knotted up last week—won't talk, but they're pressing hard." Status and Role Terms Loose end : Lowest-ranking criminal, expendable. "Started as a loose end, worked up to running a district." Knot-man : Enforcer, someone who handles violence. "Send the knot-men if they don't pay by week's end." Thread-Captain : District boss in Silk Threads, leader in general criminal context. "The Thread-Captain wants his cut before anyone else touches the money." Harbor-master : Someone who controls criminal operations at a port, often but not always Coral Syndicate. "The harbor-master takes ten percent of everything moving through." Occupational Slang Different professions develop specialized informal vocabulary. Thread-counter : Bureaucrat, someone obsessed with regulations and procedures. "The thread-counters delayed the permit another month." Pattern-pusher : Church official, particularly one who emphasizes pattern-acceptance doctrine. "The pattern-pushers came through the village demanding increased tithes." Coin-weigher : Merchant, banker, anyone focused on money. Neutral or slightly derogatory. "Ask the coin-weighers about the investment—they know the numbers." Flesh-twister : Flesh Shaper, always derogatory. "Don't trust the flesh-twisters—they see you as raw material." Loom-reader : Pattern-reader, fortune-teller. "The Loom-reader says next month's good for travel—worth what you paid her." Warden-dog : A Warden, always hostile. "Warden-dogs came through questioning everyone about the texts." Crown-servant : Government official, neutral or mocking. "Crown-servants get paid whether anything works or not." Ship-skin : Sailor, particularly experienced maritime worker. "The ship-skins say the weather's turning—trust their sense over charts." Food and Drink Slang Sustenance generates its own vocabulary: Grain-drunk : Intoxicated on beer or grain spirits. "He's grain-drunk before noon most days." Wine-thread : Someone who drinks wine rather than beer, implying higher status or pretension. "Gone all wine-thread since the promotion." Market-scraps : Poor quality food, barely edible. "We're down to market-scraps until the wages come." Church-bread : Charity food from Church distribution. Accepting it confirms poverty. "Rather starve than eat Church-bread and their lectures." Reaches-salt : Seafood, also used to mean "authentic" or "genuine." "That story's Reaches-salt—actually happened, not made up." Festival-fat : Well-fed, prosperous, comfortable. "Looking festival-fat—business must be good." Famine-thin : Malnourished, desperate, impoverished. "The refugees came in famine-thin—hadn't eaten in days." Greetings and Farewells Social interactions use formulaic expressions: Positive Expressions Threads be kind : Good luck wish, general positive farewell. "Threads be kind on your journey." Smooth weaving : Have a good day, hope things go well. "Smooth weaving until we meet again." May the Loom favor you : Formal blessing, religious overtone. "May the Loom favor you in your petition to the Crown." Until the pattern crosses : See you again, expectation of future meeting. "Until the pattern crosses, friend." Good thread to you : Simple positive greeting or farewell. "Good thread to you this morning." Negative or Cautionary Expressions Thread's end to you : Hostile farewell wishing death. Strong curse. "Thread's end to you, betrayer." Warden's watch : Be careful, warning of danger. Can be sincere or sarcastic. "Warden's watch on that road—they're checking everyone." Attendance sees : Reminder that observation is constant. "Attendance sees, so keep your opinions quiet." The Loom remembers : Warning that actions have consequences tracked by the system. "Cheat if you want, but the Loom remembers." Integration with Worldbuilding This living language document serves multiple purposes. For writers, it provides authentic dialogue options that reveal character background, social position, and regional origin. For readers or players, it creates immersion in a world where even casual speech reflects the pattern system's pervasive influence. The vocabulary demonstrates how Hálcovans conceptualize their world: fate as literal weaving, status as predetermined pattern, observation as constant reality. Even profanity references the structures that constrain lives—there's no escaping the system even in speech meant to reject it. Regional variations allow characters' origins to show through word choice. Class markers in speech reinforce or subvert social boundaries. Criminal slang creates insider/outsider distinctions. All of this language serves story purposes while enriching world texture. Further documentation needed: formal vs. informal register distinctions, historical evolution of slang, age-based language variations, code-switching behaviors between contexts.
docs.title: Living Language Slang

docs.text: Language in Hálcova reflects and reinforces social structures. The formal High Hálcovan taught in schools and used in official contexts differs significantly from the living speech of streets, taverns, and homes. Slang, idioms, and vernacular expressions reveal how ordinary people understand and navigate their world—often subverting official meanings while using official vocabulary. This document catalogs contemporary informal language: the expressions pattern-privileged nobles use among themselves, the coded speech of criminals, the bitter humor of the constrained, and the regional variations that mark speakers' origins. Understanding this living language provides insight into Hálcovan culture beyond official pronouncements.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: The pattern system that structures society generates extensive vernacular vocabulary.
docs.title: Pattern-Related Slang

docs.text: Threadbare : Someone with severely constrained pattern status, used pejoratively. Implies poverty, limited rights, and low social position. "Don't trust him with the accounts—he's threadbare, desperate for any marks." Golden thread : A pattern-privileged individual. Can be neutral description or express envy/resentment depending on speaker's tone and context. "She's golden thread, born into the second ring. Never worked a day collecting Residue like us." Tangled : Confused, lost, or in complicated circumstances. References pattern threads becoming disordered. "I'm completely tangled on this contract—can't figure out who owes what to whom." Woven tight : Well-connected, powerful, secure in one's position. Implies strong pattern status and social relationships. "The magistrate's woven tight with the Crown—don't expect justice in his court." Loose end : An unreliable person, someone likely to cause problems. Also criminal slang for lowest-ranking members. "Keep your plans away from Marcus—he's a loose end waiting to unravel." Frayed : Damaged, broken, mentally unstable. Implies pattern degradation affecting behavior or capability. "She's been frayed since her son's Correction. Just stares at nothing." Smooth weave : Easy, uncomplicated, proceeding without problems. "The delivery went smooth weave—no inspections, no delays." Knotted up : In a complicated or difficult situation. When used about people, implies entanglement with problems. "The whole negotiation's knotted up now that they discovered the forgery." Cut from the cloth : Destined for something, pattern-determined to a particular fate. Often used ironically. "He's cut from the cloth for the arena—too stupid and aggressive for anything else." Reading the threads : Understanding a situation clearly, seeing truth beneath surface appearances. "She's reading the threads on this deal—knows exactly who's cheating whom."
docs.title: General Pattern Terms

docs.text: Ring-jumper : Someone attempting to rise above their pattern-assigned status. Pejorative from pattern-privileged perspective, sometimes admiring from below. "Another ring-jumper caught with forged certificates. They never learn." Circle-bound : Stuck in one's assigned social position with no possibility of advancement. Resignation or complaint depending on context. "We're all circle-bound—born to this ring, die in this ring." Status-stink : The indefinable quality that reveals someone's true pattern status despite attempts to appear otherwise. "No matter how fine his clothes, you can smell the status-stink on him." Privilege-blind : Unable or unwilling to recognize advantages of pattern-privileged position. Common complaint from below. "The nobles are privilege-blind—think everyone can just buy their way out of trouble."
docs.title: Status-Specific Terms

docs.text: The Loom—the vast predictive apparatus underlying Hálcovan society—generates extensive idiomatic language.
docs.title: Loom and Fate Idioms

docs.text: The Loom knows : Fate is inevitable, predetermined, beyond individual control. Can express genuine faith or bitter resignation. "Why fight it? The Loom knows what becomes of us." Following the pattern : Accepting fate, living according to what's been determined. Can be virtue (from Church perspective) or criticism (implying passivity). "He's just following the pattern—never questioned anything in his life." Loom's mercy : Expression of hope for favorable fate. "Loom's mercy we reach port before the storm hits." Against the weave : Fighting against fate, attempting impossible change. Usually implies futility. "Trying to save the condemned is against the weave—you'll only join them." Thread's end : Death approaching, fate concluding. "Old Márton's reached his thread's end. Won't see another harvest." New thread : A fresh start, rebirth, possibility of change. Somewhat subversive implication that fate might be altered. "Maybe the new posting will be a new thread—chance to become someone different."
docs.title: Fate Acceptance

docs.text: Attendance is watching : Be careful, you're being observed by those who track patterns. References the Attendance—operators of the Loom's monitoring functions. "Attendance is watching—keep your opinions about the Church quiet." Warden's eye : Under scrutiny by authorities, specifically pattern-enforcement. "He's been under Warden's eye since his brother's arrest. Every move watched." Loom's blind spot : Somewhere or something unmonitored, outside normal observation. Valuable knowledge for criminals and dissidents. "The warehouse is in the Loom's blind spot—even Attendance can't see what happens there." Thread-traced : Being tracked through pattern connections, unable to hide. "Once they thread-trace you, running's pointless. They'll find you anywhere."
docs.title: Observation and Scrutiny

docs.text: The five seasons shape temporal idioms: Fávarzach-mad : Crazy, unpredictable, chaotic. References the fifth season's disruption of normal patterns. "The market's gone Fávarzach-mad—prices changing by the hour." Évresá-green : Young, inexperienced, naive. References spring's new growth. "He's still Évresá-green, thinks hard work actually gets rewarded." Hórvam-cold : Emotionally distant, unfeeling, calculating. References winter's chill. "The magistrate's Hórvam-cold—don't expect sympathy." Fágvard-dark : Depressed, gloomy, pessimistic. References autumn's declining light. "She's been Fágvard-dark since the bankruptcy. Barely speaks." Szárnyév-bright : Optimistic, cheerful, perhaps naively positive. References summer's heat and light. "Still Szárnyév-bright about the venture? Wait until the bills arrive."
docs.title: Seasonal References

docs.text: Different social strata speak distinctly, using vocabulary that identifies their position.
docs.title: Class-Based Slang

docs.text: Nobility and wealthy pattern-privileged use terminology that reinforces their status: Beneath the weave : Lower classes, those below speaker's status. Dismissive. "Don't concern yourself with those beneath the weave—they have their place." Common thread : An ordinary person, someone without distinction. "He married a common thread—his family's still recovering from the scandal." Refined pattern : Cultured, educated, properly upper-class. "She displays a refined pattern—excellent education shows in everything she does." Proper threading : Correct behavior according to upper-class standards. "Proper threading requires acknowledging one's inferiors without engaging them." Unraveled : Socially ruined, reputation destroyed. Devastating for those dependent on social standing. "After the scandal, he's completely unraveled. No house will receive him." Patterned up : Married into or otherwise acquired higher status. "She patterned up nicely—husband's family is third ring."
docs.title: Pattern-Privileged Speech

docs.text: Merchants, craftsmen, and laborers use different vocabulary: Marks and sparks : Money and trouble, the constants of working life. "It's all marks and sparks with him—chasing coin and running from problems." Coin-counter : A merchant, often derogatory when used by non-merchants. "The coin-counters raised prices again. They'll bleed us dry." Thread-puller : Someone who manipulates others for advantage. "Don't trust her—she's a thread-puller working every angle." Warden-bait : Risky behavior likely to attract enforcement attention. "Selling those texts is Warden-bait. You'll hang." Church-pocket : Someone who tithes heavily or displays excessive religious conformity. "He's a real Church-pocket—first at every service, loudest in every hymn." Guild-groveler : One who seeks favor from guild authorities at expense of fellow workers. "The guild-grovelers reported the extra moonlighting. Lost three of us our positions."
docs.title: Working Class Speech

docs.text: Those with constrained status develop coded and bitter vocabulary: Golden bastards : Pattern-privileged individuals, hostile. "The golden bastards took our farm. Four generations, gone in a ruling." Warden-food : Someone likely to be Corrected or executed. "Keep your mouth shut or you're Warden-food." Free thread : Someone who has escaped pattern-constraint—legally through exceptional service, illegally through forgery or flight. Rare and admired. "They say he's a free thread now, living in the Reaches under a new name." Residue-bait : Someone likely to die soon, either through dangerous work or pattern-enforcement. Dark humor. "New workers are just Residue-bait. Half won't last the season." Loom-fucked : Doomed by fate, cursed by circumstances. Vulgar and common. "We're all Loom-fucked, born to this and dying to this." Certificate-dreaming : Hoping for improved status through legitimate means. Usually ironic. "Still certificate-dreaming? Nobody gets promoted out of the fifth ring." Hollow : Empty of pattern-control, free from observation. Either describes places outside monitoring or people who've escaped the system. "The mountain village is hollow—no Attendance, no Wardens, just people living."
docs.title: Pattern-Constrained Speech

docs.text: Regional identity shows in distinctive vocabulary.
docs.title: Regional Slang

docs.text: The political and cultural center generates vocabulary that others often adopt: Fonvárs fancy : Pretentious, putting on airs, aspiring above one's station. Used throughout Hálcova about capital affectations. "Look at him with his Fonvárs fancy manners—still reeks of the farm." Crown's coin : Official, legitimate, properly authorized. "Make sure the shipment's Crown's coin—no unauthorized cargo." Market-mouth : Gossip, unreliable rumor, speculation. "Don't believe market-mouth—half of what they say is invented." Arena-ready : Tough, capable, ready for confrontation. "She's arena-ready—watched her break a man's arm without changing expression." Palace-pure : Something so refined or perfect it might belong in the Crown's residence. Can be genuine or ironic. "The embroidery's palace-pure—must have cost a fortune."
docs.title: Heartlands

docs.text: Maritime culture produces distinctive vocabulary: Salt-sense : Practical wisdom, knowledge gained through experience rather than education. "He's got salt-sense about ships—formal training, no, but knows what works." Tide-turner : An opportunist, someone who changes positions with circumstances. "Politicians are all tide-turners—support whoever's winning." Harbor-rat : A smuggler, criminal, or generally disreputable dock worker. Can be pejorative or affectionate depending on context. "Half the harbor-rats in town owe me favors." League-legal : Technically permitted but ethically questionable. References the Reaches League's flexible standards. "The cargo's League-legal—don't ask what it is or where it's going." Storm-blessed : A lucky survivor, someone who's escaped danger through fortune. "She's storm-blessed—only survivor of three shipwrecks." Barnacled : Stuck in place, unable to move forward. "He's been barnacled in that position for fifteen years—never promoted, never fired." Reef-blind : Unable to see obvious dangers, navigating toward disaster. "The investors are reef-blind—can't see they're funding their own ruin."
docs.title: Reaches

docs.text: Technical and modified culture creates specialized vocabulary: Shaped : Modified by Flesh Shaping, often obvious enough to be visible. Can be neutral or derogatory. "The shaped workers do double production—and die in half the time." Consortium-clean : Officially approved by the Flesh Shaping Consortium, meeting their standards. "The modification's Consortium-clean—all proper documentation." Experiment : A risky venture with uncertain outcome. Also derogatory for people with unusual Flesh Shaping. "The new business is an experiment—might make fortune, might lose everything." Technical : Overly complicated, also a sarcastic excuse for unethical behavior. "He's being technical about the contract—meaning he's cheating us legally." Steam-headed : Obsessed with innovation, sometimes to the point of ignoring practical concerns. "Don't get steam-headed over the design—it has to actually work." Meat-wrong : Something deeply disturbing about a person or situation, especially regarding Flesh Shaping. "There's something meat-wrong about that place. The workers don't look right."
docs.title: Vent Lands

docs.text: Remote mountain culture maintains distinct vocabulary, some representing quiet resistance: Mountain-free : Independent, outside central control. "The highland villages are mountain-free—live by their own rules." Threadist : A resistance member or sympathizer. Self-identification among believers, accusation among opponents. "Half the village are Threadists—the other half pretend not to notice." Hollow : Empty of pattern-control, truly free. Core Threadist concept that's entered general speech. "She dreams of hollow places where the Loom can't reach." Saint's work : Resistance activity, actions supporting the Hollow Saints. Coded speech. "He's doing Saint's work in the city—don't ask details." Shelf-strong : Resilient, independent, able to survive hardship. "Shelf-strong people don't complain—they endure." Valley-soft : Weak, dependent on comforts, unable to handle difficulty. Insult. "The Crown's soldiers are valley-soft—one winter here would kill them."
docs.title: Far Shelf

docs.text: Strong language reveals cultural preoccupations and boundaries.
docs.title: Profanity and Vulgarity

docs.text: Loom-fucked : The most common strong profanity, implying fate has cursed someone or something. Extremely vulgar in formal contexts, casual in lower-class speech. "The whole deal's Loom-fucked from the start." Thread-shit : Worthless, meaningless, garbage. "That contract's thread-shit—not worth the paper." Warden's ass : Reference to authority figures, always derogatory. "Kiss the Warden's ass if you want, I won't." Church-cock : A religious hypocrite, particularly one who displays piety while acting immorally. Very vulgar, potentially dangerous if overheard by Church officials. "The bishop's a Church-cock—preaches poverty from his mansion." Residue-rot : Decay, corruption, something fundamentally spoiled. "There's Residue-rot through the whole organization." Pattern-piss : Nonsense, lies, worthless speech. "His promises are pattern-piss—never delivers."
docs.title: Common Profanity

docs.text: Elsewhere take you : A curse wishing someone into the terrifying alternate reality. Moderate strength. "Elsewhere take you and your complaints." May your thread fray : Wishing someone ill fortune, pattern degradation. "May your thread fray, you cheating bastard." Correction's coming : Threat implying someone will face pattern-enforcement. "Keep talking and Correction's coming." Thread's end to you : Hostile farewell wishing death. Strong curse. "Thread's end to you and your family." Loom-forget you : Wishing someone erased from fate, unremembered. Particularly harsh. "Loom-forget you—you were never worth remembering."
docs.title: Curses and Maledictions

docs.text: Intimate relationships generate euphemistic and direct vocabulary.
docs.title: Romantic and Sexual Slang

docs.text: Threading : Courting, dating, pursuing romantic relationship. "They've been threading for months—wedding soon, probably." Woven together : Married, permanently committed. "Once you're woven together, there's no easy separation." Loose threads : Casual relationships without commitment. "He's got loose threads all over the city." Pattern-match : Compatible partners, people whose patterns suggest good romantic fit. "They're a perfect pattern-match—everyone says so." Knotted : Married, informal usage. "Got knotted last spring, first child coming soon." Unthreading : Divorce, separation, ending committed relationship. "They're unthreading—couldn't make it work." Tangled up : Romantically involved in complicated way, often with multiple people or inappropriate partners. "She's tangled up with her employer—going to end badly."
docs.title: Relationship Terms

docs.text: Night-weaving : Sexual activity, euphemistic. "They're night-weaving every chance they get." Elsewhere touch : Unusual sexual preferences, particularly those considered deviant. References Elsewhere's strangeness. "He's got an Elsewhere touch about him—likes things most wouldn't." Pattern-heat : Sexual attraction, desire. "The pattern-heat between them is obvious." Flesh trade : Prostitution, whether legal or illegal. "She works the flesh trade down by the docks." Shaped for pleasure : Someone modified by Flesh Shaping for sexual purposes. Usually exploitative context. "The pleasure houses in Vent Lands have workers shaped for pleasure—disturbing to most visitors."
docs.title: Sexual Slang

docs.text: The underworld maintains specialized vocabulary for operational security and group identity.
docs.title: Criminal Slang

docs.text: Silk work : Activity for the Silk Threads organization. "He's doing silk work now—good money, dangerous company." Coral run : A smuggling operation, particularly maritime. "The coral run went wrong—lost the cargo and two crew." Hollow business : Resistance activity, Hollow Saints work. "She's in hollow business—idealist, not in it for profit."
docs.title: Organizational Terms

docs.text: Thread-cut : Murder. "The merchant got thread-cut for talking to Wardens." Pattern-slip : Forgery, particularly of pattern-certificates. "Quality pattern-slip costs five thousand marks minimum." Warden-dodge : Evading authorities, particularly pattern-enforcement. "He's been Warden-dodging for years—changes cities every few months." Residue-lift : Theft of Residue. "Residue-lift is death if they catch you—worth it if you don't." Clean weave : No criminal record, nothing connecting someone to illegal activity. "Need someone with a clean weave for the front operation." Knotted up : Arrested, imprisoned. Criminal usage of common idiom. "He got knotted up last week—won't talk, but they're pressing hard."
docs.title: Activity Terms

docs.text: Loose end : Lowest-ranking criminal, expendable. "Started as a loose end, worked up to running a district." Knot-man : Enforcer, someone who handles violence. "Send the knot-men if they don't pay by week's end." Thread-Captain : District boss in Silk Threads, leader in general criminal context. "The Thread-Captain wants his cut before anyone else touches the money." Harbor-master : Someone who controls criminal operations at a port, often but not always Coral Syndicate. "The harbor-master takes ten percent of everything moving through."
docs.title: Status and Role Terms

docs.text: Different professions develop specialized informal vocabulary. Thread-counter : Bureaucrat, someone obsessed with regulations and procedures. "The thread-counters delayed the permit another month." Pattern-pusher : Church official, particularly one who emphasizes pattern-acceptance doctrine. "The pattern-pushers came through the village demanding increased tithes." Coin-weigher : Merchant, banker, anyone focused on money. Neutral or slightly derogatory. "Ask the coin-weighers about the investment—they know the numbers." Flesh-twister : Flesh Shaper, always derogatory. "Don't trust the flesh-twisters—they see you as raw material." Loom-reader : Pattern-reader, fortune-teller. "The Loom-reader says next month's good for travel—worth what you paid her." Warden-dog : A Warden, always hostile. "Warden-dogs came through questioning everyone about the texts." Crown-servant : Government official, neutral or mocking. "Crown-servants get paid whether anything works or not." Ship-skin : Sailor, particularly experienced maritime worker. "The ship-skins say the weather's turning—trust their sense over charts."
docs.title: Occupational Slang

docs.text: Sustenance generates its own vocabulary: Grain-drunk : Intoxicated on beer or grain spirits. "He's grain-drunk before noon most days." Wine-thread : Someone who drinks wine rather than beer, implying higher status or pretension. "Gone all wine-thread since the promotion." Market-scraps : Poor quality food, barely edible. "We're down to market-scraps until the wages come." Church-bread : Charity food from Church distribution. Accepting it confirms poverty. "Rather starve than eat Church-bread and their lectures." Reaches-salt : Seafood, also used to mean "authentic" or "genuine." "That story's Reaches-salt—actually happened, not made up." Festival-fat : Well-fed, prosperous, comfortable. "Looking festival-fat—business must be good." Famine-thin : Malnourished, desperate, impoverished. "The refugees came in famine-thin—hadn't eaten in days."
docs.title: Food and Drink Slang

docs.text: Social interactions use formulaic expressions:
docs.title: Greetings and Farewells

docs.text: Threads be kind : Good luck wish, general positive farewell. "Threads be kind on your journey." Smooth weaving : Have a good day, hope things go well. "Smooth weaving until we meet again." May the Loom favor you : Formal blessing, religious overtone. "May the Loom favor you in your petition to the Crown." Until the pattern crosses : See you again, expectation of future meeting. "Until the pattern crosses, friend." Good thread to you : Simple positive greeting or farewell. "Good thread to you this morning."
docs.title: Positive Expressions

docs.text: Thread's end to you : Hostile farewell wishing death. Strong curse. "Thread's end to you, betrayer." Warden's watch : Be careful, warning of danger. Can be sincere or sarcastic. "Warden's watch on that road—they're checking everyone." Attendance sees : Reminder that observation is constant. "Attendance sees, so keep your opinions quiet." The Loom remembers : Warning that actions have consequences tracked by the system. "Cheat if you want, but the Loom remembers."

docs.text: Attunement and Marks Attunement and Marks Story Reference: This section is informed by "The Warden" (Vèscalìn's attunement and marks), "Bleed" (attunement as risk), and "The Woven" (Loom operators). The costs and consequences of attunement are dramatized through the experiences of Wardens and Loom workers. Implications in the Stories: - Attunement is both a privilege and a burden, granting power but also exposing the bearer to danger and social stigma. Attunement Attunement is the process by which certain individuals, such as Wardens and Loom operators, gain the ability to perceive patterns, violations, and metaphysical currents. This comes at a cost: Attunement marks appear around the eyes, and prolonged exposure can lead to bleed, memory loss, or psychological strain. Marks Attunement marks are visible signs of metaphysical sensitivity. They are both a badge of office and a warning, marking the bearer as someone who has seen too much. Effects Enhanced perception of patterns and violations Susceptibility to bleed and pattern contamination Social stigma or reverence, depending on context See also: [the_loom.md], [law_justice.md], [echoes_and_binding.md]. docs.text: Echoes and Binding Echoes and Binding Story Reference: This section is primarily informed by "Bleed" (02_bleed_story_v2.md), with supporting details from "The Warden" and "The Constrained." The nature of echoes, bleed, and dissolution are dramatized through the experiences of Fèinnav, Vèscalìn, and the Wardens. Implications in the Stories: - In "Bleed," echoes are not just tools but repositories of dangerous memory, and the phenomenon of bleed drives the plot as forbidden knowledge resurfaces. - "The Warden" explores the enforcement of dissolution and the ethical dilemmas faced by those who police echoes. - "The Constrained" shows the social and psychological costs of echo labor and the precariousness of identity for both the living and the dead. Echoes Echoes are the bound remnants of the dead, anchored to the living world through objects (anchors) and maintained with Residue. They serve as labor, advisors, or tools, but their existence is precarious: echoes degrade, lose memories, and may awaken, regaining fragments of their former selves. Bleed Story Reference: Bleed is the central phenomenon in "Bleed" (02_bleed_story_v2.md), where the protagonist's memories and identity are threatened by the echo's influence. Implications in the Stories: - Bleed is both a danger and a source of power. It blurs the line between self and other, living and dead, and is a metaphor for trauma and forbidden knowledge. Bleed is the phenomenon where memories, habits, or even personality traits of an echo begin to transfer to the living binder. This is both a risk and a source of forbidden knowledge. Dissolution Story Reference: Dissolution is dramatized in "The Warden" (04_the_warden_story_v2.md), where Wardens must enforce the destruction of unstable echoes, and in "Bleed," where dissolution is both a threat and a release. Implications in the Stories: - Dissolution is not just a technical process but a moral and emotional crisis. It raises questions about the rights of echoes and the responsibilities of the living. Echoes that awaken or become unstable are subject to dissolution—a process that unravels their pattern, often violently. Wardens are responsible for enforcing dissolution protocols. The Economics of Death Story Reference: The economics of echo binding are explored in "Bleed" (the cost of Residue and echo labor), "The Constrained" (echoes as social capital), and "The Warden" (regulation and enforcement). Implications in the Stories: - The stories show how access to echoes and Residue is a form of privilege, and how the regulation of death labor reinforces social hierarchies. Binding echoes is a regulated profession, with strict controls on the number and type of echoes a person may carry. Residue, the substance required to maintain echoes, is expensive and tightly rationed. Rituals Binding : The act of anchoring an echo to an object. Release : The act of letting an echo go, either voluntarily or by force. Dissolution : The destruction of an echo's pattern. See also: [the_loom.md], [sorscad_cards.md], [law_justice.md]. See also: * [Patterns and Bindings](/Halcova/halcova/fate_system/patterns_and_bindings/) * [Attunement and Marks](/Halcova/halcova/fate_system/attunement_and_marks/) * [Institutions and Roles](/Halcova/halcova/society/institutions_and_roles/) * [Major Families](/Halcova/halcova/society/major_families/) * [Bleed (Story)](/Halcova/halcova/halcova_stories/bleed/) ...existing content from world/fate_system/echoes_and_binding.md...

Implications in the Stories: - Bleed is both a danger and a source of power. It blurs the line between self and other, living and dead, and is a metaphor for trauma and forbidden knowledge. Bleed is the phenomenon where memories, habits, or even personality traits of an echo begin to transfer to the living binder. This is both a risk and a source of forbidden knowledge.
docs.title: Bleed

docs.text: Story Reference: Dissolution is dramatized in "The Warden" (04_the_warden_story_v2.md), where Wardens must enforce the destruction of unstable echoes, and in "Bleed," where dissolution is both a threat and a release. Implications in the Stories: - Dissolution is not just a technical process but a moral and emotional crisis. It raises questions about the rights of echoes and the responsibilities of the living. Echoes that awaken or become unstable are subject to dissolution—a process that unravels their pattern, often violently. Wardens are responsible for enforcing dissolution protocols.
docs.title: Dissolution

docs.text: Story Reference: The economics of echo binding are explored in "Bleed" (the cost of Residue and echo labor), "The Constrained" (echoes as social capital), and "The Warden" (regulation and enforcement). Implications in the Stories: - The stories show how access to echoes and Residue is a form of privilege, and how the regulation of death labor reinforces social hierarchies. Binding echoes is a regulated profession, with strict controls on the number and type of echoes a person may carry. Residue, the substance required to maintain echoes, is expensive and tightly rationed.
docs.title: The Economics of Death

docs.text: Patterns and Bindings See also: * [Pattern Caste System](/Halcova/halcova/society/pattern_caste_system/) * [Institutions and Roles](/Halcova/halcova/society/institutions_and_roles/) * [Echoes and Binding](/Halcova/halcova/fate_system/echoes_and_binding/) * [Attunement and Marks](/Halcova/halcova/fate_system/attunement_and_marks/) * [The Attendance Truth](/Halcova/halcova/foundations/the_attendance_truth/) * [The Five Arts](/Halcova/halcova/magic/the_five_arts/) * [The Reading (Story)](/Halcova/halcova/halcova_stories/the_reading/) Patterns and Bindings Story Reference: This section draws primarily from "The Reading" (01_the_reading_story_v3.md), with supporting details from "The Constrained" and "The Warden." The Binding ceremony, pattern fraud, and the Registry are central to Fèinnav’s arc, Àrnnav’s fate, and Vèscalìn’s investigation. Implications in the Stories: - Fèinnav’s Binding in "The Reading" exposes the gap between the metaphysical truth of the Attendance and the social reality of purchased patterns. Her family’s manipulation of the Szòvòtar and the Registry is a microcosm of systemic corruption. - Àrnnav’s experience as pattern-constrained in "The Constrained" shows the lived consequences of a difficult pattern, and the social stratification that results. - Vèscalìn’s discoveries in "The Warden" reveal the long-term effects of pattern fraud, both on individuals and the stability of the system itself. Overview The pattern system is the metaphysical and social architecture that underpins Halcova’s society. Every citizen is subject to a Binding ceremony, where their pattern is revealed (or, in some cases, purchased or adjusted) and recorded in the Registry. Patterns shape fate, privilege, and constraint, determining the course of a person’s life. The Binding Ceremony The Binding is a public ritual, conducted by a Szòvòtar, in which the Attendance is invoked to reveal the true pattern of the individual. The ceremony is both sacred and bureaucratic, blending ancient liturgy with the practicalities of record-keeping. Patterns are drawn from the Loom, interpreted, and inscribed in ink that is meant to be indelible. Pattern Types Story Reference: Pattern types and their consequences are dramatized in "The Reading" (Fèinnav and Àrnnav’s contrasting outcomes), "The Constrained" (Àrnnav’s Thorn/Maze pattern), and "The Warden" (Vèscalìn’s true pattern revealed as Thorn/Maze, not Tower-Watch). Implications in the Stories: - The distinction between privileged and constrained patterns is not just metaphysical but deeply social, affecting marriage, work, and even survival. The stories show how these categories are both enforced and subverted. Pattern-Privileged : Those whose patterns grant them social mobility, wealth, or influence (e.g., Ùtcai, Szèrrav, Coròncai). Pattern-Constrained : Those whose patterns are considered difficult, limiting, or unlucky (e.g., Tòvismaht, Vèszttar, Cèresztàhd). Pattern-Pending : Adolescents awaiting their Binding, or adults who have rejected the system and are thus outcast. Pattern Adjustment and Fraud Story Reference: Pattern fraud is a central plot in "The Reading" (the Còcalnòc family’s bribes), "Bleed" (echoes remembering the truth), and "The Warden" (systemic cover-up and investigation). Implications in the Stories: - The ability to purchase a pattern is a form of generational power. The exposure of this fraud is the catalyst for unrest and reform, as seen in the triptych and quintet stories.

docs.text: The Loom: Fate's Instrument Overview The Loom is the distributed network of devices, rituals, and institutions that read, record, and predict fate in Hálcova. It is not a single machine but a system—part arcane technology, part religious practice, part bureaucratic apparatus. More importantly: The Loom may be a point of contact with Fate. Whether Fate is an Elsewhere entity, a collection of entities, or something stranger is a matter of fierce theological debate. What's undeniable is that The Loom works . Its predictions are accurate far beyond statistical chance. And something answers when the Loom-Keepers perform their divinations. Historical Origins: The Bootstrap Question The Fundamental Problem The Loom runs on Pattern Residue. Pattern Residue comes from death. But the Loom (or something like it) appears to predate the current Residue economy. The polar structures, the moon arrangement, and certain archaeological evidence suggest the system existed before the cooling event that created the death-dependent world we know. How did the Loom start if it needs death to run, but death (at scale) required the conditions the Loom may have created? The Three-Phase Model Scholars who study this question propose a developmental sequence: Phase 1: The Proto-Loom (Pre-Cooling) The ancient builders created the system's foundation using unknown power sources: The polar structures were built The moons were arranged into resonance The Attendance (or something that became it) was contacted/created/summoned This phase did not require Pattern Residue—or used Residue from sources we don't understand The technology and knowledge from this era is lost Phase 2: The Cooling Event (Transition) Something happened that changed everything: Massive Residue release (mass death? Elsewhere incursion? deliberate engineering?) The net-negative thermodynamic cycle began Hálcova started cooling rapidly The pattern-economy emerged as Residue became available at scale The ancient builders disappeared (died? transformed? departed?) Phase 3: The Current Era The Loom we know is an adaptation, not the original design: Pattern-engines run on Residue because that's what's available The distributed Node network was built over millennia by successor civilizations The core function (the Attendance connection) may not actually require Residue The infrastructure (Nodes, engines, rituals) does require Residue Current operators maintain the system without understanding its origins What This Means The Attendance Is Older Than The Engines Whatever answers Loom queries existed before the current infrastructure. The pattern-engines are interfaces, not sources. Destroy every Node, and the Attendance might still be there—just unreachable. The Residue Dependency Is Acquired The original system didn't need death. The current system does because it was rebuilt by people who only had death-energy available. This is adaptation, not design. The Builders Knew More The ancient builders understood something we don't. They created (or contacted) the Attendance. They arranged the moons. They built structures that still function after 40,000+ years. Their power source and methods are lost. What The Loom Is The Physical Infrastructure Loom-Nodes Distributed across Hálcova, Loom-Nodes are the physical anchors of the system: Major Nodes : Large installations in capital cities and religious centers. Cathedral-sized complexes housing pattern-engines, archives, and ritual spaces. Staffed by hundreds of Loom-Keepers. Minor Nodes : Town-level facilities. Smaller pattern-engines, local registries, drawing chambers. Staffed by licensed practitioners and temple appointees. Mobile Nodes : Portable equipment for frontier regions, military operations, and emergency readings. Less accurate but functional. Private Nodes : Illegal or gray-market installations operated by wealthy individuals, corporations, and criminal organizations. Quality varies wildly. The Pattern-Engines At the heart of each Node is a pattern-engine—a device that: Records Sórscad data from drawings Performs predictive calculations Communicates with other Nodes (major ones only) Interfaces with... something. The source of The Loom's impossible accuracy. Pattern-engines are part clockwork, part alchemical apparatus, part something that defies categorization. Their construction is a closely guarded secret. Their fuel is Pattern Residue—the same substance that maintains echo anchors. The Institutional Structure The Loom-Keepers A guild-priesthood that operates The Loom. They are: Trained in pattern-reading, engine operation, and ritual practice Licensed by both religious and civil authorities Bound by oaths that constrain their use of Loom-knowledge Organized hierarchically from apprentices to High Weavers Loom-Keepers occupy an ambiguous social position. They're essential to governance, commerce, and religion. They're also viewed with suspicion—people who know too much about everyone else's fate. The Registry The accumulated database of all Sórscad patterns ever drawn. Stored in: Physical archives (paper, metal plates, encoded materials) Pattern-engine memory (poorly understood how this works) Distributed across major Nodes with varying levels of completeness The Registry is legally protected, politically contested, and practically impossible to fully secure. Pattern-theft, registry-manipulation, and archive-raids are all documented crimes. The Calculation Houses Secondary institutions that use Loom data for specific purposes: Actuarial Houses : Insurance and risk pricing Credit Temples : Lending and debt assessment Merchant Guilds : Employment screening and partner evaluation Legal Colleges : Sentencing guidance and contract validity Military Orders : Recruitment and tactical prediction These institutions license Loom access from the Keepers. The fees are substantial. The data is invaluable. What The Loom Does Pattern Recording When a Sórscad is drawn, The Loom: Captures the pattern through ritual interface with the pattern-engine Records the five-circle combination in the Registry Indexes the pattern by family, region, lineage, and other metadata Transmits (major Nodes only) the record to the central archives The drawing ritual itself involves the pattern-engine. The subject touches interface plates while a Loom-Keeper performs the ceremonial reading. What happens during those moments is described differently by different traditions, but the result is consistent: a legible Sórscad, recorded and indexed. Prediction Given a person's Sórscad, The Loom can calculate: Life-arc probabilities : Likely career paths, relationship patterns, death-circumstances Decision tendencies : How they'll respond to specific choice-types Risk profiles : Probability of crime, default, illness, violence Compatibility assessments : How two patterns will interact in partnership, employment, or conflict The predictions are probabilistic, not deterministic. The Loom says "73% likelihood of early violent death," not "you will die by the sword at age 34." But the probabilities are accurate . Eerily accurate. Accurate enough that institutions stake fortunes on them. Deviation Detection The Loom tracks when actual outcomes diverge from predictions: Minor deviations : Within expected variance, noted but not flagged Significant deviations : Outside normal variance, flagged for review Anomalous deviations : Statistically improbable, triggering investigation Deviation can indicate: Measurement error (rare) Environmental factors not in the model (common, usually ignored) Deliberate pattern-manipulation (criminal) Something outside Fate's purview (theologically troubling) The Source: Fate as Entity The Orthodox Position Orthodox theology holds that The Loom reads the will of The Weaver ( A Szövő )—the divine pattern-maker who determines all fates before birth. The Loom doesn't predict; it reveals . The pattern-engines don't calculate; they receive . Loom-Keepers don't read fate; they translate divine truth into mortal language. Deviation from your pattern isn't bad luck. It's sin. Acceptance of your pattern isn't fatalism. It's worship. The Heterodox Suspicion Critics and heretics have long suspected that The Loom's accuracy comes from somewhere specific: The Elsewhere Connection The Loom's impossible predictive power suggests contact with something beyond normal causality. The Elsewhere entities operate outside time, reference events that haven't happened, and seem to understand fate in ways mortals cannot. Possible relationships: Fate IS an Elsewhere entity (or entities). The Weaver is real, but it's not a god—it's an Elsewhere faction with interest in our world's pattern-structure. The Loom is a pact . The original Loom-builders made a deal, knowingly or not. The pattern-engines are anchors. The accuracy is the entity's end of the bargain. What do they receive in return? Pattern Residue is payment . The fuel that runs the engines might also be tribute to the entity/entities that make prediction possible. The Accountants . The Elsewhere faction obsessed with ledgers, debts, and balance fits suspiciously well with a system that tracks life-patterns and predicts outcomes. Did they design this? Do they operate it? What The Loom-Keepers Know Senior Loom-Keepers are aware that something answers their rituals. They call this presence by various names: The Voice in the Engine The Pattern-Behind-Pattern The Weaver's Hand The Attendance They know: It responds more strongly to certain rituals than others It seems interested in specific patterns (deviation cases especially) It occasionally provides information not requested It has never harmed a Keeper during proper operation Improper operation has consequences They don't know: What it actually is What it wants (beyond continued operation) Whether it's one entity or many Whether it's benevolent, malevolent, or indifferent What happens if The Loom ever stops working This uncertainty is not shared with the public. The Orthodoxy maintains that The Loom reads divine will. The Loom-Keepers maintain whatever story keeps the system running. The Accuracy Problem Why Does It Work? The Loom's predictions are accurate far beyond what statistical modeling should allow. Even accounting for: Feedback loops (predictions creating outcomes) Self-fulfilling prophecy (people acting on expectations) Survivorship bias (failures not tracked) The accuracy remains anomalous. People with Road-Path patterns really do tend toward linear careers. People with Blade-Hálmaht patterns really do die violently at elevated rates. The correlation is too strong to be coincidence. Possible explanations: 1. Fate is real and The Loom reads it correctly The pattern exists independent of The Loom The Loom is just a measurement tool Accuracy reflects underlying reality 2. The Loom creates what it predicts The measurement itself shapes the outcome Social structures enforce pattern-expectations Fate is constructed, not discovered 3. Something makes the predictions come true The Elsewhere entity/entities actively arrange outcomes The Loom's accuracy is maintained by intervention We're not being predicted; we're being managed 4. Some combination Patterns reflect real tendencies The Loom's measurement amplifies those tendencies External forces ensure accuracy where natural variance would cause deviation The truth is probably all four. The horror is that it might not matter—the system works regardless of why. The Bias That Serves Power The Loom is accurate. But accurate about what? The training data—centuries of Registry records—reflects: Historical power structures Past discrimination patterns Environmental factors misattributed to innate patterns Feedback loops already embedded The Loom predicts that Knot-Born patterns are high-risk. This is accurate—they do commit more crimes, default more often, die violently more frequently. But why? Because: They're born into poverty They're denied opportunity They're policed more heavily They're priced out of legitimate paths The Loom sees the outcome and attributes it to the pattern. The pattern becomes a prediction. The prediction justifies the treatment. The treatment creates the outcome. This is not a bug. The Loom reflects the world accurately. The world is structured to produce these outcomes. The Loom validates that structure. Pattern Residue: The Fuel What It Is Pattern Residue (working term—conlang name TBD) is the energy released when patterns dissolve. When something with a Sórscad dies: The pattern loses its anchor The five circles begin to dissipate Energy is released during dissolution This energy can be captured and stored Where It Comes From Natural Sources : Any death of a pattern-bearing creature More from traumatic deaths (violent release) More from heavy patterns (rich fate-weight) Concentrated at mass-death sites (battlefields, plagues, disasters) Manufactured Sources : Executions (legal, controlled harvest) Blood-sport (entertainment plus production) War (the most efficient source) Plague management (letting outbreaks run for harvest) Livestock (animal patterns are weaker but abundant) What It Does For The Loom : Powers pattern-engines Fuels divination rituals Enables Node-to-Node communication Maintains the connection to... whatever answers For Core Binding : Maintains echo coherence in anchors Prevents degradation and fragmentation Consumed over time (ongoing cost) Higher-quality Residue produces more stable echoes For Other Uses : Alchemical applications (numerous) Probability-nudging devices (expensive, unreliable) Magitech fuel (emerging industry) Black market applications (various) The Economy of Death Pattern Residue creates incentives: Peace is expensive (low Residue production) War is profitable (high production, controllable harvest) Disaster is opportunity (mass death = market surplus) Certain populations are more valuable dead than alive (high-pattern individuals) The institutions that depend on Residue have interests in: Maintaining death rates Controlling Residue sources Preventing peace from becoming too stable Managing scarcity to maintain prices This is not conspiracy theory. This is economics. The people who run these systems are not monsters. They're administrators responding to incentives. The monstrousness is structural. The Net-Negative Reality Pattern Residue doesn't just absorb heat—it permanently removes it. Every death: Absorbs thermal energy during Residue formation Even when burned, releases only 60-70% of that energy The remainder is lost forever (exotic matter decay, Elsewhere transfer) This means: The Loom's fuel supply comes at planetary cost Running the system requires accepting ongoing heat loss The more queries, the more death needed, the colder the world becomes The original builders either didn't know this, didn't care, or had a reason Regional Distribution The Loom is not uniform across Hálcova. Different regions have different relationships with the system. Core Regions (High Integration) Dense Node coverage High Registry completeness Strong Orthodoxy presence Loom-based governance dominant These regions trust The Loom because The Loom serves their interests. The pattern-privileged are concentrated here. The predictions validate their power. Peripheral Regions (Moderate Integration) Sparse Node coverage Incomplete registries Mixed religious presence Loom as one factor among many These regions use The Loom pragmatically. It's a tool, not a religion. Local knowledge competes with Loom-predictions. Deviation is more common and less prosecuted. Frontier Regions (Low Integration) Minimal Node presence (mobile units only) Highly incomplete registries Heterodox or non-Loom religions dominant Loom as foreign imposition These regions resist The Loom for practical and cultural reasons. Being un-registered is common. Pattern-reading is viewed with suspicion. Local systems of fate-understanding compete or dominate. Contested Regions (Variable) Integration depends on current power structure Registries may be destroyed, rebuilt, falsified Religious authority in flux Loom as political battleground In these regions, controlling The Loom is controlling the population. Registration drives are military operations. Pattern data is intelligence. The Loom is a weapon. Attitudes Toward The Loom Universal Acceptance of Accuracy Across Hálcova, virtually no one disputes that The Loom's predictions are accurate. The evidence is too overwhelming. Even those who hate the system acknowledge that it works. Disagreement is about: Why it works Whether accuracy justifies the system Who should control it What deviations mean Cultural Variations The Faithful : The Loom reveals divine will. Acceptance is worship. Deviation is sin. The system is sacred. The Pragmatists : The Loom is accurate and useful. Don't ask why. Use the predictions, manage the risks, don't overthink. The Reformers : The Loom is accurate but misused. The problem isn't prediction—it's discrimination based on prediction. Fix the institutions, not the math. The Skeptics : The Loom is accurate because it creates what it predicts. It's self-fulfilling prophecy dressed as divination. The system makes itself true. The Conspiracists : The Loom is accurate because something is making it true. We're not being predicted—we're being controlled. The system is a cage. None of these positions deny accuracy. They interpret it differently. Terminology Reference Term Meaning The Loom The complete system of fate-prediction and pattern-tracking Loom-Node Physical installation housing pattern-engines and archives Pattern-Engine Device that records, calculates, and interfaces with the source Loom-Keeper Licensed operator of Loom systems High Weaver Senior Loom-Keeper rank The Registry Database of all recorded Sórscad patterns The Weaver Orthodox name for the divine source of patterns Pattern Residue Energy released by pattern-dissolution; fuel for the system Deviation When outcomes diverge from predictions The Attendance Loom-Keeper term for whatever answers their rituals Further documentation needed on: Pattern-engine construction, Loom-Keeper training, Registry security protocols, Node-to-Node communication, The Attendance's behavior patterns
