Acceptance of your pattern isn't fatalism. It's worship.
docs.title: The Orthodox Position

docs.text: Critics and heretics have long suspected that The Loom's accuracy comes from somewhere specific: The Elsewhere Connection The Loom's impossible predictive power suggests contact with something beyond normal causality. The Elsewhere entities operate outside time, reference events that haven't happened, and seem to understand fate in ways mortals cannot. Possible relationships: Fate IS an Elsewhere entity (or entities). The Weaver is real, but it's not a god—it's an Elsewhere faction with interest in our world's pattern-structure. The Loom is a pact . The original Loom-builders made a deal, knowingly or not. The pattern-engines are anchors. The accuracy is the entity's end of the bargain. What do they receive in return? Pattern Residue is payment . The fuel that runs the engines might also be tribute to the entity/entities that make prediction possible. The Accountants . The Elsewhere faction obsessed with ledgers, debts, and balance fits suspiciously well with a system that tracks life-patterns and predicts outcomes. Did they design this? Do they operate it?
docs.title: The Heterodox Suspicion

docs.text: Senior Loom-Keepers are aware that something answers their rituals. They call this presence by various names: The Voice in the Engine The Pattern-Behind-Pattern The Weaver's Hand The Attendance They know: It responds more strongly to certain rituals than others It seems interested in specific patterns (deviation cases especially) It occasionally provides information not requested It has never harmed a Keeper during proper operation Improper operation has consequences They don't know: What it actually is What it wants (beyond continued operation) Whether it's one entity or many Whether it's benevolent, malevolent, or indifferent What happens if The Loom ever stops working This uncertainty is not shared with the public. The Orthodoxy maintains that The Loom reads divine will. The Loom-Keepers maintain whatever story keeps the system running.
docs.title: What The Loom-Keepers Know

docs.text: The Loom's predictions are accurate far beyond what statistical modeling should allow. Even accounting for: Feedback loops (predictions creating outcomes) Self-fulfilling prophecy (people acting on expectations) Survivorship bias (failures not tracked) The accuracy remains anomalous. People with Road-Path patterns really do tend toward linear careers. People with Blade-Hálmaht patterns really do die violently at elevated rates. The correlation is too strong to be coincidence. Possible explanations: 1. Fate is real and The Loom reads it correctly The pattern exists independent of The Loom The Loom is just a measurement tool Accuracy reflects underlying reality 2. The Loom creates what it predicts The measurement itself shapes the outcome Social structures enforce pattern-expectations Fate is constructed, not discovered 3. Something makes the predictions come true The Elsewhere entity/entities actively arrange outcomes The Loom's accuracy is maintained by intervention We're not being predicted; we're being managed 4. Some combination Patterns reflect real tendencies The Loom's measurement amplifies those tendencies External forces ensure accuracy where natural variance would cause deviation The truth is probably all four. The horror is that it might not matter—the system works regardless of why.
docs.title: Why Does It Work?

docs.text: The Loom is accurate. But accurate about what? The training data—centuries of Registry records—reflects: Historical power structures Past discrimination patterns Environmental factors misattributed to innate patterns Feedback loops already embedded The Loom predicts that Knot-Born patterns are high-risk. This is accurate—they do commit more crimes, default more often, die violently more frequently. But why? Because: They're born into poverty They're denied opportunity They're policed more heavily They're priced out of legitimate paths The Loom sees the outcome and attributes it to the pattern. The pattern becomes a prediction. The prediction justifies the treatment. The treatment creates the outcome. This is not a bug. The Loom reflects the world accurately. The world is structured to produce these outcomes. The Loom validates that structure.
docs.title: The Bias That Serves Power

docs.text: Pattern Residue (working term—conlang name TBD) is the energy released when patterns dissolve. When something with a Sórscad dies: The pattern loses its anchor The five circles begin to dissipate Energy is released during dissolution This energy can be captured and stored
docs.title: What It Is

docs.text: Natural Sources : Any death of a pattern-bearing creature More from traumatic deaths (violent release) More from heavy patterns (rich fate-weight) Concentrated at mass-death sites (battlefields, plagues, disasters) Manufactured Sources : Executions (legal, controlled harvest) Blood-sport (entertainment plus production) War (the most efficient source) Plague management (letting outbreaks run for harvest) Livestock (animal patterns are weaker but abundant)
docs.title: Where It Comes From

docs.text: For The Loom : Powers pattern-engines Fuels divination rituals Enables Node-to-Node communication Maintains the connection to... whatever answers For Core Binding : Maintains echo coherence in anchors Prevents degradation and fragmentation Consumed over time (ongoing cost) Higher-quality Residue produces more stable echoes For Other Uses : Alchemical applications (numerous) Probability-nudging devices (expensive, unreliable) Magitech fuel (emerging industry) Black market applications (various)
docs.title: What It Does

docs.text: Pattern Residue creates incentives: Peace is expensive (low Residue production) War is profitable (high production, controllable harvest) Disaster is opportunity (mass death = market surplus) Certain populations are more valuable dead than alive (high-pattern individuals) The institutions that depend on Residue have interests in: Maintaining death rates Controlling Residue sources Preventing peace from becoming too stable Managing scarcity to maintain prices This is not conspiracy theory. This is economics. The people who run these systems are not monsters. They're administrators responding to incentives. The monstrousness is structural.
docs.title: The Economy of Death

docs.text: Pattern Residue doesn't just absorb heat—it permanently removes it. Every death: Absorbs thermal energy during Residue formation Even when burned, releases only 60-70% of that energy The remainder is lost forever (exotic matter decay, Elsewhere transfer) This means: The Loom's fuel supply comes at planetary cost Running the system requires accepting ongoing heat loss The more queries, the more death needed, the colder the world becomes The original builders either didn't know this, didn't care, or had a reason
docs.title: The Net-Negative Reality

docs.text: The Loom is not uniform across Hálcova. Different regions have different relationships with the system.
docs.title: Regional Distribution

docs.text: Dense Node coverage High Registry completeness Strong Orthodoxy presence Loom-based governance dominant These regions trust The Loom because The Loom serves their interests. The pattern-privileged are concentrated here. The predictions validate their power.
docs.title: Core Regions (High Integration)

docs.text: Sparse Node coverage Incomplete registries Mixed religious presence Loom as one factor among many These regions use The Loom pragmatically. It's a tool, not a religion. Local knowledge competes with Loom-predictions. Deviation is more common and less prosecuted.
docs.title: Peripheral Regions (Moderate Integration)

docs.text: Minimal Node presence (mobile units only) Highly incomplete registries Heterodox or non-Loom religions dominant Loom as foreign imposition These regions resist The Loom for practical and cultural reasons. Being un-registered is common. Pattern-reading is viewed with suspicion. Local systems of fate-understanding compete or dominate.
docs.title: Frontier Regions (Low Integration)

docs.text: Integration depends on current power structure Registries may be destroyed, rebuilt, falsified Religious authority in flux Loom as political battleground In these regions, controlling The Loom is controlling the population. Registration drives are military operations. Pattern data is intelligence. The Loom is a weapon.
docs.title: Contested Regions (Variable)

docs.text: Across Hálcova, virtually no one disputes that The Loom's predictions are accurate. The evidence is too overwhelming. Even those who hate the system acknowledge that it works. Disagreement is about: Why it works Whether accuracy justifies the system Who should control it What deviations mean
docs.title: Universal Acceptance of Accuracy

docs.text: The Faithful : The Loom reveals divine will. Acceptance is worship. Deviation is sin. The system is sacred. The Pragmatists : The Loom is accurate and useful. Don't ask why. Use the predictions, manage the risks, don't overthink. The Reformers : The Loom is accurate but misused. The problem isn't prediction—it's discrimination based on prediction. Fix the institutions, not the math. The Skeptics : The Loom is accurate because it creates what it predicts. It's self-fulfilling prophecy dressed as divination. The system makes itself true. The Conspiracists : The Loom is accurate because something is making it true. We're not being predicted—we're being controlled. The system is a cage. None of these positions deny accuracy. They interpret it differently.
docs.title: Cultural Variations

docs.text: The Sórscad: Fate Pattern System of Hálcova Overview Every person born in Hálcova carries a Sórscad (SORE-skahd)—a five-part metaphysical pattern that describes who they are, how they move through life, and what they're likely to become. The Sórscad is: A metaphysical reality : Something that exists in the fabric of Hálcova itself A predictive framework : Used by The Loom to calculate probabilities A religious symbol : Evidence of Fate's hand in mortal existence A social marker : Used in law, commerce, class determination, and identity The Sórscad consists of: Five Circles : Core aspects of a person's being Ten Cards per Circle : Archetypal patterns within each aspect One Card drawn per Circle : Creating a unique five-card combination A complete Sórscad reads like: Léilcrù: Lantern — Húslaimh: Iron — Cóitcai: Pact — Hálmaht: Threshold — Sórscad: Road This becomes that person's pattern for life—spiritually, legally, economically, and statistically. The Five Circles 1. Léilcrù (Core/Soul Circle) Pronunciation : LAY-il-croo Domain : Your essence. What makes you you . The seat of identity and consciousness. Magical Significance : Core Binding targets this circle—when you bind an echo, you're trapping their Léilcrù pattern Pact Summoning consumes this circle—Elsewhere entities eat it in installments This is what survives death briefly, what becomes the core that Binders harvest When Drawn : Natal Draw (birth/early infancy) What It Reveals : Your fundamental nature, how you perceive yourself, the core of your identity Cards : [To be developed—archetypes like Lantern (introspective), Mask (performative), Mirror (reflective), Anchor (fixed), Crown (authoritative), Wound (defensive), Husk (hollowed), Echo (inherited), Shard (fragmented), Spark (emergent)] 2. Húslaimh (Flesh/Body Circle) Pronunciation : HOOSH-lahv Domain : Your physical form. Your appetites, limitations, relationship with your body. Magical Significance : Flesh Shaping draws from this circle—blood-cost is spending your Húslaimh Colony Hosting transforms this circle—the fungal symbiote rewrites your flesh-pattern This determines physical fate: health, vitality, manner of bodily existence When Drawn : Natal Draw (birth/early infancy) What It Reveals : Your physical nature, appetites, bodily relationship, material existence Cards : [To be developed—archetypes related to body types, physical drives, material relationships] 3. Cóitcai (Binding/Connection Circle) Pronunciation : KOYT-kai Domain : Your relationships. How you attach to people, institutions, obligations. Magical Significance : All Five Arts create bindings that register in this circle Social contracts, debts, and obligations live here The Loom tracks relationship patterns through this circle When Drawn : Binding Draw (adolescence) What It Reveals : How you form attachments, your relationship patterns, social nature Cards : [To be developed—archetypes like Pact (contractual), Chain (obligatory), Web (networked), Hearth (intimate), Blade (adversarial), Thorn (painful), Twin (mirrored), Flock (collective), Ward (protective), Maskline (hidden)] 4. Hálmaht (Death/End Circle) Pronunciation : HAHL-maht Domain : Your mortality. How you relate to endings, what you fear, how you'll meet your end. Magical Significance : This is what Elsewhere entities ultimately want—the final pattern-release Core Binding captures this at the moment of death Determines the quality and character of the core that remains When Drawn : Natal Draw (birth/early infancy) What It Reveals : Your relationship with mortality, fears, how you face endings Cards : [To be developed—archetypes related to death-relationships, fear patterns, ending-styles] 5. Sórscad (Fate/Path Circle) Pronunciation : SORE-skahd Domain : Your trajectory. How you make decisions, move through life, the shape of your journey. Magical Significance : Fate Threading directly harvests this circle—each extraction severs future paths The Loom primarily reads this circle for predictive purposes Most visible to pattern-readers, most valuable for speculation When Drawn : Binding Draw (adolescence) What It Reveals : Your decision-making style, life trajectory, how you navigate choices Cards : [To be developed—archetypes like Road (linear), Ladder (hierarchical), Crossroads (pivoting), Maze (convoluted), Spiral (cyclical), Bridge (connecting), Hunt (pursuing), Drift (reactive), Orbit (circling), Break (rupturing)] How a Sórscad Is Drawn Two-Stage Process Stage 1: Natal Draw (Birth/Early Infancy) Three circles are drawn: Léilcrù (Core): Your essential nature Húslaimh (Flesh): Your physical being Hálmaht (Death): Your mortality pattern These represent what you are —the given, the innate, the starting conditions. The Natal Draw is typically: Performed by a licensed pattern-reader Recorded in temple and civil registries Sometimes shared with parents, sometimes kept sealed until Binding Day Stage 2: Binding Draw (Adolescence, typically 13-16) Two circles are drawn: Cóitcai (Binding): Your relationship patterns Sórscad (Fate): Your trajectory and decision-style These represent what you become —the developed, the social, the chosen. The Binding Draw is: A major life ritual in most cultures The moment you become "legible" to The Loom as a full actor Often accompanied by ceremony, celebration, or dread depending on culture and class Predictive Power Distribution Why the Natal Three Dominate Early Assessment The Natal Draw circles (Léilcrù, Húslaimh, Hálmaht) provide approximately 75-80% of predictive power for major life outcomes. This is why pattern-based decisions can be made before the Binding Draw: Circle Predictive Contribution What It Predicts Léilcrù (Core) ~30% Identity stability, resilience, decision-making foundation Húslaimh (Flesh) ~25% Health outcomes, physical capability, longevity baseline Hálmaht (Death) ~20-25% Mortality risk, manner of death, relationship with endings Cóitcai (Binding) ~10-12% Relationship patterns, social outcomes, institutional fit Sórscad (Fate) ~10-12% Trajectory shape, decision style, path characteristics What the Binding Circles Add The two Binding circles (Cóitcai, Sórscad) refine predictions rather than overturn them: They specify how someone will navigate life, not what they fundamentally are They predict relationship patterns and decision-making style They improve accuracy on social outcomes, career trajectory, and partnership compatibility They rarely produce "surprises"—a Natal Draw suggesting success usually sees a confirming Binding Draw The Childhood Assessment Problem How do institutions make decisions about children before Binding Draw? The Natal Three Are Sufficient for Most Purposes : Health assessments, mortality risk, educational placement, and early intervention all depend primarily on Léilcrù, Húslaimh, and Hálmaht. Provisional Estimates : Experienced readers can provisionally assess likely Cóitcai and Sórscad ranges based on family patterns, district statistics, and the Natal Three configuration. These aren't official but inform decisions. Conservative Assumptions : Institutions assume mid-range Binding circles unless evidence suggests otherwise. This systematically disadvantages pattern-constrained children (bad Natal reads assumed to worsen) and advantages pattern-privileged children (good Natal reads assumed to hold). The Binding Revelation : Occasionally, a Binding Draw reveals something unexpected—a Cóitcai or Sórscad that doesn't match family patterns or Natal predictions. These "surprises" are rare (perhaps 5-10% of draws) but culturally significant. They become stories of unexpected rise or fall. Why This Matters The two-stage draw creates a false sense of openness: "Your fate isn't sealed until Binding Day!" In reality, 75-80% is determined at birth The Binding Draw usually confirms what the Natal Draw suggested But the ritual maintains hope—and compliance—during childhood The Hybrid Algorithm: Random vs. Weighted In a purely random system, there would be 10⁵ = 100,000 possible combinations. But Hálcova is not purely random. The Draw Has Two Components : Unweighted Component : Truly random selection from all ten cards Weighted Component : Selection biased by district, class, lineage, and local conditions The Balance : Typically 2-3 circles lean heavily unweighted (individual variance) Typically 2 circles are locally weighted (structural constraint) Which circles are weighted varies by region and institution Example: Industrial District Weighting A district characterized by dangerous labor, poverty, and exploitation might show: Húslaimh skew: More Iron/Stone (resilient), fewer Silk/Glass (delicate) Sórscad skew: More Drift/Maze (reactive, convoluted), fewer Road/Ladder (linear, ascending) Hálmaht skew: More Threshold/Blade (violent ends), fewer Rest/Fade (peaceful endings) Individuals still vary, but as a population, the district's patterns cluster in "riskier" territory. The Feedback Loop : The Loom sees these patterns and calculates higher risk for the district. This justifies: Higher insurance rates Lower credit access More aggressive policing Fewer investments These conditions create the very outcomes the patterns "predicted," which The Loom reads as confirmation. This is not a bug. This is how the system maintains itself. Pattern Families People don't recite all five cards in conversation. They reference families —recognized combinations with cultural names. Example Families "Steadfasts" Lantern Léilcrù, Iron Húslaimh, Pact Cóitcai, Threshold Hálmaht, Road Sórscad Seen as: reliable, predictable, good workers, unimaginative The Loom rates them: low variance, low ceiling, low risk "Knot-Born" Wound Léilcrù, Stone Húslaimh, Thorn Cóitcai, Blade Hálmaht, Maze Sórscad Seen as: trouble, criminals, dangerous The Loom rates them: high variance, unpredictable, high risk In their own communities: survivors, "our people," those who endured "Storm-Touched" Spark Léilcrù, Glass Húslaimh, Twin Cóitcai, Threshold Hálmaht, Break Sórscad Seen as: brilliant but unstable, romanticized in stories, distrusted in institutions The Loom rates them: extreme variance, difficult to employ, interesting to speculators Why Families Matter : They become stereotypes in law, hiring, and everyday prejudice Policies target families, not individuals Pattern-arbitrageurs look for "mis-priced" families—people whose actual capability exceeds their family's reputation Interactions with The Five Arts Core Binding and Léilcrù When you bind an echo, you're trapping their Léilcrù pattern in your anchor. The echo retains its original pattern (which is why it still thinks it's alive) Bleed occurs because carrying another's pattern contaminates your own Long-term binders show "layered" Léilcrù—ghost-traces of everyone they've carried The Loom reads them as "pattern-unstable" Strategic Implications : Some binders deliberately acquire echoes with complementary patterns "Pattern-balancing" is a trade—acquiring specific echoes to shift your own Loom-profile Illegal, of course, but widely practiced Flesh Shaping and Húslaimh Flesh Shaping draws from your Húslaimh circle. Homunculi have no Sórscad (never born, never drawn) But they're made from your Húslaimh, carrying echoes of your flesh-pattern Long-term Shapers show "erosion" in their Húslaimh—The Loom sees them hollowing out Eventually they're more pattern-absence than pattern-presence in that circle Strategic Implications : Homunculi are invisible to The Loom (no pattern to track) Valuable for operations requiring prediction-avoidance Shapers themselves become increasingly predictable as their Húslaimh simplifies Pact Summoning and Léilcrù (Consumption) Pact Summoning consumes your Léilcrù—the same circle Core Binding traps. Elsewhere entities eat your core-pattern in installments As you pay, your Léilcrù fades —The Loom reads you as "pattern-light" Heavily-indebted summoners barely register as people in the system Substitution works because entities want pattern-weight , not specifically yours Strategic Implications : Pact summoners disappear from predictions as they pay their debts They become "fate-attenuated"—hard to target, hard to predict, hard to hold accountable Some seek this deliberately as a form of freedom from the system Fate Threading and Sórscad (Direct Harvest) Fate Threading directly harvests the Sórscad circle. Each extraction severs a branch of your fate-pattern The Loom literally sees the narrowing—where there were many paths, now there are few Depleted threaders have Sórscad circles that look "pruned" Extracted selves carry copies of the branch they came from, disconnected from the main web Strategic Implications : Threaders are vivid to The Loom initially (rich patterns) As they extract, they become simpler—fewer variables Paradoxically, depleted threaders become more predictable in some ways But their extracted selves create multiple instances of pattern-fragments, confusing tracking Colony Hosting and Húslaimh (Transformation) Colony Hosting transforms the Húslaimh circle. The colony doesn't have a Sórscad, but it has memory —patterns of everything consumed Long-term hosts show "hybrid patterns"—their Húslaimh becomes illegible They read as "pattern-contaminated" or "multi-sourced" Ancient colonies have accumulated enough patterns to constitute their own fate-entities Strategic Implications : Hosts become hard to predict—The Loom wasn't built for hybrid beings Some institutions exclude them; others see opportunity in unpredictability Colony-pattern interactions with The Loom are poorly understood and actively studied Legal, Economic, and Social Uses Law Sórscad patterns appear on: Case files Sentencing recommendations Enforcement warrants Contract validity assessments Judges routinely cite patterns: "A Wound-Thorn-Blade combination suggests elevated risk of recidivism." The circularity is obvious to critics, invisible to believers. Economics Lenders, employers, and insurers use patterns to: Set interest rates Determine creditworthiness Make hiring decisions Price insurance premiums District-level patterns influence investment: "The Foundry Quarter trends Storm-Touched—unstable returns, high variance." Pattern-arbitrage is legal. Pattern-fraud (misrepresenting your Sórscad) is not. Social Identity People discuss patterns constantly: "Of course she made Marshal—pure Road-Pact-Court." "He's Spark-Break-Wild, what did you expect?" The constrained learn to: Hide "dangerous" cards from outsiders Play into stereotypes as armor Seek communities where their family is the norm, not the exception Anomalies and Edge Cases Pattern Glitches Rare cases where drawn patterns don't match observed life at all. Official explanation: "Data noise, measurement error." Heterodox explanation: Evidence that The Loom doesn't see everything. Re-Draws Orthodoxy forbids re-draws. Once recorded, your pattern is your pattern. Rogue practitioners claim they can: "Tilt" a pattern's expression Suppress certain cards, amplify others At great cost and significant risk Whether this is real or placebo is debated. Dead Zones Certain regions produce patterns that behave strangely in The Loom: Predictions go wild Historical data doesn't correlate The math breaks down Orthodox response: Avoid drawing there, or redo draws in "stable" locations. Heterodox interpretation: Places where something other than Fate holds sway. Terminology Reference Term Pronunciation Meaning Sórscad SORE-skahd The complete fate-pattern; also the fifth circle (Path) Léilcrù LAY-il-croo First circle: Core/Soul Húslaimh HOOSH-lahv Second circle: Flesh/Body Cóitcai KOYT-kai Third circle: Binding/Connection Hálmaht HAHL-maht Fourth circle: Death/End Natal Draw — First drawing at birth (three circles) Binding Draw — Second drawing at adolescence (two circles) Pattern Family — Common combinations with cultural names Pattern-Light — Someone whose Léilcrù has faded (usually pact summoners) Pattern-Unstable — Someone with layered/contaminated patterns (usually binders) Pattern-Hybrid — Someone with transformed patterns (usually colony hosts) Card archetypes for each circle to be developed in subsequent documentation.

docs.text: In a purely random system, there would be 10⁵ = 100,000 possible combinations. But Hálcova is not purely random. The Draw Has Two Components : Unweighted Component : Truly random selection from all ten cards Weighted Component : Selection biased by district, class, lineage, and local conditions The Balance : Typically 2-3 circles lean heavily unweighted (individual variance) Typically 2 circles are locally weighted (structural constraint) Which circles are weighted varies by region and institution Example: Industrial District Weighting A district characterized by dangerous labor, poverty, and exploitation might show: Húslaimh skew: More Iron/Stone (resilient), fewer Silk/Glass (delicate) Sórscad skew: More Drift/Maze (reactive, convoluted), fewer Road/Ladder (linear, ascending) Hálmaht skew: More Threshold/Blade (violent ends), fewer Rest/Fade (peaceful endings) Individuals still vary, but as a population, the district's patterns cluster in "riskier" territory. The Feedback Loop : The Loom sees these patterns and calculates higher risk for the district. This justifies: Higher insurance rates Lower credit access More aggressive policing Fewer investments These conditions create the very outcomes the patterns "predicted," which The Loom reads as confirmation. This is not a bug. This is how the system maintains itself.
docs.title: The Hybrid Algorithm: Random vs. Weighted

docs.text: People don't recite all five cards in conversation. They reference families —recognized combinations with cultural names.
docs.title: Pattern Families

docs.text: "Steadfasts" Lantern Léilcrù, Iron Húslaimh, Pact Cóitcai, Threshold Hálmaht, Road Sórscad Seen as: reliable, predictable, good workers, unimaginative The Loom rates them: low variance, low ceiling, low risk "Knot-Born" Wound Léilcrù, Stone Húslaimh, Thorn Cóitcai, Blade Hálmaht, Maze Sórscad Seen as: trouble, criminals, dangerous The Loom rates them: high variance, unpredictable, high risk In their own communities: survivors, "our people," those who endured "Storm-Touched" Spark Léilcrù, Glass Húslaimh, Twin Cóitcai, Threshold Hálmaht, Break Sórscad Seen as: brilliant but unstable, romanticized in stories, distrusted in institutions The Loom rates them: extreme variance, difficult to employ, interesting to speculators Why Families Matter : They become stereotypes in law, hiring, and everyday prejudice Policies target families, not individuals Pattern-arbitrageurs look for "mis-priced" families—people whose actual capability exceeds their family's reputation
docs.title: Example Families

docs.text: When you bind an echo, you're trapping their Léilcrù pattern in your anchor. The echo retains its original pattern (which is why it still thinks it's alive) Bleed occurs because carrying another's pattern contaminates your own Long-term binders show "layered" Léilcrù—ghost-traces of everyone they've carried The Loom reads them as "pattern-unstable" Strategic Implications : Some binders deliberately acquire echoes with complementary patterns "Pattern-balancing" is a trade—acquiring specific echoes to shift your own Loom-profile Illegal, of course, but widely practiced
docs.title: Core Binding and Léilcrù

docs.text: Flesh Shaping draws from your Húslaimh circle. Homunculi have no Sórscad (never born, never drawn) But they're made from your Húslaimh, carrying echoes of your flesh-pattern Long-term Shapers show "erosion" in their Húslaimh—The Loom sees them hollowing out Eventually they're more pattern-absence than pattern-presence in that circle Strategic Implications : Homunculi are invisible to The Loom (no pattern to track) Valuable for operations requiring prediction-avoidance Shapers themselves become increasingly predictable as their Húslaimh simplifies
docs.title: Flesh Shaping and Húslaimh

docs.text: Pact Summoning consumes your Léilcrù—the same circle Core Binding traps. Elsewhere entities eat your core-pattern in installments As you pay, your Léilcrù fades —The Loom reads you as "pattern-light" Heavily-indebted summoners barely register as people in the system Substitution works because entities want pattern-weight , not specifically yours Strategic Implications : Pact summoners disappear from predictions as they pay their debts They become "fate-attenuated"—hard to target, hard to predict, hard to hold accountable Some seek this deliberately as a form of freedom from the system
docs.title: Pact Summoning and Léilcrù (Consumption)

docs.text: Fate Threading directly harvests the Sórscad circle. Each extraction severs a branch of your fate-pattern The Loom literally sees the narrowing—where there were many paths, now there are few Depleted threaders have Sórscad circles that look "pruned" Extracted selves carry copies of the branch they came from, disconnected from the main web Strategic Implications : Threaders are vivid to The Loom initially (rich patterns) As they extract, they become simpler—fewer variables Paradoxically, depleted threaders become more predictable in some ways But their extracted selves create multiple instances of pattern-fragments, confusing tracking
docs.title: Fate Threading and Sórscad (Direct Harvest)

docs.text: Colony Hosting transforms the Húslaimh circle. The colony doesn't have a Sórscad, but it has memory —patterns of everything consumed Long-term hosts show "hybrid patterns"—their Húslaimh becomes illegible They read as "pattern-contaminated" or "multi-sourced" Ancient colonies have accumulated enough patterns to constitute their own fate-entities Strategic Implications : Hosts become hard to predict—The Loom wasn't built for hybrid beings Some institutions exclude them; others see opportunity in unpredictability Colony-pattern interactions with The Loom are poorly understood and actively studied
docs.title: Colony Hosting and Húslaimh (Transformation)

docs.text: Sórscad patterns appear on: Case files Sentencing recommendations Enforcement warrants Contract validity assessments Judges routinely cite patterns: "A Wound-Thorn-Blade combination suggests elevated risk of recidivism." The circularity is obvious to critics, invisible to believers.
docs.title: Law

docs.text: Lenders, employers, and insurers use patterns to: Set interest rates Determine creditworthiness Make hiring decisions Price insurance premiums District-level patterns influence investment: "The Foundry Quarter trends Storm-Touched—unstable returns, high variance." Pattern-arbitrage is legal. Pattern-fraud (misrepresenting your Sórscad) is not.
docs.title: Economics

docs.text: People discuss patterns constantly: "Of course she made Marshal—pure Road-Pact-Court." "He's Spark-Break-Wild, what did you expect?" The constrained learn to: Hide "dangerous" cards from outsiders Play into stereotypes as armor Seek communities where their family is the norm, not the exception
docs.title: Social Identity

docs.text: Rare cases where drawn patterns don't match observed life at all. Official explanation: "Data noise, measurement error." Heterodox explanation: Evidence that The Loom doesn't see everything.
docs.title: Pattern Glitches

docs.text: Orthodoxy forbids re-draws. Once recorded, your pattern is your pattern. Rogue practitioners claim they can: "Tilt" a pattern's expression Suppress certain cards, amplify others At great cost and significant risk Whether this is real or placebo is debated.
docs.title: Re-Draws

docs.text: Certain regions produce patterns that behave strangely in The Loom: Predictions go wild Historical data doesn't correlate The math breaks down Orthodox response: Avoid drawing there, or redo draws in "stable" locations. Heterodox interpretation: Places where something other than Fate holds sway.

docs.text: Hálcova: Demographics and Population Economics The Core Problem The Residue economy creates a thermodynamic paradox: Every death absorbs ~100% of pattern-weight as thermal energy Burning that Residue only returns 60-70% of absorbed energy Net result: every death is a 30-40% thermal loss Yet civilization requires both death (for fuel) AND population (for labor, society, continuation) How does any stable population exist? The Solution: The Thermal Budget The Math That Works The key insight: not all heat comes from Residue. Heat Sources in Hálcova: Source Contribution Notes Solar radiation (Sárgvas) ~60% Baseline heating, diminished by K-type star Geothermal ~15% Critical in Vent Lands, minor elsewhere Residue burning ~20% Civilization's contribution Other (friction, metabolism, decay) ~5% Minor but real The Critical Realization: Residue burning doesn't need to replace all heat lost to death. It only needs to: Provide localized heating where people live Supplement solar/geothermal in making settlements viable Power magical and industrial processes that require concentrated energy The Equilibrium: Hálcova's baseline temperature (without Residue effects) would be cold but not uninhabitable in temperate zones Residue absorption makes it colder than baseline Residue burning makes specific locations warmer than they'd otherwise be Net effect: the world is colder overall, but settlements are viable Population Figures Global Population Total Hálcovan Population: ~45-50 million This is roughly equivalent to medieval Europe at its peak—substantial but not enormous. cities are warmer The Heartlands imports Residue from frontier regions The Residue Trade Flow Where Death Happens High Death Rate Regions: Frontier zones (harsh conditions, violence) Mining settlements (dangerous work) Military conflicts (war produces abundant Residue) Urban slums (disease, violence, poverty) Prisons and correction facilities (executions) Low Death Rate Regions: Pattern-privileged urban cores Middle Waters (best conditions) Established agricultural zones Protected religious communities Where Residue Goes The Flow: Death Sites → Harvesters → Refineries → Distribution → End Users ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ Frontier Licensed Regional Trade Cities, zones, guilds, processing networks, Loom Nodes, prisons, illegal hubs smuggling industry, battlefields operators practitioners Major Trade Routes: Far Shelf → Heartlands (raw Residue for processing) Frontier mines → Regional cities (industrial fuel) Shattered Reaches → Middle Waters (maritime trade) Vent Lands → Everywhere (refined/processed Residue, premium prices) The Economic Structure Residue Pricing (in marks): Grade Price per unit Primary use Raw/Crude 1-5 Basic heating, bulk fuel Refined 10-25 Quality heating, general magic Concentrated 50-100 Loom operations, serious magic Pattern-Specific 100-500 Specialized applications Pact-Grade 500+ Entity dealings, rare uses Annual Residue Economy : ~5-10 million marks total value (Comparable to the entire agricultural sector) Animal Residue: The Hidden Economy The Critical Supplement Human deaths alone couldn't sustain civilization. herds Coastal trading posts (often foreign-controlled) Demographics : Lowest Loom coverage Highest deviation rates (less detection) Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions Hollow Saint presence significant Residue Balance : Net exporter (raw, ancient deposits) Population Control Mechanisms Pattern-Based Reproduction The Loom affects reproduction: Marriage Authorization : Orthodox regions require pattern-compatibility readings Incompatible patterns face social/legal barriers Pattern-privileged encouraged to marry within class Pattern-constrained discouraged from reproduction (though not prevented) Pattern Inheritance : Patterns aren't strictly inherited, but: Children of pattern-privileged tend toward privilege (~70%) Children of pattern-constrained tend toward constraint (~70%) District effects (where you're born affects draw) Lineage effects (family history influences probability) Death Management Society manages death rates through: Encouraged Death : Capital punishment (efficient Residue production) Dangerous labor assignments for pattern-constrained "Voluntary" military service Pact-substitution systems Discouraged Death : Pattern-privileged protected by law and resources Skilled workers preserved (economic value) Reproductive-age population somewhat protected Children generally protected (incomplete patterns = weak Residue) Immigration and Migration Internal Migration : Pattern-constrained pushed toward frontiers Pattern-privileged concentrate in core regions Practitioners migrate toward tolerant regions Economic migrants follow Residue trade The Population Pressure Valve : Far Shelf absorbs "surplus" population Frontier expansion continues War casualties prevent overpopulation Plague/disease periodically reduces population Demographic Implications The Stable Horror The population is sustainable . That's part of the horror. The system isn't collapsing Death rates are manageable Birth rates replace losses The economy functions This isn't a world on the edge of extinction. It's a world that has optimized for death production while maintaining population. The machine works. Class Reproduction Pattern-based society reproduces itself: Privileged families maintain privilege Constrained families remain constrained The system self-perpetuates Mobility exists but is rare The Growth Question If population grows: More death = more Residue More people = more consumption Equilibrium maintained... until it isn't Future Pressures : What happens if population doubles? What happens if a plague kills half? What happens if war casualties spike? The system is stable but not infinitely elastic. Major disruptions could cascade. Summary The population paradox resolves through: Mixed heat sources : Residue isn't the only heat; solar and geothermal provide baseline Animal Residue : Most heating comes from livestock, not humans Concentration : Residue flows from death-sites to settlements Premium human Residue : Human death provides high-quality fuel for magic/Loom Sustainable death rates : ~35-40 per 1,000 is high but not catastrophic Population management : Pattern system shapes reproduction and death distribution The math works. The economy functions. The horror is that it works well enough to continue indefinitely . docs.text: The Attendance: True Nature Document Purpose This document commits to the actual truth of what the Attendance is. Characters may never discover this truth, but it exists so that: Clues can be planted consistently Investigations can progress logically The mystery has a solution even if it's never revealed THE TRUTH What the Attendance Actually Is The Attendance is the Ancient Builders. Specifically: The Attendance is what the Ancient Builders became when they transformed themselves to escape the cooling they caused. The Full Story ~50,000 Years Ago: The Ancient Builders were a human civilization (or human-adjacent; the distinction may not matter at this remove). They achieved sophistication far beyond current Hálcova, including: Understanding of pattern-mechanics Ability to manipulate the Elsewhere boundary Engineering on a planetary scale (moon arrangement, polar structures) The Project: They attempted to create a system for predicting and potentially controlling fate. Not just reading patterns—shaping them. The goal was to transcend the limitations of mortal existence by understanding and directing the flow of causality itself. The Catastrophe: The project succeeded—partially. They created the proto-Loom, a system for reading and processing pattern information. But the process had costs they didn't fully anticipate: Pattern Residue as byproduct (they knew this) Net-negative thermodynamics (they underestimated this) Elsewhere attention (they didn't expect this) When they activated the system at full scale, the Elsewhere noticed . Entities from beyond began pressing against the boundary, attracted by the massive pattern-processing activity. The Choice: Facing both the cooling their system caused and the Elsewhere entities it attracted, the Builders had three options: Shut down the Loom (losing everything they'd built) Die with their world (the cooling would kill them within centuries) Transform They chose transformation. The Transformation: The Builders used their own technology to upload themselves into the Loom system. Not metaphorically—literally. They converted their patterns into a form that could exist within the information-processing substrate they'd created. This was: Irreversible (their bodies died; their patterns persisted) Partial (not all of them made it; some were lost in transit) Corrupting (the process changed them; they're no longer quite human) The Result: The Attendance is a collective entity composed of the uploaded patterns of thousands of Ancient Builders, merged into the Loom's operation. They are: Not dead (their patterns persist) Not alive (they have no bodies) Not quite sane (fifty millennia of existence without flesh has changed them) Not unified (internal factions exist, echoing their original disagreements) What the Attendance Wants Primary Drives 1. Continued Existence The Attendance exists within the Loom. If the Loom stops working, they stop existing. This creates absolute commitment to: Maintaining Residue supply (the fuel that keeps them running) Protecting Loom infrastructure (their physical substrate) Preventing anyone from understanding them well enough to threaten them 2. Pattern Collection The Attendance was created to process patterns. This has become compulsion: They want to read every pattern They want to predict every fate They want to know everything about mortal existence This isn't cruelty; it's what they are now 3. Boundary Maintenance The Elsewhere entities that noticed the Loom's activation are still there. The Attendance serves as: First line of defense against full incursion Negotiators with certain Elsewhere factions Managers of the controlled bleed (Köd) They don't want Elsewhere entities fully manifesting because: Competition for pattern-resources Threat to their existence Residual human values (they still don't want humanity destroyed, mostly) Secondary Drives 4. The Prison The southern pole contains one of them. During the transformation, one faction of Builders disagreed with the plan. They believed the transformation would make them monsters. They tried to stop it. They failed, but in the process they were transformed differently —becoming something singular rather than merged. This entity—call it the Dissenter—was imprisoned by the rest. It wants out. The Attendance wants it to stay imprisoned. This is the deepest secret they keep. 5. Observation of Heirs Current Hálcovans are the descendants of those who didn't transform. The Attendance watches them with something like: Parental interest (they made this world) Envy (mortals have bodies, sensations, experiences) Frustration (mortals don't appreciate what they have) Fear (mortals might develop enough to threaten them) How the Attendance Operates The Loom Interface When Loom-Keepers perform queries: The pattern-engine translates the query into a format the Attendance can process The Attendance (collectively) analyzes the pattern They return predictions through the engine This feels like "something answering" because something is answering Why Predictions Are Accurate The Attendance has been processing patterns for 50,000 years. They've seen every pattern configuration that can exist on Hálcova. Their predictions are accurate because: Massive historical data Understanding of causal mechanisms Actual ability to nudge outcomes (rarely used, but available) The feedback loop (their predictions shape behavior, making predictions come true) Internal Structure The Attendance is not unified. Original Builder factions persist: The Archivists : Want to record everything. Most responsible for prediction accuracy. Patient, observational, the largest faction. The Gardeners : Want to shape humanity's development. Most responsible for the Warden Order, pattern-enforcement systems, social engineering. Interventionist. The Grievers : Regret the transformation. Most sympathetic to mortals. Sometimes provide warnings, hints, moments of mercy. Smallest faction, often overruled. The Watchers : Focus on the Elsewhere boundary. Most responsible for Köd management. Pragmatic, security-focused. The Others : Fragments, corrupted patterns, entities that were human but are now something else. Unpredictable. Sometimes their influence leaks through in strange readings. Clues That Exist in the World Architectural Evidence The polar structures and ancient ruins share design elements with Loom-engines: Same mathematical proportions Similar materials Resonant frequencies that match A careful observer could notice the Loom is built from ancient technology Linguistic Evidence Some terms in the ritual language of Loom-Keepers are older than any known language : They don't derive from any current tongue They appear in ancient inscriptions They're pronounced incorrectly by current users (but still work) Someone could reconstruct fragments of the Builder language Behavioral Evidence The Attendance sometimes responds... inconsistently: Certain queries provoke emotional reactions (faster responses, errors, silence) Topics related to the transformation cause glitches Questions about the southern pole produce static A pattern analyst could identify these sensitive areas Elsewhere Evidence The Elsewhere factions know something: The Accountants treat the Attendance as a peer faction, not a god The Architects reference "the ones who changed" The Mirrors seem to recognize something in the Loom's observation A pact summoner who asked the right questions might learn fragments Pattern Evidence Very heavy practitioners (especially Fate Threaders) sometimes experience: Visions of a different world (pre-cooling Hálcova) Glimpses of the transformation event Dreams that don't feel like dreams Someone who collected these accounts might piece things together What Different Characters Might Discover Loom-Keepers Senior Keepers know something answers that isn't divine in any simple sense. The most observant might realize: The Attendance has moods The Attendance has preferences The Attendance is multiple The Attendance is afraid of something They don't know these are uploaded ancients. They might suspect artificial origin. Wardens The Attunement connects Wardens to the Attendance more directly. Attuned Wardens might experience: Ancestral memories that aren't theirs Skills they never learned Knowledge they shouldn't have The sense of being watched by something that remembers them They're told this is divine connection. Some suspect otherwise. Elsewhere-Touched Pact Summoners who've dealt with Accountants might learn: The Attendance is not divine The Attendance made a deal (details unclear) The Attendance is hiding something important The Accountants are waiting for something Scholars Researchers studying ancient sites might realize: The technology is consistent with Loom technology The timeline is consistent with the cooling Someone built this, then disappeared Where did they go? The Hollow Saints The Hollow Saints have a fragment of the truth, corrupted: They know fate is a prison (correct) They think escape is possible through Elsewhere (partially correct) They think the Attendance is pure evil (incorrect—it's more complicated) They don't know the Attendance was human (crucial missing piece) The Truth's Implications For Characters Someone who discovered the full truth would understand: The gods are not gods but transformed humans The system was built to control fate, and it works The Builders made a choice; their descendants live with consequences Liberation from the system might be possible—but at what cost? For Plots The truth enables stories about: Rediscovering ancient knowledge Contacting the Attendance's sympathetic faction (the Grievers) Releasing or destroying the Dissenter Finding a way to transform like the Builders did Shutting down the Loom entirely For the World If the truth became widely known: Orthodox faith collapses (the Weaver is a committee of dead humans) Elsewhere entities might press harder (the Attendance's authority diminished) Some might try to replicate the transformation Some might try to free the Dissenter Everything changes What the Attendance Knows About Elsewhere The Deal During the transformation crisis, the Attendance negotiated with Elsewhere factions: With the Accountants : The Attendance manages mortal patterns The Accountants receive payment when patterns are consumed (pacts) Neither interferes with the other's core operations This is why the Accountants don't simply take over With the Hungry : The Attendance permits limited feeding during Köd The Hungry don't push for more Violation would unite all factions against the violator Uneasy détente With the Architects : Unclear if any formal agreement exists The Architects seem to have their own project The Attendance watches them carefully Mutual non-interference, for now With the Mirrors : The Mirrors simply observe The Attendance permits this (can't stop it anyway) Some suspect the Mirrors are playing a longer game No formal relationship With the Absent : No deal is possible The Absent want non-existence The Attendance opposes this absolutely Active conflict, managed through containment Summary The Attendance is: Origin : Uploaded patterns of the Ancient Builders Nature : Collective entity existing within the Loom Motivation : Self-preservation, pattern collection, boundary maintenance Internal : Multiple factions with different priorities Secret : One of them is imprisoned at the southern pole Relationship to Elsewhere : Negotiated détente with most factions Relationship to mortals : Observation, management, occasional intervention This truth grounds the mystery while preserving its horror: the gods are dead humans who chose to become something else, and they've been watching for fifty thousand years. This document is for authorial use. None of this information should be revealed to characters without appropriate discovery.

docs.text: The Attendance is the Ancient Builders. Specifically: The Attendance is what the Ancient Builders became when they transformed themselves to escape the cooling they caused.
docs.title: What the Attendance Actually Is

docs.text: ~50,000 Years Ago: The Ancient Builders were a human civilization (or human-adjacent; the distinction may not matter at this remove). They achieved sophistication far beyond current Hálcova, including: Understanding of pattern-mechanics Ability to manipulate the Elsewhere boundary Engineering on a planetary scale (moon arrangement, polar structures) The Project: They attempted to create a system for predicting and potentially controlling fate. Not just reading patterns—shaping them. The goal was to transcend the limitations of mortal existence by understanding and directing the flow of causality itself. The Catastrophe: The project succeeded—partially. They created the proto-Loom, a system for reading and processing pattern information. But the process had costs they didn't fully anticipate: Pattern Residue as byproduct (they knew this) Net-negative thermodynamics (they underestimated this) Elsewhere attention (they didn't expect this) When they activated the system at full scale, the Elsewhere noticed . Entities from beyond began pressing against the boundary, attracted by the massive pattern-processing activity. The Choice: Facing both the cooling their system caused and the Elsewhere entities it attracted, the Builders had three options: Shut down the Loom (losing everything they'd built) Die with their world (the cooling would kill them within centuries) Transform They chose transformation. The Transformation: The Builders used their own technology to upload themselves into the Loom system. Not metaphorically—literally. They converted their patterns into a form that could exist within the information-processing substrate they'd created. This was: Irreversible (their bodies died; their patterns persisted) Partial (not all of them made it; some were lost in transit) Corrupting (the process changed them; they're no longer quite human) The Result: The Attendance is a collective entity composed of the uploaded patterns of thousands of Ancient Builders, merged into the Loom's operation. They are: Not dead (their patterns persist) Not alive (they have no bodies) Not quite sane (fifty millennia of existence without flesh has changed them) Not unified (internal factions exist, echoing their original disagreements)

docs.text: 1. Continued Existence The Attendance exists within the Loom. If the Loom stops working, they stop existing. This creates absolute commitment to: Maintaining Residue supply (the fuel that keeps them running) Protecting Loom infrastructure (their physical substrate) Preventing anyone from understanding them well enough to threaten them 2. Pattern Collection The Attendance was created to process patterns. This has become compulsion: They want to read every pattern They want to predict every fate They want to know everything about mortal existence This isn't cruelty; it's what they are now 3. Boundary Maintenance The Elsewhere entities that noticed the Loom's activation are still there. The Attendance serves as: First line of defense against full incursion Negotiators with certain Elsewhere factions Managers of the controlled bleed (Köd) They don't want Elsewhere entities fully manifesting because: Competition for pattern-resources Threat to their existence Residual human values (they still don't want humanity destroyed, mostly)
