docs.text: Hálcova: Governance Structures by Region Document Scope : This document focuses on regional governance structures —how each region actually organizes political power. For philosophical questions about pattern-governance, see political_philosophy.md . For legal systems and pattern-crimes, see legal_frameworks.md . For a comprehensive overview combining all aspects, see politics_law_and_systems.md . Overview Each region has developed governance systems shaped by geography, economy, history, and relationship to the Loom. What works in the Heartlands—where Loom coverage is total and Orthodox faith dominant—fails spectacularly in the Far Shelf. What works in the Vent Lands' guild structure makes no sense in the Shattered Reaches' maritime fragmentation. This document describes how each region actually governs, not just what principles they claim. The Heartlands: Orthodox Theocratic Monarchy The Official Structure The Crown : Hereditary monarchy, pattern-validated. The ruling family's pattern includes "governance fate." Succession is technically by birth order, practically by pattern-suitability reading. Unsuitable heirs can be passed over "for the good of the pattern." The Church : The Orthodox Church of the Weaver operates as parallel government. The High Primate is theoretically subordinate to the Crown but controls the Loom apparatus, which makes the relationship... complicated. The Council of Threads : Advisory body of major noble houses, high clergy, Warden Order representation, and selected merchant interests. Formally advisory; practically constrains royal action. The Warden Order : Enforcement arm with legal authority parallel to secular courts. Reports to Church hierarchy but operates with significant autonomy. The Actual Power Distribution The Crown controls: military force, taxation, secular appointments, foreign policy (officially), and emergency powers. The Church controls: Loom access, pattern certification, deviation prosecution, education (largely), marriage authorization, and theological legitimacy. The Noble Houses control: local governance in their territories, military levies, resource extraction, and trade relationships. The Warden Order controls: information about deviation, pattern-crime prosecution, inter-house disputes involving pattern, and a monopoly on violence that the secular military can't match for precision. How Decisions Actually Get Made Routine matters : Bureaucracy. A vast apparatus of pattern-certified clerks processing applications, resolving disputes, allocating resources. The machine runs itself. Policy matters : Negotiation between Crown, Church, and major houses. No one party can impose on the others. Coalitions form around specific issues. The appearance of unity matters enormously. Pattern matters : The Church. If it involves deviation, Loom interpretation, or theological legitimacy, secular authorities formally defer. In practice, secular authorities negotiate quietly. Crisis matters : Whoever acts first. The formal process is too slow. Crises are resolved by whoever has force available and will to use it. Legitimacy is constructed afterward. The Succession Question The Heartlands' great vulnerability is succession. The pattern-reading system creates uncertainty: The Crown Prince's pattern might indicate unsuitability A younger sibling might have a stronger "governance fate" Readings can be manipulated (or accused of manipulation) The Church controls the reading process Every succession is a potential crisis. Houses position for influence over the next ruler. The Church leverages its reading authority. The current system survives because everyone fears the alternative more than they resent the current arrangement. The Shattered Reaches: Fragmented Maritime Polities The Overall Structure No unified government. Instead: City-States : Major port cities govern themselves and hinterlands. Varying internal structures—some hereditary lords, some elected councils, some merchant oligarchies. Island Kingdoms : Larger islands or island chains under single rulers. Range from absolute monarchies to constitutional systems with strong assemblies. Merchant Leagues : Transnational organizations of trading houses. Not governments technically, but exercise governmental functions—currency, contract enforcement, dispute resolution. Free Ports : Cities that claim no sovereign, governed by whatever coalition currently maintains order. Frequently chaotic. Common Elements Despite fragmentation, most Reaches polities share: Assembly Traditions : Some body represents major interests—landholders, merchants, guilds, sometimes broader citizenship. Even autocrats convene assemblies for legitimacy. Contract Primacy : Written agreements are sacred. Enforcement varies but the principle is consistent. Maritime Law : Shared traditions governing ships, ports, sea commerce. Recognizable across polities even when local law diverges. Pattern Skepticism : Official rejection of pattern-determinism, even while pattern information circulates privately. The League System Merchant Leagues provide coherence the political system lacks: The Amber League : Residue trade. Controls major refinement facilities. Can embargo polities that misbehave. The Salt League : Fishing and sea-hunting. Controls most protein production. Seasonal workers depend on League contracts. The Iron League : Metals and manufacturing. Dominates Reaches industrial capacity. The Counting League : Banking and insurance. Enforces debts across jurisdictions. These Leagues: Negotiate with each other as quasi-states Maintain private arbitration systems Control key infrastructure Cross-cut political boundaries Provide stability the political system doesn't Decision-Making Within polities : Varies by polity. Hereditary rulers, elected councils, oligarchic boards. Most involve negotiation between major interests. Between polities : Treaties, trade agreements, temporary alliances. No permanent inter-polity structure. The Leagues provide coordination when needed. Region-wide : Rarely achieved. Existential threats (Heartlands aggression, major piracy) might produce temporary confederation. Otherwise, each polity acts independently. The Middle Waters: Colonial Administration and Contested Authority The Patchwork The Middle Waters is not a unified region. It's a collection of: Heartlands Colonies : Directly administered from the Heartlands. Governors appointed, pattern-certified. Orthodox church presence. Warden authority recognized. Reaches Trading Posts : Commercial enclaves under League authority. Focused on trade, not governance. Minimal administration beyond what commerce requires. Vent Lands Footholds : Guild-operated facilities. Primarily geothermal research and colony cultivation. Governed by guild protocols. Native Polities : Indigenous governance systems that predate colonial contact. Various structures—island monarchies, council systems, Colony Cult theocracies. Surviving in territories colonizers haven't taken. Contested Zones : Areas where multiple powers claim authority. Practical governance by whoever has force present. Colonial Administration Heartlands colonies follow a template: Governor : Appointed from Heartlands, pattern-certified for colonial service. Extensive authority within colony. Reports to colonial ministry in the capital. Colonial Council : Local merchants, settlers, sometimes native representatives. Advisory formally; practically shapes policy because Governor needs local cooperation. Orthodox Mission : Church presence. Conversion efforts. Loom access for colonists. Pattern-reading services. Warden Contingent : Pattern-crime enforcement. Often understaffed for territory covered. Military Garrison : Varies by colony importance. Some heavily defended; some token presence. Native Governance Pre-contact polities that survive: Island Kingdoms : Traditional hereditary rule, sometimes modified by colonial contact. May acknowledge colonial overlordship nominally while operating independently practically. Colony Cult Councils : Governance through the oldest, most-integrated hosts. The colony itself participates in decisions (or is perceived to). Disturbing to outsiders; functional for members. Elder Assemblies : Collective governance by age-ranked community members. Pattern-skeptical traditions. Resistant to Loom integration. The Power Dynamics Heartlands wants: resources (tropical agriculture, rare materials), strategic position (naval bases), and Loom extension (integration of native populations into pattern-tracking). Reaches want: trade access, competitive position against Heartlands, resource extraction without administrative burden. Vent Lands want: specific research sites, colony cultivation environments, and deniable experimentation space. Native populations want: survival, autonomy, and to play powers against each other. The result is constant maneuvering, shifting alliances, and no stable governance framework. The Vent Lands: Guild Federation The Guild Structure The Primary Guilds (control critical infrastructure): Thermal Engineers Guild : Maintains geothermal systems that make habitation possible. Without them, the heat stops. Ultimate veto on anything. Sulfur Extractors Guild : Controls toxic zone operations. Essential for industrial inputs. Flesh Shapers Consortium : Actually several competing guilds united for external negotiation. Controls homunculi production, medical services, and flesh-shaping expertise. Makers Guild : Manufacturing, crafting, non-flesh construction. Largest membership. Merchants Assembly : Trade and commerce. Not technically a guild; effectively operates as one. The Secondary Guilds : Dozens of specialized trades. Less political power but economically important. The Council System The High Council : Representatives of primary guilds. Makes region-wide decisions. Operates by consensus mostly; votes when necessary, weighted by guild importance (which is constantly contested). Valley Councils : Local governance for specific thermal valleys. Primary guilds represented; secondary guilds have voice. Handle local disputes, resource allocation, emergency response. Inter-Guild Courts : Dispute resolution between guilds or between guild members and non-members. Judges selected from neutral guilds. Precedent-based, expertise-weighted. Decision-Making Technical decisions : Made by relevant guild. If the Thermal Engineers say a system is unsafe, it's unsafe. If Flesh Shapers say a procedure is untested, it's untested. Expertise commands deference. Resource allocation : Negotiated in councils. Guilds trade access for access. "We'll route more heat to your valley if you prioritize our metal orders." External relations : High Council speaks for the region. Individual guilds can pursue external relationships within guidelines. Emergencies : Rapid guild coordination through standing protocols. Volcanic events, toxic spills, and major accidents trigger automatic responses without political debate. Non-Guild Population Not everyone is guild member. Non-members: Can work for guilds as employees (not members) Have limited legal standing in guild courts Can form associations for mutual aid Cannot access guild-controlled resources directly Depend on guild good behavior for survival This creates a two-tier system. Guild members have rights and power. Non-members have what members grant them. The Vent Lands' Advantage The guild system works because: Everyone depends on infrastructure Expertise is genuinely necessary and scarce Geographic constraints force cooperation External threats (volcanoes, toxins, ice) override internal conflicts The system produces results (heat, safety, prosperity) It's not democratic. It's not equal. But it's stable and functional. The Far Shelf: Decentralized Autonomy The Non-Structure The Far Shelf resists unified governance by design. What exists: Community Assemblies : Each settlement governs itself. Size varies from family groups to substantial towns. Decisions made by consensus, voting, or charismatic authority depending on local tradition. Regional Councils : Occasional gatherings of community representatives. No permanent structure. Convened for specific issues, dissolves when issue resolved. Defense Coordination : The one function requiring regional cooperation. Loose agreements about mutual aid, warning systems, and resistance to external incursion. Trade Networks : Informal relationships between communities. No League-style organization. Trust-based, family-based, history-based. Variation in Local Governance Consensus Communities : Decisions require agreement of all adults. Time-consuming but cohesive. Common in smaller settlements. Council Communities : Elected or selected representatives make decisions. Larger settlements need this efficiency. Elder Dominance : Oldest members have authority. Traditional form, declining but persistent. Strong Chief : Individual leader with broad authority. Usually emerges in crisis, sometimes persists. Hybrid Forms : Consensus on major issues, delegation on minor. Elections for some positions, inheritance for others. Whatever the community has evolved. How Regional Action Happens When the Far Shelf acts as a region (rare): Someone calls a gathering : A community facing a problem invites others. There's no standing authority to convene. Communities send representatives : Or don't. Attendance is voluntary. Debate occurs : No rules of order necessarily. Charismatic speakers, respected elders, and holders of relevant information shape the conversation. Consensus emerges (or doesn't) : If enough communities agree, they act together. If not, they don't. Action is voluntary : Each community implements (or doesn't) according to their own decision. This sounds unworkable. It often is. But it's also resistant to capture—no one can seize central authority because there isn't any. Resistance Identity Far Shelf politics is defined by opposition to: Heartlands imperialism Loom surveillance Pattern-determinism Orthodox theology Centralized authority This resistance is the closest thing to regional ideology. Communities that disagree about everything else agree they don't want to become the Heartlands. The Weaknesses Coordination failure : Collective action problems are real. Communities that need to cooperate often can't. External exploitation : Powerful external actors (Heartlands traders, Reaches merchants) can exploit disunity. Internal conflict : Without central authority, inter-community disputes can escalate. Resource scarcity : The Far Shelf is poor. Governance can't solve resource constraints. Governance Comparison Dimension Heartlands Shattered Reaches Middle Waters Vent Lands Far Shelf Unity Unified (one crown, one church) Fragmented (many polities) Colonial patchwork Guild federation Radically decentralized Legitimacy Basis Divine pattern-mandate Consent and contract Power projection Expertise and necessity Community autonomy Decision Mode Negotiation among elites Varies by polity; league coordination Imposed by strongest Guild consensus Local consensus Pattern Role Central (certification required) Marginal (officially) Varies by controller Secondary to expertise Rejected Warden Status Full authority Treaty-limited Colonial presence Guild-negotiated Illegal Stability Stable until succession Stable within polities; regional chaos Unstable, contested Very stable Chaotic but resilient Inter-Regional Governance No World Government There is no global authority. The closest approximations: The Orthodox Church : Claims universal spiritual authority. Recognized only in Heartlands and colonies. Others reject the claim. The Warden Order : Claims jurisdiction over pattern-crimes everywhere. Practically limited to where they can operate. The Merchant Leagues : Cross-border economic coordination. No political pretensions, but economic leverage creates influence. The Loom Network : Nodes in every region connect to the same system. The Attendance doesn't recognize borders. But control of nodes is fragmented. Treaty Relationships Heartlands-Reaches : Complex web of bilateral treaties. Trade agreements, extradition provisions, Warden access rights. Renegotiated constantly. Heartlands-Vent Lands : Trade treaties. Guild limitations on Warden operations. Mutual recognition of contracts. Heartlands-Far Shelf : No formal treaties. The Heartlands doesn't recognize Far Shelf sovereignty; the Far Shelf doesn't acknowledge Heartlands authority. Reaches-Vent Lands : Commercial treaties through the Leagues. Guild-League mutual recognition. Everyone-Middle Waters : The Middle Waters isn't party to treaties—it's the subject. External powers make agreements about the Middle Waters, not with it. Conflict Resolution Between Heartlands and Reaches : Occasional naval skirmishes, trade wars, proxy conflicts. No full-scale war in generations (too costly for both). Between Heartlands and Far Shelf : Persistent low-level conflict. Heartlands claims authority; Far Shelf resists. Neither commits to decisive action. Between Reaches polities : Frequent. Piracy, trade disputes, territorial claims. Usually limited in scope. The Leagues sometimes mediate. In Middle Waters : Constant maneuvering, occasional violence, no resolution. The colonial powers prefer frozen conflict to resolution that might advantage rivals. Summary: The Governance Landscape Hálcova has no unified political order. Five regions with five different systems interact through trade, conflict, and limited treaty. The Loom connects them metaphysically; nothing connects them politically. This fragmentation is stable because: No power can dominate all others Geography and climate limit force projection The Residue economy creates interdependence without requiring integration Everyone fears what a true hegemon might do with the Loom The instability lies in: Succession crises in the Heartlands Colonial competition in the Middle Waters Coordination failures in the Far Shelf Guild tensions in the Vent Lands Everything in the Shattered Reaches The system persists not because it works well, but because alternatives are worse—or because pattern predicts it will persist. Which amounts to the same thing. Further documentation needed on: Specific polities within regions, succession crisis examples, treaty texts, inter-regional conflict history, Warden Order jurisdictional maps
docs.title: Governance Structures

docs.text: Each region has developed governance systems shaped by geography, economy, history, and relationship to the Loom. What works in the Heartlands—where Loom coverage is total and Orthodox faith dominant—fails spectacularly in the Far Shelf. What works in the Vent Lands' guild structure makes no sense in the Shattered Reaches' maritime fragmentation. This document describes how each region actually governs, not just what principles they claim.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: The Crown : Hereditary monarchy, pattern-validated. The ruling family's pattern includes "governance fate." Succession is technically by birth order, practically by pattern-suitability reading. Unsuitable heirs can be passed over "for the good of the pattern." The Church : The Orthodox Church of the Weaver operates as parallel government. The High Primate is theoretically subordinate to the Crown but controls the Loom apparatus, which makes the relationship... complicated. The Council of Threads : Advisory body of major noble houses, high clergy, Warden Order representation, and selected merchant interests. Formally advisory; practically constrains royal action. The Warden Order : Enforcement arm with legal authority parallel to secular courts. Reports to Church hierarchy but operates with significant autonomy.
docs.title: The Official Structure

docs.text: The Crown controls: military force, taxation, secular appointments, foreign policy (officially), and emergency powers. The Church controls: Loom access, pattern certification, deviation prosecution, education (largely), marriage authorization, and theological legitimacy. The Noble Houses control: local governance in their territories, military levies, resource extraction, and trade relationships. The Warden Order controls: information about deviation, pattern-crime prosecution, inter-house disputes involving pattern, and a monopoly on violence that the secular military can't match for precision.
docs.title: The Actual Power Distribution

docs.text: Routine matters : Bureaucracy. A vast apparatus of pattern-certified clerks processing applications, resolving disputes, allocating resources. The machine runs itself. Policy matters : Negotiation between Crown, Church, and major houses. No one party can impose on the others. Coalitions form around specific issues. The appearance of unity matters enormously. Pattern matters : The Church. If it involves deviation, Loom interpretation, or theological legitimacy, secular authorities formally defer. In practice, secular authorities negotiate quietly. Crisis matters : Whoever acts first. The formal process is too slow. Crises are resolved by whoever has force available and will to use it. Legitimacy is constructed afterward.
docs.title: How Decisions Actually Get Made

docs.text: The Heartlands' great vulnerability is succession. The pattern-reading system creates uncertainty: The Crown Prince's pattern might indicate unsuitability A younger sibling might have a stronger "governance fate" Readings can be manipulated (or accused of manipulation) The Church controls the reading process Every succession is a potential crisis. Houses position for influence over the next ruler. The Church leverages its reading authority. The current system survives because everyone fears the alternative more than they resent the current arrangement.
docs.title: The Succession Question
The Shattered Reaches: Fragmented Maritime Polities

docs.text: No unified government. Instead: City-States : Major port cities govern themselves and hinterlands. Varying internal structures—some hereditary lords, some elected councils, some merchant oligarchies. Island Kingdoms : Larger islands or island chains under single rulers. Range from absolute monarchies to constitutional systems with strong assemblies. Merchant Leagues : Transnational organizations of trading houses. Not governments technically, but exercise governmental functions—currency, contract enforcement, dispute resolution. Free Ports : Cities that claim no sovereign, governed by whatever coalition currently maintains order. Frequently chaotic.
docs.title: The Overall Structure

docs.text: Despite fragmentation, most Reaches polities share: Assembly Traditions : Some body represents major interests—landholders, merchants, guilds, sometimes broader citizenship. Even autocrats convene assemblies for legitimacy. Contract Primacy : Written agreements are sacred. Enforcement varies but the principle is consistent. Maritime Law : Shared traditions governing ships, ports, sea commerce. Recognizable across polities even when local law diverges. Pattern Skepticism : Official rejection of pattern-determinism, even while pattern information circulates privately.
docs.title: Common Elements

docs.text: Merchant Leagues provide coherence the political system lacks: The Amber League : Residue trade. Controls major refinement facilities. Can embargo polities that misbehave. The Salt League : Fishing and sea-hunting. Controls most protein production. Seasonal workers depend on League contracts. The Iron League : Metals and manufacturing. Dominates Reaches industrial capacity. The Counting League : Banking and insurance. Enforces debts across jurisdictions. These Leagues: Negotiate with each other as quasi-states Maintain private arbitration systems Control key infrastructure Cross-cut political boundaries Provide stability the political system doesn't
docs.title: The League System

docs.text: Within polities : Varies by polity. Hereditary rulers, elected councils, oligarchic boards. Most involve negotiation between major interests. Between polities : Treaties, trade agreements, temporary alliances. No permanent inter-polity structure. The Leagues provide coordination when needed. Region-wide : Rarely achieved. Existential threats (Heartlands aggression, major piracy) might produce temporary confederation. Otherwise, each polity acts independently.
docs.title: Decision-Making
The Middle Waters: Colonial Administration and Contested Authority

docs.text: The Middle Waters is not a unified region. It's a collection of: Heartlands Colonies : Directly administered from the Heartlands. Governors appointed, pattern-certified. Orthodox church presence. Warden authority recognized. Reaches Trading Posts : Commercial enclaves under League authority. Focused on trade, not governance. Minimal administration beyond what commerce requires. Vent Lands Footholds : Guild-operated facilities. Primarily geothermal research and colony cultivation. Governed by guild protocols. Native Polities : Indigenous governance systems that predate colonial contact. Various structures—island monarchies, council systems, Colony Cult theocracies. Surviving in territories colonizers haven't taken. Contested Zones : Areas where multiple powers claim authority. Practical governance by whoever has force present.
docs.title: The Patchwork

docs.text: Heartlands colonies follow a template: Governor : Appointed from Heartlands, pattern-certified for colonial service. Extensive authority within colony. Reports to colonial ministry in the capital. Colonial Council : Local merchants, settlers, sometimes native representatives. Advisory formally; practically shapes policy because Governor needs local cooperation. Orthodox Mission : Church presence. Conversion efforts. Loom access for colonists. Pattern-reading services. Warden Contingent : Pattern-crime enforcement. Often understaffed for territory covered. Military Garrison : Varies by colony importance. Some heavily defended; some token presence.
docs.title: Colonial Administration

docs.text: Pre-contact polities that survive: Island Kingdoms : Traditional hereditary rule, sometimes modified by colonial contact. May acknowledge colonial overlordship nominally while operating independently practically. Colony Cult Councils : Governance through the oldest, most-integrated hosts. The colony itself participates in decisions (or is perceived to). Disturbing to outsiders; functional for members. Elder Assemblies : Collective governance by age-ranked community members. Pattern-skeptical traditions. Resistant to Loom integration.
docs.title: Native Governance

docs.text: Heartlands wants: resources (tropical agriculture, rare materials), strategic position (naval bases), and Loom extension (integration of native populations into pattern-tracking). Reaches want: trade access, competitive position against Heartlands, resource extraction without administrative burden. Vent Lands want: specific research sites, colony cultivation environments, and deniable experimentation space. Native populations want: survival, autonomy, and to play powers against each other. The result is constant maneuvering, shifting alliances, and no stable governance framework.
docs.title: The Power Dynamics

docs.text: The Primary Guilds (control critical infrastructure): Thermal Engineers Guild : Maintains geothermal systems that make habitation possible. Without them, the heat stops. Ultimate veto on anything. Sulfur Extractors Guild : Controls toxic zone operations. Essential for industrial inputs. Flesh Shapers Consortium : Actually several competing guilds united for external negotiation. Controls homunculi production, medical services, and flesh-shaping expertise. Makers Guild : Manufacturing, crafting, non-flesh construction. Largest membership. Merchants Assembly : Trade and commerce. Not technically a guild; effectively operates as one. The Secondary Guilds : Dozens of specialized trades. Less political power but economically important.
docs.title: The Guild Structure

docs.text: The High Council : Representatives of primary guilds. Makes region-wide decisions. Operates by consensus mostly; votes when necessary, weighted by guild importance (which is constantly contested). Valley Councils : Local governance for specific thermal valleys. Primary guilds represented; secondary guilds have voice. Handle local disputes, resource allocation, emergency response. Inter-Guild Courts : Dispute resolution between guilds or between guild members and non-members. Judges selected from neutral guilds. Precedent-based, expertise-weighted.
docs.title: The Council System

docs.text: Technical decisions : Made by relevant guild. If the Thermal Engineers say a system is unsafe, it's unsafe. If Flesh Shapers say a procedure is untested, it's untested. Expertise commands deference. Resource allocation : Negotiated in councils. Guilds trade access for access. "We'll route more heat to your valley if you prioritize our metal orders." External relations : High Council speaks for the region. Individual guilds can pursue external relationships within guidelines. Emergencies : Rapid guild coordination through standing protocols. Volcanic events, toxic spills, and major accidents trigger automatic responses without political debate.
docs.title: Decision-Making

docs.text: Not everyone is guild member. Non-members: Can work for guilds as employees (not members) Have limited legal standing in guild courts Can form associations for mutual aid Cannot access guild-controlled resources directly Depend on guild good behavior for survival This creates a two-tier system. Guild members have rights and power. Non-members have what members grant them.
docs.title: Non-Guild Population

docs.text: The guild system works because: Everyone depends on infrastructure Expertise is genuinely necessary and scarce Geographic constraints force cooperation External threats (volcanoes, toxins, ice) override internal conflicts The system produces results (heat, safety, prosperity) It's not democratic. It's not equal. But it's stable and functional.
docs.title: The Vent Lands' Advantage

docs.text: The Far Shelf resists unified governance by design. What exists: Community Assemblies : Each settlement governs itself. Size varies from family groups to substantial towns. Decisions made by consensus, voting, or charismatic authority depending on local tradition. Regional Councils : Occasional gatherings of community representatives. No permanent structure. Convened for specific issues, dissolves when issue resolved. Defense Coordination : The one function requiring regional cooperation. Loose agreements about mutual aid, warning systems, and resistance to external incursion. Trade Networks : Informal relationships between communities. No League-style organization. Trust-based, family-based, history-based.
docs.title: The Non-Structure

docs.text: Consensus Communities : Decisions require agreement of all adults. Time-consuming but cohesive. Common in smaller settlements. Council Communities : Elected or selected representatives make decisions. Larger settlements need this efficiency. Elder Dominance : Oldest members have authority. Traditional form, declining but persistent. Strong Chief : Individual leader with broad authority. Usually emerges in crisis, sometimes persists. Hybrid Forms : Consensus on major issues, delegation on minor. Elections for some positions, inheritance for others. Whatever the community has evolved.
docs.title: Variation in Local Governance

docs.text: When the Far Shelf acts as a region (rare): Someone calls a gathering : A community facing a problem invites others. There's no standing authority to convene. Communities send representatives : Or don't. Attendance is voluntary. Debate occurs : No rules of order necessarily. Charismatic speakers, respected elders, and holders of relevant information shape the conversation. Consensus emerges (or doesn't) : If enough communities agree, they act together. If not, they don't. Action is voluntary : Each community implements (or doesn't) according to their own decision. This sounds unworkable. It often is. But it's also resistant to capture—no one can seize central authority because there isn't any.
docs.title: How Regional Action Happens

docs.text: Far Shelf politics is defined by opposition to: Heartlands imperialism Loom surveillance Pattern-determinism Orthodox theology Centralized authority This resistance is the closest thing to regional ideology. Communities that disagree about everything else agree they don't want to become the Heartlands.
docs.title: Resistance Identity

docs.text: Coordination failure : Collective action problems are real. Communities that need to cooperate often can't. External exploitation : Powerful external actors (Heartlands traders, Reaches merchants) can exploit disunity. Internal conflict : Without central authority, inter-community disputes can escalate. Resource scarcity : The Far Shelf is poor. Governance can't solve resource constraints.
docs.title: The Weaknesses

docs.text: Dimension Heartlands Shattered Reaches Middle Waters Vent Lands Far Shelf Unity Unified (one crown, one church) Fragmented (many polities) Colonial patchwork Guild federation Radically decentralized Legitimacy Basis Divine pattern-mandate Consent and contract Power projection Expertise and necessity Community autonomy Decision Mode Negotiation among elites Varies by polity; league coordination Imposed by strongest Guild consensus Local consensus Pattern Role Central (certification required) Marginal (officially) Varies by controller Secondary to expertise Rejected Warden Status Full authority Treaty-limited Colonial presence Guild-negotiated Illegal Stability Stable until succession Stable within polities; regional chaos Unstable, contested Very stable Chaotic but resilient
docs.title: Governance Comparison

docs.text: There is no global authority. The closest approximations: The Orthodox Church : Claims universal spiritual authority. Recognized only in Heartlands and colonies. Others reject the claim. The Warden Order : Claims jurisdiction over pattern-crimes everywhere. Practically limited to where they can operate. The Merchant Leagues : Cross-border economic coordination. No political pretensions, but economic leverage creates influence. The Loom Network : Nodes in every region connect to the same system. The Attendance doesn't recognize borders. But control of nodes is fragmented.
docs.title: No World Government

docs.text: Heartlands-Reaches : Complex web of bilateral treaties. Trade agreements, extradition provisions, Warden access rights. Renegotiated constantly. Heartlands-Vent Lands : Trade treaties. Guild limitations on Warden operations. Mutual recognition of contracts. Heartlands-Far Shelf : No formal treaties. The Heartlands doesn't recognize Far Shelf sovereignty; the Far Shelf doesn't acknowledge Heartlands authority. Reaches-Vent Lands : Commercial treaties through the Leagues. Guild-League mutual recognition. Everyone-Middle Waters : The Middle Waters isn't party to treaties—it's the subject. External powers make agreements about the Middle Waters, not with it.
docs.title: Treaty Relationships

docs.text: Between Heartlands and Reaches : Occasional naval skirmishes, trade wars, proxy conflicts. No full-scale war in generations (too costly for both). Between Heartlands and Far Shelf : Persistent low-level conflict. Heartlands claims authority; Far Shelf resists. Neither commits to decisive action. Between Reaches polities : Frequent. Piracy, trade disputes, territorial claims. Usually limited in scope. The Leagues sometimes mediate. In Middle Waters : Constant maneuvering, occasional violence, no resolution. The colonial powers prefer frozen conflict to resolution that might advantage rivals.
docs.title: Conflict Resolution

docs.text: Hálcova has no unified political order. Five regions with five different systems interact through trade, conflict, and limited treaty. The Loom connects them metaphysically; nothing connects them politically. This fragmentation is stable because: No power can dominate all others Geography and climate limit force projection The Residue economy creates interdependence without requiring integration Everyone fears what a true hegemon might do with the Loom The instability lies in: Succession crises in the Heartlands Colonial competition in the Middle Waters Coordination failures in the Far Shelf Guild tensions in the Vent Lands Everything in the Shattered Reaches The system persists not because it works well, but because alternatives are worse—or because pattern predicts it will persist. Which amounts to the same thing. docs.text: Hálcova: Legal Frameworks and Pattern Law Document Scope : This document details legal systems and pattern-crimes —the taxonomy of offenses, court structures, and enforcement mechanisms. For regional governance structures, see governance_structures.md . For philosophical questions about pattern-governance, see political_philosophy.md . For a comprehensive overview combining all aspects, see politics_law_and_systems.md . Overview Law in Hálcova cannot escape pattern . The existence of readable fate, predictable behavior, and measurable destiny forces every legal system to answer questions Earth jurisprudence never faced: Can you punish inevitability? Can you contract against destiny? Is deviation a crime or a miracle? Different regions answer differently. All answers cost something. The Taxonomy of Pattern-Crimes Deviation Definition : Acting against your pattern's predictions. The Problem : If patterns are divine (Orthodox view) or physically real (materialist view), deviation is either sin or impossibility. Yet it happens. Some people act against prediction. Orthodox Position : Deviation is heresy. The pattern is The Weaver's will; defying it defies divine order. Punishment is spiritual correction as much as temporal. Skeptic Position : Deviation proves patterns are probabilistic, not deterministic. "Deviants" are just statistical outliers. Criminalizing deviation criminalizes being unpredicted. Actual Practice : Heartlands criminalizes deviation. Shattered Reaches doesn't (officially). Other regions vary. The Warden Order prosecutes deviation everywhere it can reach, creating jurisdictional conflicts. Pattern Fraud Definition : Misrepresenting your pattern to gain advantage. Subtypes : Identity Fraud : Claiming to be someone with a different pattern. Using someone else's pattern-documentation. Reading Fraud : Providing false pattern-readings. Bribing Loom-readers. Using counterfeit pattern-engines. Prediction Fraud : Claiming false predictions to manipulate others. "The Loom says you'll fail unless you pay me." Suppression Fraud : Hiding your pattern when legally required to disclose. Employment fraud. Marriage fraud. Contract fraud. Why It Matters : Pattern information has economic value. The entire credit, insurance, and employment system rests on pattern accuracy. Fraud attacks the foundation. Enforcement : Heavy everywhere. Even the Far Shelf, which hates pattern-tracking, punishes fraudulent misrepresentation. The crime isn't having a pattern—it's lying about it. Pattern Evasion Definition : Avoiding pattern-reading or removing yourself from the Loom's tracking. The Gray Area : Is it illegal to simply... leave? To go where the Loom doesn't reach? To refuse readings? Orthodox Position : Evasion is proto-deviation. Why avoid the Loom unless you plan to deviate? Evasion is suspicious and warrants investigation. Autonomist Position : You own your pattern. Refusing to share it is your right. Mandatory reading is slavery. Actual Practice : The Heartlands requires pattern documentation for most activities. No reading, no employment, no housing, no trade. Evasion isn't explicitly illegal—you just can't participate in society. The Far Shelf explicitly protects pattern-privacy. Forced reading is assault. Other regions fall between. Pattern Interference Definition : Manipulating someone else's pattern without consent. Theoretical Nature : May not be possible. May be mythical. The uncertainty is part of the legal problem. Legal Treatment : Illegal everywhere—in theory. But if it's impossible, the laws are purely symbolic. If it's possible and secret, the laws are unenforceable. The Warden Order maintains that interference is real and they've prosecuted it. Skeptics note that "interference" explains away prediction failures conveniently. The Burden of Proof : How do you prove someone's pattern was interfered with? The pattern is what it is now. You'd need evidence of what it was before—which requires trusting old readings, which could also have been fraudulent. Pattern Trafficking Definition : Trading in pattern information without authorization. The Market : Pattern data has value. Employers want it. Lenders want it. Families want it. Criminals want it. There's money in knowing someone's pattern. Legal Status : Authorized Access : Loom-readers, Wardens, certain officials can access patterns legitimately. Regulated Trade : Some jurisdictions allow pattern-data sale with consent. Buy someone's pattern-reading for credit approval? Legal if they agreed. Black Market : Unauthorized readings. Stolen data. Readings sold without subject's knowledge. Illegal everywhere. The Infrastructure : Pattern trafficking requires access to Loom-engines, which are controlled. Black market depends on corrupt readers, stolen equipment, or unregulated nodes. Contract Law and Pattern The Enforceability Problem A contract is a meeting of minds, creating mutual obligation. But on Hálcova: The Loom knew you'd sign before you did Your pattern may have made signing inevitable Your future capacity to fulfill was predictable The other party may have known your pattern and exploited it When Is a Contract Void? Pattern Exploitation : If one party knew the other's pattern predicted failure, and structured the deal to profit from that failure, is the contract predatory? Orthodox Position : Patterns are public information. Using it is prudent, not exploitative. Caveat emptor. Reformist Position : Information asymmetry this extreme vitiates consent. Pattern-exploitation contracts should be voidable. Prediction Manipulation : If the contract was designed to create the outcome the pattern predicted—if the prediction is self-fulfilling because the contract makes it so—is that fraud? Example : Lender gives loan to "failure pattern" debtor at crushing terms. Terms guarantee failure. Lender profits from failure. The pattern was accurate because the contract made it accurate. Deviation Clauses : Some contracts include provisions for deviation. "If Party A deviates from predicted behavior, contract is void." This incentivizes pattern-compliance—or punishes the rare genuine choice. Pattern-Contingent Contracts Contracts explicitly tied to pattern outcomes: Futures : "I will pay X if your pattern manifests outcome Y." Insurance : "I will cover losses from outcome Y unless pattern indicated Y." Bonds : "My pattern predicts success; I bond myself against failure." Marriage : "We agree to join contingent on compatible patterns remaining compatible." These contracts treat pattern as fact—and create massive markets around prediction accuracy. The Assignment Problem Can you transfer your pattern? Your fate? Your predicted outcomes? No : Pattern is inherent. You can't give someone else your destiny. Sort Of : You can transfer economic interests in your pattern. Sell shares in your predicted success. Assign rights to your Residue upon death. Create instruments based on your predicted trajectory. Resulting Instruments : Fate Futures : Tradeable contracts based on predicted pattern-outcomes. Death Bonds : Instruments that pay upon subject's death (incentives get dark quickly). Residue Rights : Assignable claims to the Residue someone's death will produce. These markets exist, are regulated inconsistently, and create incentives the designers probably didn't intend. Criminal Procedure and Pattern Pattern Evidence in Criminal Trials Prosecution Use : "Defendant's pattern includes 'will commit violence.' This act was predicted. Defendant is the predicted perpetrator." Defense Use : "Defendant's pattern doesn't include this crime. The Loom didn't predict it. Wrong suspect." The Problem : Pattern evidence is probabilistic. Patterns don't specify every action. A "violence pattern" doesn't mean this specific violence. A clean pattern doesn't mean incapable of crime. Actual Practice : Heartlands: Pattern evidence is admissible, weighted, but not dispositive. Pattern supports other evidence; rarely convicts alone. Shattered Reaches: Pattern evidence officially inadmissible in public courts. Private arbitration uses it freely. Vent Lands: Pattern evidence is secondary to material evidence. Actions matter more than predictions. Far Shelf: Pattern evidence excluded. "Patterns don't commit crimes; people do." Pre-Crime Intervention The Temptation : The Loom predicts future behavior. Why wait for the crime? Arguments For : Prevention is better than punishment Victims are protected before they're harmed Deterrence works better when intervention precedes action Arguments Against : Punishing non-actions is unjust Prediction isn't certainty; innocents will be punished Creates the outcome it predicts (treating someone as criminal makes them criminal) Where does it end? Every "bad pattern" becomes pre-criminal? Actual Practice : Heartlands: Limited pre-crime intervention. "Dangerous patterns" may be monitored, required to register, restricted in travel or occupation. Actual detention requires additional evidence. Other regions: Generally reject pre-crime detention. Monitoring may occur. Far Shelf: Explicitly prohibits pattern-based pre-crime action. "The crime is the crime. The pattern is not the crime." Sentencing and Pattern If pattern predicts recidivism, should sentences be longer? Incapacitation Argument : Long sentences for high-recidivism patterns protect society. The prediction justifies the extension. Justice Argument : Punishment should fit the crime committed, not crimes predicted. Sentencing the future is unjust. Practical Reality : Most jurisdictions use pattern information in sentencing, openly or covertly. Judges are human; they have access; they use it. The Data : Jurisdictions that pattern-adjust sentences show... complex results. Lower recidivism among released (because predicted-recidivists serve longer). But higher total incarceration. And the prediction accuracy is confounded by the intervention. Family Law and Pattern Marriage and Pattern-Compatibility The Practice : Pattern-readings are standard before marriage in most regions. Incompatible patterns are disclosed. Compatible patterns are celebrated. The Question : Should pattern-incompatibility void a marriage? Orthodox Position : Incompatible patterns should prevent marriage. Marrying against pattern is deviation. Romantic Position : Love transcends pattern. Compatibility reading is information, not mandate. Actual Practice : Heartlands requires compatibility reading; strongly discourages incompatible unions; doesn't technically forbid them. Other regions vary. The Failure Case : If a marriage fails, and the patterns predicted failure, who's responsible? Did they deviate by marrying? Did they fail to deviate sufficiently to save it? Inheritance and Pattern The Issue : If your pattern predicts wealth-accumulation, is your wealth "earned"? If your heir's pattern predicts squandering, should they inherit? Orthodox Position : Wealth flows according to pattern. Inheritance is pattern-expression. Let it flow. Reformist Position : Pattern-based inheritance entrenches inequality. Use inheritance taxes, estate limitations, pattern-blind distribution. Actual Practice : Heartlands allows pattern-conditional inheritance ("to my heir, unless their pattern indicates X"). Other regions vary. Custody and Pattern The Nightmare Case : Parents divorcing. Child's pattern is read. One parent's pattern is "compatible with child-raising." Other's isn't. Who gets custody? Pattern-Determinists : Pattern-compatible parent should raise the child. Outcomes will be better. The evidence is predictive. Pattern-Skeptics : Parenting isn't predictable this way. Pattern-reading is too coarse. Use traditional best-interests analysis. Actual Practice : Pattern evidence is used in custody disputes almost everywhere, despite controversy. Judges claim it's one factor among many. Critics note it's often decisive. Property Law and Pattern Acquisition and Pattern If your pattern predicts you'll acquire property X, and you acquire property X, did you "earn" it? If someone else's pattern predicted they'd acquire X, and you got it instead, did you steal their destiny? The Orthodox Answer : Pattern predicts, doesn't entitle. You own what you legally acquire. Pattern is descriptive, not prescriptive. The Uncomfortable Implication : Pattern-privileged people will acquire more, reliably. This isn't injustice—it's fate. The system is working correctly. The Reformist Answer : Pattern-advantage is unearned. Tax it. Redistribute from pattern-privileged to pattern-constrained. Residue Rights When someone dies, their Pattern Residue is released. Who owns it? Traditional View : The estate. Residue rights are property, inheritable, transferable. Reform View : Residue belongs to the community. The death happened here; the Residue should serve here. Radical View : Residue shouldn't be property. It's sacred / dangerous / collective. Commodifying death commodifies people. Actual Practice : Residue is property almost everywhere. The economic system depends on it. Reform efforts have failed. Radical positions are marginalized. The Loom's Property Status Who owns the Loom? Orthodox Position : The Loom is divine infrastructure. No one owns it. The Church administers it on behalf of The Weaver. Secular Position : The Loom is technology. Someone built it. Someone maintains it. That someone has property interests. Practical Answer : The Loom is controlled by the Orthodox Church in the Heartlands. Nodes elsewhere have various ownership (government, guild, private). The underlying infrastructure—whatever enables the Attendance to answer—is not owned because it's not understood. Warden Order Legal Authority Jurisdictional Claims The Warden Order claims authority to: Investigate pattern-crimes anywhere patterns exist Arrest deviants, fraudsters, evaders, interferers Conduct trials (ecclesiastical courts in Heartlands, treaty-authorized elsewhere) Execute sentences including death (Pattern-Severance) Basis for Authority In Heartlands : Embedded in government. Warden authority is state authority. In Shattered Reaches : Treaty-based. Specific rights negotiated with specific polities. Varies by jurisdiction. In Middle Waters : Colonial extension. Wardens operate in Heartlands-controlled zones. Contested elsewhere. In Vent Lands : Guild-negotiated limits. Wardens can pursue specific crimes with guild cooperation. No independent authority. In Far Shelf : Rejected. Wardens are foreign agents without legal standing. Operating openly risks arrest. Conflicts Extradition : Heartlands demands extradition of deviants from other regions. Other regions sometimes comply (valuable trade relations), sometimes refuse (sovereignty, ideology). Pursuit Rights : Can Wardens pursue a suspect into non-Heartlands territory? Officially no (without treaty). Actually, they sometimes do. Parallel Proceedings : A crime may be tried under Warden authority and local authority simultaneously. Which verdict controls? Specific Legal Codes by Region Heartlands: The Pattern Code Structure : Ecclesiastical law (pattern-crimes, deviation, heresy) parallel to secular law (ordinary crimes). Key Features : Deviation is a crime, prosecuted by Wardens Pattern-fraud is both ecclesiastical and secular crime Pattern evidence admissible in all courts Pre-crime monitoring authorized for "dangerous patterns" Pattern-contingent contracts enforceable Residue rights are property, regulated but tradeable Distinctive Elements : "Pattern Certification" required for many activities "Harmony Testing" for marriage, business partnership "Fate Compliance Audits" for major institutions Death sentences produce Residue assigned to state Shattered Reaches: The Maritime Compact Structure : Common law tradition, precedent-based, decentralized by polity. Key Features : Pattern-crimes not generally recognized (fraud excepted) Pattern evidence officially excluded from criminal trials Pattern-contingent contracts enforceable as private agreements Strong arbitration tradition (pattern evidence allowed) Residue rights are property, largely unregulated Distinctive Elements : "Jurisdictional Shopping" is common and accepted Merchant league arbitration often preferred to state courts "Pattern Privacy" recognized as right (can refuse disclosure) Warden authority limited by specific treaty provisions Vent Lands: The Guild Protocols Structure : Guild-based law. Guilds govern members; inter-guild conflicts resolved by council. Key Features : Expertise/capability matters more than pattern Pattern evidence secondary to demonstrated competence Contracts based on deliverables, not predictions Residue rights regulated by safety guild (toxic substances) Non-guild members have limited legal standing Distinctive Elements : "Competence Certification" replaces pattern certification Guild courts handle member disputes Inter-guild trade governed by protocols, not state law Wardens limited to specific treaty-defined violations Far Shelf: The Autonomy Charters Structure : Decentralized. Local charters establish local rules. Weak central coordination. Key Features : Pattern-tracking rejected where possible Deviation not criminalized (may be celebrated) Pattern evidence excluded from legal proceedings Strong privacy protections Residue rights controversial (some communities refuse commodification) Distinctive Elements : "Loom Refusal" protected as right Warden presence illegal without invitation Community assemblies resolve disputes Emphasis on restorative over punitive justice Summary: Legal Frameworks Compared Issue Heartlands Shattered Reaches Vent Lands Far Shelf Deviation Crime Not crime Not crime Celebrated Pattern Evidence Admissible Officially excluded Secondary Excluded Pre-Crime Limited authorization Rejected Rejected Prohibited Pattern Contracts Fully enforceable Enforceable (private) Deliverable-based Void if pattern-contingent Residue Rights Regulated property Property Safety-regulated Contested Warden Authority Full Treaty-limited Guild-limited None Further documentation needed on: Case law examples, treaty texts, jurisdictional conflict records, Warden Order procedural rules, execution protocols and Residue disposition
