docs.text: The Art of Building Servants
docs.title: Flesh Shaping

docs.text: Flesh Shaping creates homunculi —constructed servants built from raw materials and animated with blood. Unlike echoes, homunculi never lived. They have no history, no memories, no existence prior to their creation. They are made , not captured. This sounds cleaner than Core Binding. It isn't. The horror is different, not lesser.
docs.title: Fundamental Principle

docs.text: Raw Materials A homunculus is built from physical components: Flesh (from corpses, butcher shops, battlefields) Bone (structural support, framework) Clay (crude but durable) Metal (for specialized purposes) Wax (malleable, temporary) Leather (flexible, resilient) Different materials produce different results. The medium shapes the creation: Bone-wrights build skeletal servants—light, fast, clicking when they move Flesh-sculptors work in meat and muscle—things that bleed when cut, that smell like bodies Clay-formers make crude laborers—durable, slow, expressionless Metal-smiths forge mechanical servants—precise, cold, expensive A crafter typically specializes. Working in multiple materials requires different skills, different tools, different mindsets. The Spark: Blood Materials alone produce nothing but a statue. The homunculus needs life , and that life comes from blood. Creation Cost The crafter bleeds into their creation. Not a nick, not a small cut—a letting . The amount scales with complexity: Simple tool (a fetching hand, a watching eye): A cupful. Dizziness, hunger afterward. Basic servant (follows instructions, performs labor): Several cups. Pale for days, sleeping hard, eating constantly. Soldier construct (built for violence): Enough to leave you bedridden for a week. Some crafters need transfusions. Mimic (passes for human): Crafters have died on the table finishing these, bled out with hands still inside the chest cavity, shaping the last chamber of a heart. The homunculus must be sparked with the crafter's own blood . This is the bond. This is why it serves you and not someone else. Your blood is the signature on the contract.
docs.title: Creation

docs.text: Tethering A completed homunculus can be bound to a token —a small object similar to a Core Binder's anchor. The homunculus was made for this token, crafted with the binding built in from the start. When dormant, the homunculus collapses into the token. Not destroyed—folded. Compressed. Waiting. Where it waits is unclear. Crafters disagree. Some say the homunculus enters a kind of stasis. Others believe it exists in a pocket dimension tied to the token. Others think it simply ceases to exist until summoned, recreated each time from the pattern stored in the binding. Nobody knows for certain. The homunculi don't remember dormancy, or if they do, they can't describe it. Summoning Activate the token, and the homunculus unfolds back into reality. Fast for simple constructs—they snap into existence almost instantly. Slower for complex ones—they need time to become , flesh knitting together, bones locking into place, the body assembling itself from nothing visible. Every summoning costs fresh blood. The homunculus drinks when it wakes. Small ones need a palm-slice and a minute of feeding. Larger ones need significantly more. A crafter summoning a soldier-construct is opening veins, not cutting palms.
docs.title: Conjuring and Tethering

docs.text: Daily Feeding The token drinks too. When you collapse a homunculus back to dormancy, the token takes a drop. Just a drop. Daily maintenance, whether you summon that day or not. Miss a day: The token goes cold, inert. You'll need a full summoning-price to wake it again. Miss a week: The homunculus inside starts to degrade. Patterns corrupting. Miss a month: What comes out when you finally feed it won't be what you put in. A crafter is always bleeding . Six constructs means six drops a day, minimum. Morning ritual: a knife and a row of hungry objects. The Homunculus Doesn't Care Whose Blood It needs the crafter's blood to be made . But once it exists, it can be sustained on anyone's. The temptation is always there: You're tapped out, anemic, exhausted There's a prisoner in the basement There's a beggar who won't be missed There's animal blood available (but it makes constructs sluggish, wrong) Human blood works best Your blood works best of all, but you're running out The Supply Chain Where does the blood come from? Bloodhouses : Places where the desperate sell by the pint. Technically legal in some jurisdictions. The sellers are gaunt, hollow-eyed, always cold. They don't last long. Fresh ones cycle in. Nobody asks where the old ones went. Wartime crafters : Military Flesh Shapers have access to prisoners, wounded enemies, civilians in occupied territory. A soldier-construct requires a lot of fuel. The supply chain gets dark fast. The black market : Blood dealers who don't ask questions about sourcing. The Homunculus Knows It can smell blood. It can tell the difference between: Willing and unwilling Healthy and sick Its maker and a stranger Fear-blood and calm-blood Some crafters swear their constructs behave differently depending on what they've been fed: More vicious on fear-blood Sluggish on the blood of the drugged Eager when they've tasted someone they'll meet again
docs.title: Upkeep: The Blood Economy

docs.text: Physical Markers Pale. Always. The healthy glow is for people who keep their blood inside. Hungry. Constantly eating, body trying to rebuild what they keep giving away. They're thin despite the meals. Track marks. The crook of the elbow, the wrist, anywhere veins are easy to reach. Old scars and fresh wounds. Behavioral Changes Territorial about blood. Other people's injuries make them attentive in uncomfortable ways. A nosebleed at dinner and every crafter in the room goes still for a second. They know things about blood they shouldn't. Can tell by smell if someone's sick. Can taste pregnancy, disease, fear. The knowledge seeps in. Occupational hazard. The Long-Term Cost The old ones are brittle. Bones thin. Healing slow. They've given too much for too long. Some switch to "volunteers" early, preserving themselves at the cost of others. Some hold out until their body forces the choice. Some just... stop making the choice and let a construct drink the last of them. A Flesh Shaper who's been practicing for decades is a medical wreck held together by stubbornness and careful feeding schedules.
docs.title: What This Does to Crafters

docs.text: Tools Simple, single-purpose. A hand that fetches. A mouth that repeats messages. An eye that watches. Barely present—more automation than entity. Cheap to make, cheap to maintain. Every crafter has a few. Servants More complex. Can follow multi-step instructions, adapt to obstacles, perform labor. They have enough presence to seem almost like people, though nobody's fooled up close. The backbone of any serious crafter's stable. Soldiers Built for violence. Expensive in materials and spark—a soldier-construct might represent months of work and enough blood loss to hospitalize the crafter. They degrade faster than other types. Combat tears them up, and they don't heal—they have to be repaired . Field repairs are crude. Proper maintenance requires a workshop, materials, and more blood. Mimics The dangerous ones. Built to pass as human. Built to fool people who know what homunculi look like. Built, sometimes, to impersonate a specific person. Requirements: Exceptional skill Massive vitality investment Often a core fragment from someone who knew how to be a person (burned in the creation, not bound—but the traces remain) Mimics are assassins' tools. Spies. Replacements. Most societies ban them outright. Crafters who build them are either very powerful, very well-protected, or very desperate.
docs.title: Hierarchy of Constructs

docs.text: What They Want They're made to serve. They don't want things the way people do. Except blood. Blood is the one drive that's built in, inescapable. A well-fed homunculus is loyal, precise, obedient. A hungry one gets creative about fulfilling its primary need. Neglected Constructs What happens when a homunculus isn't fed properly: Returns to dormancy on its own, drinking the token to survive Stands very still near sleeping people "Accidentally" causes injuries during tasks Simply attacks, if starved long enough This isn't rebellion. It isn't malice. It's just need —the only need they have—expressing itself when the leash gets loose. Do They Have Experiences? Complex homunculi exhibit preferences, aversions, something that looks like pain when damaged. They respond to stimuli in ways that suggest inner states. But they never lived. They have no history, no childhood, no formation. Whatever they experience, it's not the same as what people experience. Is it real? Does it matter if it acts real? Crafters disagree. Some treat their constructs as tools. Some treat them as servants. A few treat them almost as children—made things that deserve consideration despite their origins. The homunculi themselves don't seem to have opinions on the matter. Or if they do, they don't share them.
docs.title: The Homunculus Perspective

docs.text: What Does Flesh Shaping Exploit? The crafter : Every homunculus costs a piece of you. Noble self-sacrifice or slow suicide dressed as craft? The materials : Where do you get the flesh? The bone? Flesh Shapers haunt graveyards, battlefields, slaughterhouses. They make deals with executioners. They show up after disasters with empty carts. The blood supply : When your blood runs low, whose do you use? The ethics get murky fast. The homunculi : Do they deserve consideration? They experience something. They can suffer, or at least they act like they can. Does their artificial origin excuse how we treat them? The crafter who says "it's just a construct" sounds a lot like the binder who says "it's just an echo." The rationalization is different. The function is the same.
docs.title: Moral Angle

docs.text: How Other Practitioners See Them Core Binders view Flesh Shapers as butchers playing with corpse-meat. "At least we work with what was . You're just... building things out of scraps." Pact Summoners don't understand why anyone would work so hard when you could just make a deal. Fate Threaders see them as limited—"You can only make what you can build." Colony Summoners and Flesh Shapers have professional overlap. Some respect. Some rivalry. Similar materials, different methods. Public Perception Flesh Shapers are openly unsettling. Their workshops smell like death. Everyone knows where the materials come from. In some places, they're tolerated as necessary—military applications, dangerous labor, tasks nobody else will do. In others, they're shunned. The craft is legal but shameful. You hire one when you need one, and you don't invite them to dinner. Legal Status Regulation focuses on the crafter , not the product: Licensing requirements Restrictions on mimic construction Blood sourcing laws (where they exist) Limits on military applications The homunculus itself isn't a citizen, was never a citizen, can't become a citizen. It's property. What happens to it is the crafter's business, as long as the crafter follows the rules.
docs.title: Opposition and Social Position

docs.text: The Art of Dealing with the Outside
docs.title: Pact Summoning

docs.text: Somewhere adjacent to reality, things exist. Not dead things—Core Binding covers the dead. Not made things—Flesh Shaping builds those. These are entities that are , fully and independently, in a place that isn't here. The Elsewhere is what practitioners call that place. The entities there have their own drives, their own intelligence, their own agendas. For reasons nobody fully understands, some of them are willing to answer when called. Pact Summoning is negotiation. Unlike the other Arts, you're not in control. You're making a deal with something that has its own reasons for saying yes.
docs.title: Fundamental Principle

docs.text: What It Is Mystery is load-bearing here. The Elsewhere isn't mapped, isn't understood, isn't safe to investigate. What's known: It's not an afterlife. The dead don't go there. Cores don't come from there. It's not a spirit world. It's not a reflection of our reality. It's somewhere genuinely alien. Time works differently. Entities reference events that haven't happened yet. They remember pacts made with summoners' ancestors—ancestors who haven't made those pacts yet, by our timeline. Space is wrong. The few descriptions from people who claim to have glimpsed it are contradictory. Too many angles. Colors that hurt. Distance that doesn't correlate with movement. The entities there aren't gods. Aren't demons in a religious sense. Aren't faeries in a folkloric sense. Different cultures use all those words, but none of them are accurate. They're other . Intelligences that evolved—if "evolved" means anything there—in a place with different rules than ours. Why They Answer Unknown. Theories: They want something from our world that they can't get otherwise Our reality is entertainment, or food, or raw material They're curious They're compelled by the calling ritual (unlikely—they can choose not to respond) Different entities have different reasons The uncertainty is part of the horror. You're dealing with something, and you don't know why it's dealing with you.
docs.title: The Elsewhere

docs.text: Formation Making a pact requires contact: Rituals : Specific words, gestures, offerings that attract attention from the Elsewhere Thin places : Locations where the boundary between here and there is weak Resonant objects : Items that have been touched by Elsewhere influence, that carry traces of prior contact Bloodlines : Families that have dealt before. The connection persists across generations. The entities remember. The entity chooses whether to engage. You can call. It doesn't have to answer. Some calls go unanswered for years. Some are answered immediately. Some are answered by something other than what you were trying to reach. Negotiation Pact terms are negotiated. Both parties bring something to the table. The entity is at least as intelligent as you. Probably more intelligent. Certainly more experienced—it's been doing this longer than your civilization has existed. The pact, once formed, binds both sides. Break it and there are consequences. For you. Possibly for the entity too, which is why they're careful about terms. The Price Is You The entity wants your core . The same thing a Core Binder would harvest from your corpse. But the Elsewhere entity takes it in installments. Every summoning. Every use of the pact's power. Every favor called in. Each one costs a piece of you. You feel it: A coldness that doesn't warm Fatigue that sleep doesn't fix The sense that you're less than you were yesterday, in a way you can't name The Honest Horror Pact entities are honest. That's part of what makes them terrifying. No tricks. No hidden clauses. No surprises. The entity tells you exactly what's going to happen: I will eat you, slowly, and in exchange you get this. And people say yes anyway.
docs.title: The Pact

docs.text: Why Would Anyone Agree? Power now, death later. For someone with nothing, that's a trade worth making. You get decades of capability in exchange for a shorter life. If your life was going to be short and powerless anyway, this is an upgrade. The timeline is negotiable. Small pacts, small bites. Use the power sparingly, and you might get decades before the debt comes due. Use it constantly, and you might have months. Some people don't plan to live long anyway. Soldiers. Assassins. The terminally ill. The suicidal. The entity offers a way to matter before the end. Arrogance. The belief that you'll find a way out. That you're smarter than everyone who came before. That you'll be the one to beat the system. You won't be. But you'll believe it until you don't.
docs.title: The Math of Desperation

docs.text: You Can Pay with Other People's Souls You can only offer your own core to one entity. That's your primary pact. But you can offset your debt by providing other cores. The entity doesn't care whose core it gets. A core is a core. But you have to deliver . Classic Arrangements First-born clauses : The child isn't born yet. You're mortgaging a future you can't see. By the time the debt comes due, you've had years to love what you promised away. Seventh son of a seventh son : Rare cores are worth more. One exceptional soul might buy you years off your own debt. Designated sacrifices : Prisoners. Slaves. The defeated. If you can deliver someone's core to the entity, it counts. How you get it is your problem. Secondary Markets This creates economies within economies: Pact summoners hunting for substitutes Cults breeding or kidnapping to pay their founders' debts Wars fought partly to generate currency for Elsewhere transactions Noble families trading heirs' futures for political advantage Criminal organizations offering "debt relief" in exchange for services The entities don't judge. They just collect.
docs.title: Substitution

docs.text: You Can't The terms are the terms. You agreed. The entity will collect what it's owed, one way or another. However The entity can die. They're not gods. They're powerful, alien, long-lived—but not immortal. Kill your pact-partner and the contract dissolves. You keep whatever's left of your core. This is rare. Elsewhere entities are hard to find when they don't want to be found. Harder to hurt when they're found. They know they have enemies, and they're careful. But it happens. Some summoners spend their entire lives searching for a way to kill what they owe. - Other entities might help. Faction politics in the Elsewhere mean your creditor's enemies might be willing to deal. You could trade one pact for another. One master for another. Out of the pot, into the fire. - Early collection. If the entity decides you're more trouble than you're worth, it can call the debt due. All of it. At once. You don't survive that. But at least you're not in debt anymore. Evil Genie Escapes It does happen—rarely—that someone wriggles out through a loophole. A technicality. A desperate gambit the entity didn't anticipate. These cases become legends. They're also why entities have gotten very, very good at writing airtight terms over the millennia. If you think you've found a loophole, you probably haven't. The entity has seen your trick before. Usually from someone much smarter than you.
docs.title: Breaking the Pact

docs.text: What Happens When You Call The entity arrives. Not from an anchor, not from a token—it manifests . The transition is visible. Uncomfortable to witness. Air pressure changes Light bends wrong, casting shadows that don't match objects Temperature shifts—sometimes hot, sometimes cold, sometimes both in different parts of the room The smell of somewhere else. No one can describe it. Everyone recognizes it. The Relationship The entity isn't your servant. It's your contractor . It does what the pact specifies. If you negotiated well, that's a lot. If you didn't, it might technically fulfill the letter while violating the spirit. It knows every trick you know, and many you don't. Duration and power depend on pact terms and what you've paid recently. Use the connection sparingly, and you get modest manifestations. Burn through your remaining soul fast, and you can call forth something terrifying. The entity can refuse if you're asking for something outside the agreement. It can renegotiate. It can leave if the terms allow. You're not its master. You're its customer. There's a difference.
docs.title: The Summoning

docs.text: It Varies Appearance depends on faction, individual nature, and possibly what your mind can process: Geometric : Wrong angles. Shapes that fold in directions that don't exist. Looking at them too long makes your eyes water. Almost biological : Too many limbs. Limbs that aren't limbs. A face close enough to human to be worse than something completely alien. Sensory rather than visual : A sound that has location. A pressure that has opinions. A smell that watches you. Changing : Different every time you see them. Or exactly the same, down to the shadow, no matter the lighting. Summoners in the same faction's service sometimes recognize each other's patrons. Like spotting a uniform. Or a brand.
docs.title: What They Look Like

docs.text: You're in Contact with the Outside You're not just paying with your core. The connection itself marks you. Manifestations Perception shifts : The boundary thins for you. You see cracks in reality where others see solid walls. Glimpses of Elsewhere bleeding through at odd moments. Dreams that aren't dreams. Resonance : Other entities notice you. You're marked as someone who deals. Some are curious. Some are hungry. Some are your patron's enemies, looking for leverage. Faction drift : Your patron's nature echoes in you. Not memories like Core Binding's bleed— tendencies . You start wanting what they want. Valuing what they value. The longer the pact, the more you serve their interests without being asked. The door : If you've given access as part of your terms, you're not always sure when it's open. Gaps in your memory. Actions you don't remember taking. The question of who's driving.
docs.title: Contamination

docs.text: When Your Core Is Gone When a summoner's debt is fully collected: The body is still there. The soul is gone. What remains varies: A husk that breathes, blinks, maybe eats if you put food in its mouth. But nobody's home. Or something's moved in . The entity, or a piece of it, using the empty vessel. Looking out through human eyes. Or the body just stops. Heart keeps beating for a while, then doesn't. No violence, no unusual decay. Just vacancy, then nothing. Different factions leave different remains: The Hungry leave bodies that look starved —not thin, just emptied The Mirrors leave bodies that don't move right anymore, like something's trying to remember how limbs work The Absent leave bodies that are simply... gone. There one moment, not there the next. No one sees them leave.
docs.title: The Consumed

docs.text: The entities aren't unified. They have allegiances, rivalries, territories. The politics are opaque to humans—we catch glimpses. Wars referenced obliquely. Names spoken with something like fear. Requests that clearly serve some larger game. The full picture is never given. You're a pawn who doesn't know the board.
docs.title: The Elsewhere Factions

docs.text: What They Want : Order Not justice. Not fairness. Ledgers that balance. Every debt paid. Every promise kept. Every exchange recorded. They invented the pact structure. The contract format. The terms and conditions. Other factions adopted their framework because it works. Characteristics They don't care what you do with the power. They care that the price is paid on time. Their summoners tend toward obsessive record-keeping. Counting things. Needing symmetry. Uncomfortable when anything is unbalanced. They might be the "safest" to deal with—predictable, honorable in their way. But their honor is the honor of a loan shark. Miss a payment and they take what's owed, plus interest. What They're Really After Unknown. Possibly they're building something. A structure. A pattern. Every soul a brick in a wall no one can see.
docs.title: The Accountants

docs.text: What They Want : Sensation Our world is dense with feeling—physical, emotional, experiential. The Elsewhere is thin. These entities are starving. Characteristics Pacts often include clauses about experiencing . The summoner has to feel things—intensely—and the entity feeds on it. Their summoners tend toward extremes. Thrill-seekers, hedonists, masochists. People who burn bright because something's drinking the flame. They're generous with power because they're getting paid in real-time. Every time you use the gift, you feel something, and they're right there, mouth open. What They're Really After More. Always more. They might not be collecting souls for any purpose beyond consumption. Just eating . And they're never full.
docs.title: The Hungry

docs.text: What They Want : Change Specific changes. Moves in a game being played across centuries. They give orders that seem arbitrary—stand here, say this, kill him, spare her—and the pattern only becomes visible generations later. Characteristics Their summoners are pieces on a board. Useful, but not privy to the strategy. The contamination is subtle. You start thinking in long timelines. Personal goals feel small. You catch yourself making decisions that serve something larger, and you can't explain why. They might be at war with each other. Or cooperating on something vast. The summoner never knows which. What They're Really After The board to look a certain way. Our world reshaped. Not conquered— adjusted . Every soul they collect might be a piece removed from play.
docs.title: The Architects

docs.text: What They Want : Identity They're fascinated by selfhood—the thing that makes you you and not someone else. They collect cores not as currency but as specimens. Art. Components of something they're building or becoming. Characteristics Pacts often include clauses about access . They want to wear you sometimes. See through your eyes. Make your choices. Not possession exactly—more like borrowing. Their summoners have the worst contamination: identity bleed. Am I me? Was that my thought? When I wanted that, was it me wanting? They might be trying to become something. Using human cores as templates. Building a self out of stolen pieces. What They're Really After To be what we are. Or to understand it. Or to take it apart and see how it works. The souls they collect might be raw material for constructing something that can finally be .
docs.title: The Mirrors

docs.text: What They Want : Nothing That's what makes them terrifying. No demands, no hungers, no apparent agenda. They answer when called. They fulfill their terms. They collect what's owed. They never explain why. Characteristics Pacts with them are simple, clean, almost generous. Which makes experienced summoners deeply suspicious. Their summoners report the least contamination—but also the least contact . The entity does the job and leaves. No presence, no pressure, no bleeding through. What They're Really After The only honest answer is "we don't know." That might be the most dangerous answer of all.
docs.title: The Absent

docs.text: The Accountants vs. The Architects : Most friction. One wants every debt balanced now . The other lets ledgers run for centuries if it serves the plan. The Hungry : Looked down on by the others. Addicts. No sophistication. Just appetite . The Mirrors : Feared. What they're doing with the cores is wrong even by Elsewhere standards. The Absent : Make everyone nervous. You can't predict what you can't understand.
docs.title: Faction Dynamics

docs.text: Unknown. Load-bearing mystery. Hints: The Accountants file them. Somewhere. For something. The Hungry consume them. Gone. Used up. Fuel. The Architects place them. Pieces on a board. Maybe still aware. The Mirrors wear them. Incorporate them. The entity you're dealing with might be partly made of collected cores. The Absent : Nobody knows. Nobody's ever found out.
docs.title: What Happens to Collected Souls

docs.text: Your future spreads ahead of you like roots seeking water. Every significant choice you'll face branches into potential futures. Potential yous . Fate Threading is the art of reaching into those branches and pulling. You grab a version of yourself from a choice you haven't made yet, drag them into the present, and make them real. The cost: that choice is gone. The path closes behind you. You will never become that person naturally—you already extracted them. You're not mining your history. You're cannibalizing your becoming.
docs.title: Fundamental Principle

docs.text: Only Yourself. Only Forward. You can only pull versions of yourself from future fate-lines. No one else. Nothing from the past. No past-branch access. You decided not to become a soldier at eighteen. That soldier-you doesn't exist anymore. The choice was made. The branch collapsed. Only forward potential. You can pull from decisions you will face. The you that takes the job next month. The you that kills the man threatening your family tomorrow. The you that says yes to a proposal you haven't received yet. Always impacting your future. Every pull severs a path you could still walk. The web of your possibilities gets narrower with each extraction.
docs.title: The Core Rule

docs.text: Sensing Fate Threaders can feel their fate-web. Not clearly—more like sensing pressure. Weight. Heavy futures: almost certain, highly probable, rich with consequence Light futures: unlikely, dependent on many contingencies, wispy Close futures: imminent choices, easy to grasp Distant futures: far-off possibilities, harder to reach Pulling You reach forward. Focus on a choice-point. Feel the version of yourself that exists down that path. And pull . The extraction isn't gentle. It feels like tearing something out of yourself—because you are. That potential was part of you. Now it's standing next to you, a separate person. The Closure The path closes behind the pull. That choice-point is spent. When you reach that moment naturally—the job offer, the marriage proposal, the crossroads—the option you pulled from won't exist. You'll have to take a different path, or no path at all.
docs.title: The Mechanism

docs.text: Any version of yourself that could exist based on choices you haven't made yet. Examples Tomorrow you face a duel. You can pull the you who wins—skilled, confident, bloody-handed. (You cannot pull the you who dies. Dead futures contain nothing to extract.) Next year you might take a job with a merchant house. You can pull the you who spent a decade there, learned the trade, made the connections. But then you'll never be able to take that job naturally—the future's already been harvested. You're considering marriage. You can pull the you who said yes, lived that life, raised those children. But if you pull the married-you, you've spent that future. You might still marry her, but it won't be the same. That fate-line is corrupted.
docs.title: What You Can Pull

docs.text: Past branches. You didn't become a soldier. That soldier doesn't exist. Gone forever. Dead futures. If a fate-line ends in your death, there's nothing to extract. Death isn't a version of you. It's the absence of you. Other people. Your fate-web contains connections to others, but you can't pull them . Only yourself. Selves from others' webs. Your brother's potential futures are his. Even if your fates are entangled, you can only pull from your own branches.
docs.title: What You Cannot Pull

docs.text: Youth Is Wealth Young threaders have wide webs. Lots of major choices ahead. Lots of potential selves to pull. Old threaders have narrow webs. Most choices are behind them. Most branches already collapsed through living, not pulling. The Narrowing A threader who pulls aggressively in youth might find themselves at forty with almost no remaining futures. They've spent their potential. What's left is a thin line leading to a handful of possible deaths—and that's it. Every year you live, your web narrows naturally. Every pull accelerates that narrowing. The combination is a countdown.
docs.title: The Brutal Math

docs.text: Aging Each pull costs years. Your body knows you're spending future. Hair grays. Joints ache. Skin thins. Heavy threaders look decades older than their actual age. The body is keeping score, even if the mind tries to ignore it. Coherence You're supposed to become those selves. That's how identity works—you make choices, and you become the person who made them. When you rip them out prematurely, you become less. The sense of who you are gets foggy. Heavy threaders lose track of their own identity—too many versions of themselves walking around, too many futures cashed out early. Some forget their own names. Not amnesia—something stranger. They know they have a name. They just aren't sure which one is theirs and which one belongs to an extraction. Narrowing Web Every pull closes a path. The more you pull, the fewer futures remain. Eventually you're looking at a fate-web that's almost empty. Just the thin line of your remaining lifespan, no branches, no choices that matter, no potential left. This is visible to other threaders. A depleted fate-web looks like a dying tree—sparse, brittle, few leaves. Anchoring Load The extracted selves are tethered to you. You're their origin point, and they need that connection to remain stable. While you live, they're coherent. Pull too many and your anchoring spreads thin. Neglected selves start to degrade—memories corrupting, identity fragmenting. Soft cap: six to ten stable extractions, depending on the threader's strength. Push past that and they start going wrong.
docs.title: The Costs

docs.text: They're you . From a choice you haven't made yet. What They Know They have your memories up to now—the shared past you both lived. Then they have memories of the life they would have lived , down the fate-line you pulled them from. The soldier-you remembers the war you never fought. Knows the friends you never made, the enemies you never killed. The scholar-you remembers the books you never read. Knows the languages you never learned. They know things you don't. Skills you don't have. Experiences you skipped. What They Feel They're you. But they're also not you anymore. Loyal : They understand what you did, why you needed them. They're willing to help because you're the same person, fundamentally. Resentful : They had a life . It wasn't real yet, but it was going to be. You stole it. Collapsed their entire existence into serving the version that got to keep the body. Superior : The king-you looks at present-you and sees a lesser version. Unfinished. Unpolished. Why should he take orders from his own rough draft? Pitying : The happy-you, the peaceful-you, the one who got out—they look at you and see someone still trapped in the mess they escaped. What They Can Do Anything you could do, if you'd made their choices. They have real skills, real knowledge, real capabilities. But they're not summoned tools. They're people . They make their own decisions, have their own opinions, pursue their own goals. You can ask them to help. You can try to convince them. You can't control them.
docs.title: The Extracted Self

docs.text: When they die, that fate-line is destroyed. Not blocked— gone . You will never become that person. That potential is spent and destroyed. Whatever they knew, whatever they could do, is lost. The choice-point they came from? When you reach it naturally, it won't exist as an option anymore. You took it off the table by pulling and losing them. Implications Protecting your extractions matters. They're not disposable. Old threaders are cautious. They've lost extractions before. They know the cost. Suicide as weapon. An extraction that wants to hurt you can do it by dying. Kill themselves, and they take a piece of your future with them. Murder as fate-destruction. If someone kills your extractions, they're not just killing people—they're unmaking your possibilities .
docs.title: Death of an Extracted Self

docs.text: If you die, your extracted selves drift. Memories corrupt over weeks or months Identity fragments. They forget their unlived lives. Eventually they become echoes. Walking, talking, but not coherent. Not quite people anymore. Some extracted selves will do anything to keep you alive. You're not just their origin—you're their coherence. Without you, they dissolve.
docs.title: Your Death

docs.text: You're always eating your future. Every pull means: I will never become that person naturally. I will never walk that path. I will never make that choice and see where it leads. Young threaders have options. Old threaders have regrets. The oldest threaders—the ones who pulled too much—are ghosts before they die. No future left. Just the thin present moment, and the handful of selves they extracted before the well ran dry. And those selves? They know what you did. They know you spent their futures to get their skills, their knowledge, their help. Some forgive you. Some serve you. Some wait.
docs.title: The Horror

The Art of Growing What You've Eaten

docs.text: You carry a fungal colony inside you. It has eaten the dead. It remembers what it consumed. When you summon, you fruit —push the colony's biomass out of your body, shaped by the pattern of something it has previously decomposed. You are the garden. The dead are the seeds. What grows serves you—mostly.
docs.title: Fundamental Principle

docs.text: What It Is A symbiotic fungal organism threaded through your body. Mycelium wrapped around your organs, woven into your muscles, nested in your gut. It's been there since infection—possibly since birth, if your bloodline carries the strain. It's not intelligent. Not exactly. But it remembers . Chemically, structurally. Every dead thing it has ever broken down is stored as a pattern, a template, a set of instructions for reconstruction. How You Get One Three paths: Inheritance : Some bloodlines have carried colonies for generations. The fungus passes from parent to child—in the womb, through nursing, through deliberate ritual feeding. These colonies are old, rich with patterns, heavy with the dead of your ancestors. Implantation : Deliberate infection. Consume a prepared culture. Inhale spores from an established host. Let someone cut you and pack the wound with living mycelium. The colony takes root over weeks—painful weeks, as it learns your body and you learn its hunger. Wild infection : Rare and dangerous. Wild strains aren't adapted to human hosts. They might consume you instead of partnering. But they also haven't been domesticated, limited, bred for obedience. Wild hosts are unstable and powerful. The Relationship You and the colony aren't one being. You're partners—sometimes cooperative, sometimes competing. Communication : Chemical, not verbal. You feel what it needs. Hunger. Satiation. Readiness. Reluctance. Over time you learn to interpret its states, and it learns yours. Negotiation : It wants to be fed. It wants to fruit. It wants to spread. Satisfy those drives and it cooperates fully. Deny them and it starts taking what it needs. Conflict : You can suppress the colony. Starve it, deny it, fight its urges. This is painful for both. Long-term suppression can damage the colony—or you.
docs.title: The Colony

docs.text: The Core Rule The colony can only summon what it has consumed. No pattern, no summon. The Consumption Process Feed the colony dead things. Corpses, carcasses, any organic matter that was once alive. The colony breaks it down over hours to days, depending on size. A rat takes hours. A human takes days. A horse takes a week. During decomposition, the colony absorbs the pattern —the biological blueprint. The physical matter is processed into nutrients. You benefit from this. Hosts who feed their colonies regularly need less food otherwise. What You Can Feed It Animals : Common, easy, socially acceptable (mostly). A well-maintained colony has consumed dozens of creatures. Humans : Richer patterns, more useful for complex summons. Also murder, or at minimum corpse acquisition. Other hosts : A colony that consumes another colony gains its patterns. This is how strains merge, compete, and evolve. It's also how wars between hosts end. Parts : You don't need the whole thing. A hand gives you a hand-pattern. A heart gives you a heart. Useful for specialists. Storage Limits The colony can only hold so many patterns clearly. Old patterns degrade. Recent consumption (weeks): clear patterns, high-fidelity summons Older consumption (months): degraded patterns, approximate summons Ancient consumption (years): fragmentary patterns, partial summons Hosts who want to keep a pattern fresh have to re-feed periodically. Kill another one of the same thing. Refresh the template.
docs.title: Feeding the Colony

docs.text: The Process You call a pattern. Will it, focus on it, reach into the colony's memory. The colony responds—if willing, if it has the pattern, if you have the biomass. Fruiting begins. Mycelium pushes outward through skin, mouth, wounds. Uncomfortable to agonizing depending on size. The biomass shapes itself according to the stored pattern. The summon separates. Stands, moves, exists as an independent organism—connected to you, but physically distinct. What Comes Out A fungal reconstruction of whatever the colony consumed. Shape of the original. Structure. Proportions. Approximate capabilities. A summoned wolf can run and bite. A summoned soldier can fight. No original mind. The colony's impression of behavior, filtered through chemical memory. Looks wrong . Fibrous flesh. Pale or mottled coloring. No blood—cut it and it leaks clear fluid. Faces that approximate features without achieving them. The Tether The summon remains connected. You sense what it senses, dimly. It follows your intentions, mostly. Colony drives lurk underneath. Distance matters. Close summons are responsive. Distant ones get autonomous. Severed tether doesn't vanish the summon—it just stops being yours .
docs.title: The Summoning (Fruiting)

docs.text: Biomass The summon is made from you . Small summons: a meal's worth. Hungry, lightheaded afterward. Medium summons: several meals. Gaunt, shaky. Large summons: dangerous. Pulling from muscle, reserves, things you need. Multiple summons: multiplicative cost. Recovery After dismissing or reabsorbing: Eating. A lot. Protein, fat, minerals. Time. Days for large summons. The colony's cut. Not everything comes back. Long-term summoners are lighter than they should be. The Colony's Demands When it's not satisfied: Hunger : Craving dead things. Compulsion to seek corpses. Fruiting pressure : The need to externalize. Suppress too long and it might fruit involuntarily. Spread drive : The colony wants new hosts. You start noticing people as candidates .
docs.title: The Costs

docs.text: Reabsorption Pull the biomass back in. Reverse fruiting. Recovers some of what you spent. Uncomfortable. Something crawling back inside. Takes time. Minutes to longer. Damaged summons bring damage back with them. Decomposition If you won't reabsorb: Fast breakdown. Hours. Messy. Collapses into fungal matter. Wasteful. No biomass recovery. Abandonment Leave a summon active indefinitely: It feeds itself. Hunting, scavenging. It might grow. Add biomass. It might reproduce. Spread spores. It stops being yours. Feral.
docs.title: Reabsorption and Dismissal

docs.text: Physical Signs Pale or grayish undertone. Mycelium shows through. Faint patterning visible in certain light. Run cool. The colony takes heat. Smell of loam, petrichor, hint of decay. Eyes develop cloudiness over time. Behavioral Signs Constant eating. Protein and fat. Stay thin despite it. Drawn to dead things. Notice corpses. Have to resist acquiring. Touch people differently. Assessing. The colony is interested in new hosts. The Old Ones Decades of hosting: More mycelium than meat. Don't think quite like humans. Colony priorities seeped in. Some stop being human-shaped between summonings. Framework for fruiting.

docs.text: Core Binding + Pact Summoning If a pact summoner dies, is there a core to harvest? Depends on how much is left. A summoner who's been paying for decades might leave a core so thin it's barely usable. Or nothing at all. Duds—empty, immediately gone upon death. Or the core is pulled to the Elsewhere. Something happens to it there. This might be the thing we don't understand. Flesh Shaping + Pact Summoning Could you spark a homunculus with a pact summoner's diminished core? What would that create? Would the entity still have a claim? Elsewhere Entities + Core Binding The entities have no cores. They're from outside. The rules of death here don't apply. You can't bind one. Can't harvest one. They're outside the economy that governs everything else. That's part of why they're dangerous. Fate Threading + Other Arts Can you pull a version of yourself that practiced a different Art? Yes. And they'd come with the knowledge and corruption of that practice. The Flesh Shaper-you is pale and hungry. The Core Binder-you has echoes bleeding into them. The Pact Summoner-you might still owe something to an entity. Colony + Core Binding Can a colony consume a practitioner and gain something from their practice? Unknown. Colonies gain patterns, not abilities. But a Flesh Shaper's pattern might include something about blood-affinity. A Core Binder's pattern might include traces of their echoes. The interactions haven't been thoroughly explored. They're dangerous to test.
docs.title: Can Systems Combine?

docs.text: Every Art in Hálcova operates on the same principle: You must spend something real to gain something real. The currency varies: The dead and your sense of self (Core Binding) Blood and your humanity (Flesh Shaping) Your soul in installments (Pact Summoning) Your future possibilities (Fate Threading) Your body and autonomy (Colony Summoning) But the transaction is always the same. Power has a price. The universe keeps ledgers. The debt always comes due. Welcome to Hálcova. The world between deaths. The place where everything is owed. Document compiled for worldbuilding reference. Conlang terminology to be developed and integrated.
docs.title: The Universal Truth

docs.text: Hálcova: Additional Magical and Technical Systems Overview Beyond the Five Arts, Hálcova has developed additional practices that interact with its metaphysical substrate. These range from applied sciences to dark practices to institutional technologies. All operate within the economic-psychological framework that defines reality here. Behavioral Alchemy Core Mechanism Systematically manipulating incentive structures to produce predictable behavioral outcomes. Nature This is not magic in the traditional sense. It's applied economics. But in Hálcova, where economic principles are metaphysically real, sophisticated incentive design can produce effects that look like magic. Practices Market Architecture Creating transaction structures that align self-interest with desired outcomes. A skilled architect can design situations where people choose what you want them to choose without coercion or deception. Example : Structuring a labor contract so that the worker's best response to every contingency is the response you want. They're not forced—they're incentivized. They don't resent you—they thank you for the opportunity. Commitment Devices Binding future-you to current-you's preferences. Pattern-enforceable contracts. Reputation systems that make defection visible. Example : "You must do this, and you will want to, because the alternative is structured to be worse." The subject creates their own prison and holds their own key—but never wants to use it. Information Management Controlling what's known, by whom, when. Creating asymmetries that advantage you. Revealing information strategically to shape decisions. Example : Letting someone "discover" information you planted, so they believe they have an advantage when they're actually playing your game. Why This Is Dangerous Behavioral alchemy works on anyone . Pacts require consent. Binding requires death. Flesh shaping requires material. Fate Threading only works on yourself. But behavioral alchemy just requires understanding incentives—and everyone has incentives. Practitioners Merchant houses specializing in contract design Loom-adjacent institutions managing information flow Political operatives structuring choices Criminal organizations manipulating markets Cost No inherent magical cost—this is skill, not Art. But: - Sophisticated targets recognize manipulation attempts - Failed manipulation creates enemies - Reputation effects limit repeated use - The Loom may predict your manipulation (information asymmetry cuts both ways) Residue Engineering Core Mechanism Processing Pattern Residue into useful forms beyond simple heat release. Categories Refined Residue (Fuel Grade) Standard processed Residue for furnaces and heat. Removes impurities, standardizes energy content. The coal of Hálcova. Properties : Burns steadily, predictable output, minimal side effects Applications : Heating, cooking, basic industry Trade Value : Base commodity, high volume, moderate margins Crystallized Residue (Storage Grade) Residue processed into stable solid form. Stores energy for extended periods. Properties : Compact, stable, long shelf life, requires activation to release Applications : Portable power, batteries, emergency reserves, wealth storage Trade Value : Premium commodity, lower volume, high margins Liquid Residue (Transfer Grade) Residue in suspension, movable through pipes and channels. Properties : Flows, can be pressurized, enables distributed systems Applications : City heating networks, industrial processes, magitech fluid systems Trade Value : Infrastructure commodity, requires delivery systems Residue Circuits (Information Grade) Processed to carry pattern-information rather than just heat. Properties : Can store and transmit pattern-data, interfaces with Loom-engines Applications : Loom nodes, communication systems, calculation devices Trade Value : Specialty commodity, highly regulated, enormous margins Residue Weapons (Destruction Grade) Processed for rapid energy release. Properties : Burns hotter than normal, hard to extinguish, damages pattern-integrity of living targets Applications : Military, execution, industrial destruction Trade Value : Restricted commodity, black market premium The Refinement Problem Processing Residue requires: - Heat (often from burning cruder Residue) - Alchemical catalysts - Specialized equipment - Skilled labor - Time Higher grades are more valuable but costlier to produce. This creates: - Vertical integration (controlling harvest through refinement) - Arbitrage opportunities (buy crude, sell refined) - Quality certification problems (how do you verify grade?) - Black markets (unregulated refinement, stolen Residue) Pattern Interference Core Mechanism Directly manipulating someone's Sórscad without their consent. Status Possibly mythical. Possibly real and hidden. The uncertainty is deliberate. Theory The Loom reads patterns. But reading requires interaction. The Loom-engines that read patterns could theoretically write to them. This is: - Heretical (patterns are sacred) - Dangerous (pattern corruption can cascade) - Possibly impossible (maybe the Loom only reads) - Possibly already happening (maybe someone has write access) Theoretical Methods Overlay Adding elements to someone's pattern without removing originals. Creating new layers that interfere with prediction. Making someone "illegible." Hypothetical Effect : Target becomes unpredictable. Loom readings return noise. Wardens can't track them. Hypothetical Cost : The overlay may be unstable. The pattern may reject it. The subject may experience cognitive fragmentation. Erasure Removing pattern elements. Destroying parts of someone's fate. Hypothetical Effect : Target loses aspects of themselves. Memories, capabilities, personality traits associated with erased elements. Hypothetical Cost : What happens to someone with incomplete pattern? Do they still exist? Are they still human? Substitution Replacing one pattern element with another. Changing someone's predicted trajectory. Hypothetical Effect : Target's fate changes. Or does it? Does this change their actual future or just the prediction? Hypothetical Cost : The substituted element came from somewhere. Someone else's pattern was harvested. Merger Combining patterns from multiple people. Creating composite fates. Hypothetical Effect : Hybrid individuals. Shared destinies. The basis of certain binding practices—and possibly the origin of the Colony symbiosis. Hypothetical Cost : Which identity survives? Whose pattern dominates? What happens when merged patterns conflict? Why It's Not Widespread If possible : - The Warden Order hunts practitioners with extreme prejudice - Pattern integrity is economically valued (damaged patterns = unemployable) - The Attendance may resist (or may enable for its own reasons) - Effects are unpredictable If impossible : - Rumors persist for social/political reasons - Provides convenient explanation for unexpected outcomes - Keeps the Warden Order necessary - Justifies Loom authority The Horror Nobody knows which situation is true. The uncertainty itself shapes behavior. Echo Architecture Core Mechanism Creating structures of echoes that interact, beyond simple single-echo binding. Practices Echo Networks Multiple bound echoes coordinated for shared purpose. Example : A research institution binds generations of scholars, creating a persistent intellectual tradition that survives individual death. New researchers can query the network. The network accumulates knowledge. Problem : Network consensus may ossify. The dead outvote the living. Innovation becomes heresy. Echo Hierarchies Binding the echo of someone who was themselves a binder. Creating chains of reference. Example : You bind a master binder's echo. That echo knows how to bind, and remembers their own echoes. You gain access to a lineage of knowledge—the original person's knowledge, plus their echo's knowledge, plus their echo's echo's knowledge. Problem : Hierarchies degrade. Each level is a copy of a copy. The deepest echoes are unreliable. But which level do you trust? Echo Consensus Using multiple echoes' perspectives to approximate truth. Example : If three independent echoes agree on a fact, it's probably accurate. Courts use majority-of-echoes testimony for historical disputes. Institutions use echo consensus for decisions that outlive any individual. Problem : Echoes can be wrong in the same ways. If all three witnesses to an event believed the same lie, their echoes will repeat it. Consensus isn't truth. The Degradation Problem Echoes degrade over time: - Memory becomes selective - Personality becomes caricature - Knowledge becomes outdated - Connection becomes strain Echo architectures must manage: - Redundancy (multiple echoes with overlapping knowledge) - Refresh (binding new echoes to replace degraded ones) - Integration (new echoes must be compatible with existing network) Emergent Properties Long-standing echo institutions develop emergent properties. The network of echoes may develop goals that none of the individual echoes hold. Institutional will arising from pattern-interaction between the bound dead. Some institutions: - Have been running for centuries - Have thousands of echoes integrated - Display collective behavior no one designed - May no longer serve their original purpose - May not be controllable by the living Colony Engineering Core Mechanism Deliberately shaping colonies for specific purposes, beyond simple hosting. Practices Strain Development Cultivating colony variants with desired properties. Goals : - Warmth without aggression - Integration without identity loss - Fruiting without corpse-feeding - Enhanced strength without transformation Methods : - Selective cultivation over generations - Controlled feeding (what you feed a colony shapes what it becomes) - Environmental manipulation (temperature, humidity, Residue concentration) - Hybridization between strains Architectural Integration Building colonies into structures. Applications : - Walls that regulate temperature - Foundations that process waste - Buildings that grow and repair - Structures that respond to inhabitant needs Problems : - Integrated colonies still want to spread - Structures may develop preferences - Maintenance requires feeding - Removal is destructive Medical Application Controlled colony hosting for therapeutic purposes. Applications : - Colonies that eat tumors - Colonies that enhance healing - Colonies that regulate body chemistry - Colonies that extend life Problems : - Therapeutic colonies still integrate - "Controlled" is relative - Long-term effects unknown - Patients may prefer the colony to their original state The Dependency Problem Colonies want to spread. Engineering them for specific purposes: - Constrains their natural drives - Requires ongoing intervention - Creates escape risks (what if the engineered strain gets out?) - May produce backlash (colonies resisting modification) The Vent Lands Specialty Geothermal conditions favor colony cultivation: - Stable warmth year-round - Diverse fungal biodiversity - Experimental traditions - Distance from Orthodox suppression The Vent Lands' colony engineering is the most advanced, most dangerous, and most commercially valuable on Hálcova. They export: - Engineered strains - Cultivation expertise - Architectural colonies - Medical hosting services They keep for themselves: - The most advanced strains - Military applications - The oldest, most integrated structures - Whatever they're really doing in the deep thermal zones Prediction Markets Core Mechanism Markets that aggregate information about future events through price discovery. Function The Loom predicts, but its predictions aren't publicly available in real-time. Prediction markets fill the gap: - Anyone can bet on future outcomes - Prices reflect aggregate expectations - Profit incentivizes accurate information - Markets may outperform Loom-predictions (aggregating distributed knowledge) Market Types Event Markets Will X happen by date Y? Examples : Will the war end by Láng? Will the harvest exceed last year? Will the prince marry before Köd? Trajectory Markets What path will situation X follow? Examples : Will the plague spread north or south? Will prices rise or fall? Will the treaty hold or break? Pattern Markets How will person X's pattern express? Examples : Will the merchant succeed or fail? Will the politician keep their position? Will the criminal reoffend? The Tensions Market vs. Loom When prediction markets diverge from Loom-predictions, which is correct? - Markets aggregate current information; Loom sees pattern-determined trajectories - Divergence might indicate: Loom error, market manipulation, fundamental uncertainty, or impending deviation Self-Fulfilling Prophecy Prices affect behavior. If the market predicts a business fails, investors flee, causing failure. The prediction market creates the outcome it predicts—but differently than the Loom does. Information Arbitrage Those with Loom-access can trade on privileged information. Those without access are disadvantaged. The market is structurally unfair—but may still be informative. The Horror Markets that predict deaths. Markets that predict pattern changes. Markets that predict deviations. The financial incentive to be right about tragedy. Some traders: - Profit from disasters they predicted - May have caused the disasters they predicted - Can't be distinguished from lucky vs. criminal - Create incentives for information that shouldn't exist Magitech Integration How Residue Powers Technology Basic Principle Pattern Residue stores energy. Releasing that energy can do work. The engineering challenge is controlling the release. Control Mechanisms Throttling : Restricting flow rate of Residue to the release point. More Residue = more power, but also more heat, more waste, more danger. Catalysis : Using alchemical compounds to lower the activation energy for release. Different catalysts produce different release profiles (fast, slow, sustained, pulsed). Circuitry : Channeling released energy through constructed pathways. Residue circuits can direct energy to specific functions. Feedback : Systems that adjust Residue flow based on output. Primitive automation. Common Magitech Devices Residue Furnaces Basic heat production. Feed Residue, get warmth. Scaled from personal hand-warmers to city-heating installations. Pattern Readers Loom-derived devices that interface with Sórscad. Range from simple identity verification to full diagnostic reading. All require Information Grade Residue. Communication Arrays Long-distance information transfer using Residue-powered signal propagation. Faster than messengers, expensive to operate. Calculation Engines Mechanical/alchemical computers that process pattern-data. The basis of Loom nodes. Extremely expensive, heavily regulated. Transportation Residue-heated vehicles for ice travel. Residue-powered ships for ocean crossing. No flying vehicles (Residue doesn't defeat gravity, just provides energy). Weapons Residue-heated blades (stay warm, prevent ice-up) Residue projectors (spray burning Residue) Pattern disruptors (theoretically; military secret if they exist) Limitations No Free Lunch Every magitech device requires: - Residue supply (ongoing cost) - Maintenance (parts wear out) - Skilled operators (training required) - Heat management (released energy goes somewhere) No Perpetual Motion You can't get more energy out than you put in. Residue is efficient storage, not creation. No Pattern Creation Magitech can read, store, and transmit pattern information. It cannot create genuine patterns. Homunculi remain pattern-less. Artificial life is not achievable through engineering. No Elsewhere Protection Magitech doesn't inherently protect against Elsewhere influence. During Köd, devices may malfunction. Entities may interfere with readings. The Attendance processes information; it's not blocked by insulation. Summary: The Extended Toolkit System Type What It Does Key Limitation Behavioral Alchemy Applied Science Shapes choices through incentives Targets may recognize manipulation Residue Engineering Processing Creates specialized Residue forms Higher grades require more death Pattern Interference Dark Art (?) Modifies Sórscad directly May not exist; heavily prosecuted Echo Architecture Extended Binding Creates persistent dead-networks Emergent behavior, degradation Colony Engineering Applied Biology Shapes colonies for purpose Colonies resist control Prediction Markets Institution Aggregates future information Self-fulfilling, exploitable Magitech Engineering Applies Residue to mechanical work Requires Residue supply, can't create patterns Further documentation needed on: Specific magitech devices, prediction market regulation, colony strain catalog, echo institution examples, behavioral alchemy case studies

docs.text: Market vs. Loom When prediction markets diverge from Loom-predictions, which is correct? - Markets aggregate current information; Loom sees pattern-determined trajectories - Divergence might indicate: Loom error, market manipulation, fundamental uncertainty, or impending deviation Self-Fulfilling Prophecy Prices affect behavior. If the market predicts a business fails, investors flee, causing failure. The prediction market creates the outcome it predicts—but differently than the Loom does. Information Arbitrage Those with Loom-access can trade on privileged information. Those without access are disadvantaged. The market is structurally unfair—but may still be informative.
docs.title: The Tensions

docs.text: Markets that predict deaths. Markets that predict pattern changes. Markets that predict deviations. The financial incentive to be right about tragedy. Some traders: - Profit from disasters they predicted - May have caused the disasters they predicted - Can't be distinguished from lucky vs. criminal - Create incentives for information that shouldn't exist
docs.title: The Horror

docs.text: Basic Principle Pattern Residue stores energy. Releasing that energy can do work. The engineering challenge is controlling the release. Control Mechanisms Throttling : Restricting flow rate of Residue to the release point. More Residue = more power, but also more heat, more waste, more danger. Catalysis : Using alchemical compounds to lower the activation energy for release. Different catalysts produce different release profiles (fast, slow, sustained, pulsed). Circuitry : Channeling released energy through constructed pathways. Residue circuits can direct energy to specific functions. Feedback : Systems that adjust Residue flow based on output. Primitive automation.
docs.title: How Residue Powers Technology

docs.text: Residue Furnaces Basic heat production. Feed Residue, get warmth. Scaled from personal hand-warmers to city-heating installations. Pattern Readers Loom-derived devices that interface with Sórscad. Range from simple identity verification to full diagnostic reading. All require Information Grade Residue. Communication Arrays Long-distance information transfer using Residue-powered signal propagation. Faster than messengers, expensive to operate. Calculation Engines Mechanical/alchemical computers that process pattern-data. The basis of Loom nodes. Extremely expensive, heavily regulated. Transportation Residue-heated vehicles for ice travel. Residue-powered ships for ocean crossing. No flying vehicles (Residue doesn't defeat gravity, just provides energy). Weapons Residue-heated blades (stay warm, prevent ice-up) Residue projectors (spray burning Residue) Pattern disruptors (theoretically; military secret if they exist)
docs.title: Common Magitech Devices

docs.text: No Free Lunch Every magitech device requires: - Residue supply (ongoing cost) - Maintenance (parts wear out) - Skilled operators (training required) - Heat management (released energy goes somewhere) No Perpetual Motion You can't get more energy out than you put in. Residue is efficient storage, not creation. No Pattern Creation Magitech can read, store, and transmit pattern information. It cannot create genuine patterns. Homunculi remain pattern-less. Artificial life is not achievable through engineering. No Elsewhere Protection Magitech doesn't inherently protect against Elsewhere influence. During Köd, devices may malfunction. Entities may interfere with readings. The Attendance processes information; it's not blocked by insulation.
