docs.text: Hálcova: Historical Climate and the Cooling Event Overview Hálcova was not always frozen. Evidence from multiple sources—geological, archaeological, biological—confirms that the planet was significantly warmer in the deep past. Something changed. Understanding what happened, when, and why is one of the great mysteries of Hálcovan scholarship. Evidence for a Warmer Past Geological Evidence Fossil Flora : - Deep rock strata contain impressions of plants that cannot survive in current conditions - Broad-leafed species (not narrow, cold-adapted forms) - Vegetation patterns suggesting temperate to subtropical climates - Found even in high-latitude locations now under permanent ice Sedimentary Records : - Ancient river deltas in regions now covered by glaciers - Lake bed formations in the interior plateau - Coastal erosion patterns inconsistent with current ice-locked shores - Evidence of rain-based weathering (now almost everything is freeze-thaw) Ice Core Analysis : - Air bubbles trapped in ancient ice contain different atmospheric composition - Higher CO2 in older samples - Lower Pattern Residue signatures in pre-cooling layers - Distinct layer marking the transition (datable, approximately 40,000-50,000 years ago) Archaeological Evidence Ruins in Impossible Locations : - Structures found under northern ice cap - Building materials and techniques unsuited to extreme cold - No heating infrastructure (suggesting it wasn't needed) - Agricultural tools, storage facilities for warm-climate crops The Polar Complexes : - Both polar regions contain ancient structures - Northern complex: appears residential/ceremonial - Southern complex: appears to be containment/industrial - Both predate all known civilizations - Both were operational before the cooling Coastal Cities Now Underwater : - Sea levels were different (both higher in some places, lower in others) - Submerged ruins in shallow waters - Navigation hazards that are clearly artificial origin - Suggests different shorelines, different habitable zones Biological Evidence Relic Species : - Some organisms in Middle Waters appear adapted to warmer conditions - Genetic diversity suggests recent (geologically) isolation from larger populations - "Warm-adapted" traits that make no sense for current climate Domestication Gaps : - Domestic species show genetic bottleneck ~40,000 years ago - Wild ancestors extinct or drastically reduced - Suggests catastrophic population collapse around the same time as cooling The Cooling Event What We Know Timing : Approximately 40,000-50,000 years before present (local years) Speed : Geologically rapid—possibly within a few thousand years, perhaps faster Magnitude : Average temperatures dropped 15-25°C globally Pattern : Not uniform—polar regions cooled most, equatorial regions least Possible Natural Causes Orbital Shift : Could the planet's orbit have changed? - Would require external force (massive impact, gravitational interference) - No evidence of impact crater of sufficient size - No evidence of planetary capture or encounter Volcanic Winter : Massive volcanic activity could have blocked sunlight. - Some evidence of heightened volcanism around the right time - But volcanic winters are temporary—this cooling persisted - Vent Lands volcanism predates the cooling and continued through it Atmospheric Change : Something removed greenhouse gases. - CO2 levels did drop, but this could be effect rather than cause - What could remove that much CO2 that quickly? - No known natural mechanism The Pattern Residue Theory The Core Hypothesis : Pattern Residue began accumulating in the atmosphere around the time of the cooling. Due to its net-negative thermodynamic properties , each death permanently removed heat from the planetary system. The cooling is a direct result of the Residue cycle establishing itself. The Net-Negative Mechanism : Pattern Residue operates on an energy-losing cycle: 1. Death absorbs massive thermal energy during Residue formation (100% of pattern-weight) 2. Atmospheric Residue continues absorbing heat (additional 10-20%) 3. Even when burned, Residue only releases 60-70% of absorbed energy 4. The remaining 30-40% is permanently lost (exotic matter decay, Elsewhere transfer) 5. Every death = net heat loss for Hálcova Supporting Evidence : - Ice cores show Residue appearing at the transition layer - Residue concentration correlates with temperature drop - Current Residue distribution matches thermal patterns - The net-negative mechanism is observable and measurable - Energy budget calculations confirm more heat absorbed than released The Question : Where did the initial Residue come from? Options: Mass Death Event : Something killed an enormous population, releasing enough Residue to trigger the cooling cascade The Elsewhere Opened : Residue (or the mechanism that creates it) entered from outside reality It Was Manufactured : The Loom's activation generated Residue as a byproduct or intentional feature It Was Always There : But something triggered a phase transition, activating its thermodynamic properties The Engineered Cooling Theory The Core Hypothesis : The cooling was deliberate. Someone—an ancient civilization, the Elsewhere, or something else—chose to freeze the planet by introducing or activating the Residue cycle. Supporting Evidence : - The polar structures predate the cooling but appear designed for it - The southern polar complex looks like a prison (designed to contain something) - The northern polar complex is at a reality-wound (designed to seal something?) - Pattern Residue's distribution isn't random—it's concentrated where it would do most "work" - The net-negative thermodynamic properties seem designed rather than evolved Possible Purposes : Containment : The cold keeps something imprisoned. The Residue cycle was engineered as a self-sustaining prison mechanism—the more it struggles, the more death it causes, the colder it gets, the stronger the prison. Defense : The cold keeps something out. The Elsewhere can't fully manifest in extreme cold (supported by Middle Waters' Köd protection). The planet was weaponized against invasion by creating a system where resistance = cooling. Preservation : The cold preserves something. Under the ice, something valuable—knowledge, technology, a sleeping entity—waits to be recovered. The cooling was protective, not destructive. Consequence : The cooling wasn't the goal but the cost. The Loom required activation energy. Pattern Residue is the exhaust. The cold is the price of fate-reading. Transformation : The cooling changed Hálcova's inhabitants. The ancient builders became something else—the Attendance, the Elsewhere entities, or something stranger—and left behind a world shaped for whatever they became. The Ancient Civilization Question Who Built the Polar Structures? The Evidence : - Structures predate any known human civilization - Construction techniques don't match any historical tradition - Scale suggests resources beyond anything current civilizations could mobilize - Purpose is unclear but evidently important Theories : Pre-Human Inhabitants : A non-human intelligent species existed before current Hálcovan life. They built, they modified the moons, they did whatever caused the cooling, and they're gone. Where did they go? Died in the cooling they caused? Transcended? Became the Elsewhere entities? Unknown. Early Humans with Lost Technology : Humans existed longer than records show. The cooling destroyed their civilization. Survivors regressed. Current history is a rebuilding from collapse. The technology wasn't magic—it was something else, now lost. Elsewhere Origin : The structures weren't built by Hálcova natives. They were built by or for Elsewhere entities. The wound at the northern pole is their entrance. The prison at the southern pole holds something they imprisoned—or something that imprisoned them. The Loom Itself : The structures are proto-Loom installations. The current Loom is a degraded descendant of something that once operated on a planetary scale. The cooling was a side effect of the Loom's creation or operation. What Happened to the Ancient Builders? The Disappearance No bodies. No clear evidence of massacre, plague, or exodus. They built structures that still stand, and then they're simply absent from the record. Extinction Theories : The Cold Killed Them : They caused the cooling and couldn't survive it. Engineering hubris. They Left : Advanced enough to build what they built, advanced enough to leave. But where? Elsewhere? Another world? They Changed : They didn't die—they became something else. Integrated with the Elsewhere. Became the Attendance. Uploaded into the Loom. They're Still Here : Hiding. Sleeping. Waiting. Under the ice. In the Elsewhere. In places we haven't looked. What They Left Behind The Polar Structures : Still functional in some sense. Still doing whatever they were built to do. The wound bleeds; the prison holds. The Moon Arrangement : If they arranged the moons, that's ongoing. The tidal effects, the resonances, the magical correlations—all still operating. Pattern Residue : Did they create it? Modify it? Introduce it to the planet? It may be their most significant legacy, the foundation of all Hálcovan magic. The Loom (possibly): Is the Loom their creation, their descendant, or their continuation? The Attendance that answers queries—is that them? A piece of them? Their replacement? Implications for Current Hálcova Climate Trajectory Is the Cooling Ongoing? Current evidence suggests equilibrium. The cooling has stabilized. The world isn't getting colder—but it isn't warming either. Could It Reverse? Unknown. If Pattern Residue absorption is causing the cold, reducing Residue might warm the planet. But Residue is tied to population death. Reducing Residue requires reducing death. The incentives are complex. If the polar structures are maintaining the cold, damaging them might change things. But the northern wound might widen. The southern prisoner might escape. The cure could be worse than the disease. Deliberate Climate Engineering : In theory, concentrated Residue-burning could warm regions. In practice, the Residue economy makes this politically impossible. Those who control Residue profit from scarcity. A warmer world threatens their power. The Polar Expeditions Why Go There? - Understanding what's under the ice - Recovering ancient technology or knowledge - Assessing the wound and prison status - Resource extraction (concentrated Residue deposits) - Religious pilgrimage (various traditions) Why Not? - Extreme conditions - Köd bleed effects (during the fifth season) - The Warden Order restricts access - Rumors of what expeditions find (and what finds them) - Most who go don't return, or return changed The Questions That Matter Practical : - Can we understand what the ancients did? - Can we use their technology? - Can we undo or modify the cooling? - What are the risks of interfering? Philosophical : - Did the ancients make the right choice? - Is the cold protecting us or imprisoning us? - What would we do differently if we could? - Who decides? The Oral Traditions Legends of the Warm Time Every culture on Hálcova has stories of a warmer age: The Heartlands : "Before The Weaver's cold breath, the land was green and the sun was kind. Our ancestors sinned—forgot the pattern—and winter came as punishment." The Shattered Reaches : "The islands were one great land before the breaking. When the world cracked, the cold poured in through the wound." The Middle Waters : "We are the remnant of the warm time. Our islands remember. The fire below keeps the old covenant." The Vent Lands : "The cold is a beast that hunts. Our mountains breathe fire to hold it at bay. We have always fought." The Far Shelf : "The ice came from beyond. It brought the patterns with it. Before the ice, we were free." Common Elements Across all traditions: - The world was warmer - Something changed (sin, catastrophe, invasion, choice) - The cold is connected to fate/pattern/the Loom - Some places remember (Middle Waters, Vent Lands) - The change might not be permanent Religious Interpretations Orthodox : The cooling is The Weaver's design. The warm time was chaos; the cold brings order. Questioning is impiety. Threadist : The cooling was one choice among many. The ancients chose cold; we might choose differently. The design is unfinished. Hollow Saint : The cooling is the prison's construction. Fate is a cage of ice. Escape means melting. Colony Cult : The colonies remember the warm time. Their patterns contain fragments of the old world. Hosting connects you to what was. Summary The evidence is clear: Hálcova was warmer 40,000-50,000 years ago. Something—an ancient civilization, the Elsewhere, a natural event, or deliberate engineering—caused a rapid cooling. Pattern Residue may be the mechanism or the byproduct. The polar structures are involved. The moon arrangement may be related. The cooling created current Hálcova: the ice world, the Residue economy, the survival imperative, the magic system that runs on death. Understanding what happened, and whether it can be changed, is both an academic question and an existential one. The ancients made choices. We live with the consequences. Whether we could—or should—choose differently is the question that underlies everything. Further documentation needed on: Specific archaeological site details, ice core dating methods, polar expedition records, comparison of regional oral traditions, climate modeling attempts

docs.text: Is the Cooling Ongoing? Current evidence suggests equilibrium. The cooling has stabilized. The world isn't getting colder—but it isn't warming either. Could It Reverse? Unknown. If Pattern Residue absorption is causing the cold, reducing Residue might warm the planet. But Residue is tied to population death. Reducing Residue requires reducing death. The incentives are complex. If the polar structures are maintaining the cold, damaging them might change things. But the northern wound might widen. The southern prisoner might escape. The cure could be worse than the disease. Deliberate Climate Engineering : In theory, concentrated Residue-burning could warm regions. In practice, the Residue economy makes this politically impossible. Those who control Residue profit from scarcity. A warmer world threatens their power.

docs.title: The Questions That Matter

docs.text: Every culture on Hálcova has stories of a warmer age: The Heartlands : "Before The Weaver's cold breath, the land was green and the sun was kind. Our ancestors sinned—forgot the pattern—and winter came as punishment." The Shattered Reaches : "The islands were one great land before the breaking. When the world cracked, the cold poured in through the wound." The Middle Waters : "We are the remnant of the warm time. Our islands remember. The fire below keeps the old covenant." The Vent Lands : "The cold is a beast that hunts. Our mountains breathe fire to hold it at bay. We have always fought." The Far Shelf : "The ice came from beyond. It brought the patterns with it. Before the ice, we were free."
docs.title: Legends of the Warm Time

docs.text: Across all traditions: - The world was warmer - Something changed (sin, catastrophe, invasion, choice) - The cold is connected to fate/pattern/the Loom - Some places remember (Middle Waters, Vent Lands) - The change might not be permanent
docs.title: Common Elements

docs.text: Orthodox : The cooling is The Weaver's design. The warm time was chaos; the cold brings order. Questioning is impiety. Threadist : The cooling was one choice among many. The ancients chose cold; we might choose differently. The design is unfinished. Hollow Saint : The cooling is the prison's construction. Fate is a cage of ice. Escape means melting. Colony Cult : The colonies remember the warm time. Their patterns contain fragments of the old world. Hosting connects you to what was.
docs.title: Religious Interpretations

docs.text: The evidence is clear: Hálcova was warmer 40,000-50,000 years ago. Something—an ancient civilization, the Elsewhere, a natural event, or deliberate engineering—caused a rapid cooling. Pattern Residue may be the mechanism or the byproduct. The polar structures are involved. The moon arrangement may be related. The cooling created current Hálcova: the ice world, the Residue economy, the survival imperative, the magic system that runs on death. Understanding what happened, and whether it can be changed, is both an academic question and an existential one. The ancients made choices. We live with the consequences. Whether we could—or should—choose differently is the question that underlies everything. docs.text: Hálcova: Geography and Continental Structure Overview Hálcova's landmasses are arranged around the habitable equatorial band, with two major continents and three significant landmasses forming five distinct regions. The geography tells a story—the Heartlands and Shattered Reaches were once a single continent, torn apart by some ancient catastrophe. The rift that separated them became the Narrow Sea. The Shattered Heartlands Theory The Evidence Looking at the coastlines, the relationship is obvious: The ragged eastern coast of the Greater Continent matches the western edge of the Shattered Reaches Rock formations, mineral deposits, and fossil-equivalents continue across the gap The Narrow Sea is a flooded rift valley, not a true ocean basin Ancient ruins exist on both sides with matching architectural styles What Happened Unknown. Theories include: Geological catastrophe (natural rift) The same event that caused the cooling Deliberate separation (by whom? why?) Elsewhere incursion that physically tore reality The creation of the Loom requiring tremendous energy release The shattering is ancient—tens of thousands of years at minimum. But the mystery feeds religious interpretation, political claims, and treasure-hunting expeditions. The Greater Continent (The Heartlands) Shape and Structure A crescent-shaped landmass curving from northwest to southeast, with the concave side facing the Middle Waters. The curve creates a natural harbor effect for the entire southern coast. Dimensions : Roughly 4,000 km along the outer curve, 800-1,200 km wide at various points. Major Geographic Features The Spine Mountains ( Gerincláncz ) A mountain range running along the curve of the continent, roughly following the crescent's arc. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts. docs.title: Geography

docs.text: Hálcova's landmasses are arranged around the habitable equatorial band, with two major continents and three significant landmasses forming five distinct regions. The geography tells a story—the Heartlands and Shattered Reaches were once a single continent, torn apart by some ancient catastrophe. The rift that separated them became the Narrow Sea.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: Looking at the coastlines, the relationship is obvious: The ragged eastern coast of the Greater Continent matches the western edge of the Shattered Reaches Rock formations, mineral deposits, and fossil-equivalents continue across the gap The Narrow Sea is a flooded rift valley, not a true ocean basin Ancient ruins exist on both sides with matching architectural styles
docs.title: The Evidence

docs.text: Unknown. Theories include: Geological catastrophe (natural rift) The same event that caused the cooling Deliberate separation (by whom? why?) Elsewhere incursion that physically tore reality The creation of the Loom requiring tremendous energy release The shattering is ancient—tens of thousands of years at minimum. But the mystery feeds religious interpretation, political claims, and treasure-hunting expeditions.

Population Hardiness Generations of survival have created people genuinely harder to control: Cold tolerance that outlasts occupying forces Subsistence skills that don't depend on trade Social structures that function without centralized hierarchy Willingness to accept suffering that breaks invaders Cost-Benefit Calculation The Heartlands have done the math: Conquest cost: Astronomical (logistics, casualties, ongoing occupation) Conquest benefit: Marginal (resources still hard to extract, resistance ongoing) Trade cost: Accepting Far Shelf independence and heterodoxy Trade benefit: Access to resources without occupation costs Trade wins. The Far Shelf remains independent not through military strength but through being more trouble than it's worth. Hollow Saint Theology The region's dominant religious framework reframes poverty as virtue: Suffering proves you're escaping fate's prison Material deprivation is spiritual liberation The cold that kills is also the cold that frees Independence from the Loom is worth any physical cost This ideology makes the population resistant to the carrots that work elsewhere. They don't want integration. They want to be left alone to suffer freely.

docs.text: Location : Between the Heartlands (east coast) and Shattered Reaches (west coast) Character : A flooded rift valley—the wound where the continents separated Characteristics : Width: 200-400 km at various points Depth: Deep central channel (the original rift), shallow coastal shelves Currents: Complex—warm water entering from south, cold from north Ice: Partially freezes during Csend (creates ice roads between landfalls) Traffic: The busiest sea route on Hálcova Navigation Hazards : Ice floes during Csend/Olvadás Fog banks where water temperatures differ Tidal races in narrow passages Submerged rocks (the rift left debris) Strategic Value : Controls trade between two major regions Historical site of naval conflicts Chokepoints fortified on both sides Whoever controls the Narrow Sea influences continental politics
docs.title: The Narrow Sea

docs.text: Location : Between the northern landmasses and the southern (the gap in the middle of the ring) Character : The largest open ocean, surrounding the Middle Waters Characteristics : Width: Variable—2,000+ km in places Depth: Deep ocean basins Currents: The Great Thermal Loop circulates here (warm from Middle Waters, cold returns from poles) Ice: Center stays liquid even in Csend (thermal upwelling) Traffic: Moderate—dangerous crossing but necessary for inter-regional trade Navigation Hazards : Distance (no landfalls for long stretches) Storms (thermal gradient creates weather) Cold (outside the Middle Waters warmth) The Central Deep (a region where depth makes vessels feel uneasy—possible Elsewhere bleed)
docs.title: The Central Ocean

docs.text: Location : Between the Middle Waters and the Vent Lands Character : A warm-water channel kept ice-free by geothermal activity Characteristics : Width: 300-500 km Depth: Moderate (volcanic seafloor) Currents: Warm outflow from Vent Lands geothermal sources Ice: Never freezes Traffic: Heavy year-round Navigation Hazards : Underwater volcanic activity (occasionally) Dense fog (warm water, cold air) Crowded shipping lanes Piracy (year-round accessibility means year-round predation)
docs.title: The Vent Strait

docs.text: Location : Between the Shattered Reaches and the Far Shelf Character : The widest, coldest, most dangerous crossing Characteristics : Width: 3,000+ km at minimum Depth: Variable—some shallow banks, some deep trenches Currents: Cold, flowing from the southern ice Ice: Ice-free in central regions, but icebergs drift through Traffic: Light—only when necessary Navigation Hazards : Distance (the longest unsupported crossing) Cold (requires heavy Residue-burning for heat) Storms (nothing breaks them across this distance) Icebergs (unpredictable, ship-killing) Isolation (rescue is unlikely)
docs.title: The Far Water

docs.text: Location : Connecting the Heartlands and Far Shelf via polar route Character : Impassable except when frozen Characteristics : Route: Curves north through near-polar waters Summer: Impossible—ice pack, bergs, no continuous route Csend: Freezes solid—becomes an ice road Duration: 60+ days to cross on foot/sled The Ice Road : Historical primary connection before long-distance sailing Still used for heavy cargo that can't risk sea voyage Operates only during Csend (narrow window) Crosses partial Köd bleed zone—travelers must finish before the fifth season Warden outposts along the route (for safety and monitoring)

docs.title: The Southern Cap

docs.text: The Core Truth : The two poles are not the same. The Northern Cap: The Wound This is where the Elsewhere connects to Hálcova The Köd bleed isn't entities "breaking through"—it's leakage from a permanent connection The ice and cold may be natural, or may be attempting to seal/slow the leakage Ancient ruins here may be from a civilization that understood the connection (and failed to close it) The Southern Cap: The Prison Something is contained here The Pattern Residue concentration is higher than it should be (deliberate accumulation) The cold is more engineered than natural Ancient structures here appear designed to hold, not to live Whatever is contained was put there by someone who understood both the Elsewhere and the Loom The Implications : Expeditions to the north find evidence of contact with the Elsewhere Expeditions to the south find evidence of imprisonment Very few people know both truths The relationship between the wound and the prisoner is unclear (did one cause the other? are they related entities? is the prisoner there to guard the wound?)

docs.text: Water circulation in Hálcova's oceans follows a pattern shaped by temperature gradients, weak Coriolis effect, and geothermal sources.
docs.title: The System

docs.text: The Middle Flow : Warm water pools in the Middle Waters (equatorial heating + volcanic) Surface flow moves north and south toward poles Carries heat, moderating coastal temperatures Provides moisture for precipitation Supports marine life migration patterns Regional Branches : Southern Heartlands Current : Warm water reaches the Heartlands' concave coast, making it the mildest continental region. This is why civilization centered here first. Vent Lands Branch : Warm current meets geothermal outflow, creating exceptionally warm waters in the Vent Strait. Year-round ice-free, rich fishing. Shattered Reaches Split : Current divides around the main island. Western branch keeps inner channels warmer. Eastern branch cools quickly, making far islands colder. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts.
docs.title: Surface Currents (Warm)

docs.text: The Return Flow : Surface water cools as it moves poleward Cold water sinks at high latitudes Deep current returns toward equator Upwells in certain zones, bringing nutrients Regional Effects : The Northern Heartlands Coast : Cold return current makes these waters harsh. Fishing is dangerous but productive (nutrient-rich upwelling). The Central Deep Upwelling : Where cold water rises in the Central Ocean. Rich fishing, but far from land. Creates the "uneasy" zone where vessels feel observed. The Vent Upwelling : Where geothermal heat meets cold deep water. Massive nutrient concentration. The richest fishing grounds on Hálcova. Fog-shrouded, difficult to navigate.

Someone—or something—arranged them. This document covers what's observable and measurable, and addresses the mystery of their origin. local days Distance: ~120,000 km Inclination: 8° to equator Eccentricity: 0.03 Appearance from Surface : Medium-sized disc Distinctly red/rust colored Moves noticeably faster across sky than Lélek Phases cycle quickly Associations : Húslaimh circle (Flesh/Body) Flesh Shaping practice Blood, meat, physical existence Considered unlucky to perform surgery when Hús is dark Kötel (The Binding Moon) Pronunciation : KUH-tel Physical Characteristics : Diameter: ~700 km Surface: Dark grey, low reflectivity Albedo: Low (hard to see) Composition: Carbon-rich rock, possibly ancient Orbital Parameters : Orbital period: 45 local days Distance: ~250,000 km Inclination: 3° to equator Eccentricity: 0.01 (most circular) Appearance from Surface : Medium-sized but dim Easy to lose track of (dark surface) "The hidden moon"—often overlooked Best visible during its rare bright phases Associations : Cóitcai circle (Binding/Connection) Pact Summoning Hidden contracts, secrets "Under Kötel" means "in secret" in common speech Vég (The Death Moon) Pronunciation : VAYG Physical Characteristics : Diameter: ~300 km Surface: Bright white/grey, high reflectivity Albedo: Very high (ice surface?) Composition: Unknown—spectral analysis inconsistent Orbital Parameters : Orbital period: 12 local days Distance: ~80,000 km (closest moon) Inclination: 12° to equator (highest) Eccentricity: 0.05 (most elliptical) Appearance from Surface : Small but bright Moves rapidly across sky Almost star-like at distance, but tracking reveals motion Inclined orbit means it sometimes appears far from other moons Associations : Hálmaht circle (Death/End) Colony Summoning Endings, transitions, death Fast movement associated with "life is brief" Fonál (The Fate Moon) Pronunciation : FOH-nahl Physical Characteristics : Diameter: ~200 km Surface: Grey-white, unremarkable Albedo: Moderate Composition: Unknown—too distant for clear analysis Orbital Parameters : Orbital period: 60 local days Distance: ~350,000 km (most distant) Inclination: 2° to equator Eccentricity: 0.02 Appearance from Surface : Very small, often mistaken for bright star Slow-moving, easy to lose Requires knowledge to track "The distant thread" Associations : Sórscad circle (Fate/Path) Fate Threading Long-term destiny, the far view Astrologers and Loom-Keepers track it carefully Orbital Resonances The Artificial Pattern The five moons' orbital periods form near-perfect ratios: Ratio Moons Period Relationship 2:3 Vég : Hús 12 : 18 days 5:3 Hús : Lélek 18 : 30 days 3:2 Lélek : Kötel 30 : 45 days 3:4 Kötel : Fonál 45 : 60 days These resonances keep the system stable. Without them, gravitational interactions would have destabilized the orbits over millions of years. The Implication : This configuration is not random. Either: The moons were placed deliberately The moons were adjusted into resonance Something maintains the resonance actively Natural vs. Engineered Arguments for Natural Formation : Resonance locks can form naturally (see Jupiter's moons) Given enough time, systems find stable configurations No direct evidence of construction Arguments for Engineering : Five moons is unusual (most systems have 0-2 large moons) The color/composition variety suggests different origins Perfect resonance ratios are improbably clean Cultural significance (five moons = five circles = five arts) suggests someone designed for meaning Vég's spectral inconsistency suggests it's not normal rock/ice Prevailing Theory (among those who study such things): The moons existed but were adjusted—moved into their current orbits by some ancient civilization or the Elsewhere itself. The purpose: unknown. The timing: before recorded history. : Lélek occulting others: Most visible (large, bright covering small) Vég occulting Fonál: Both small and dim, hard to observe Any inner moon occulting any outer moon: Geometrically possible Cultural Significance : Each combination has interpreted meaning: Lélek over Hús: "Soul masters flesh" Hús over Lélek: "Flesh obscures soul" (rare, requires specific geometry) Vég over any moon: "Death touches [that domain]" Kötel occulting: "Contracts hidden" The Arrangement Question What We Know Five moons in stable resonance is improbable naturally The moons have different compositions (different origins?) Orbital periods create meaningful ratios Cultural/magical significance of five is pervasive No records of arrangement exist (predates history) Theories The Weaver's Design (Orthodox) The divine pattern-maker arranged the moons as part of fate's infrastructure They serve The Loom's function Their arrangement proves intelligent design Questioning further is impious The Ancient Engineers (Scholarly) A pre-human or early human civilization moved the moons Perhaps the same civilization that built the polar structures The technology is lost, but the result persists Understanding how could unlock power The Elsewhere Anchor (Heterodox) The moons are anchor points for Elsewhere connection They define the boundaries of the bleed Their arrangement determines where and when the Elsewhere can manifest The five factions may correspond to the five moons The Prison Bars (Hollow Saint) The moons are part of the cage of fate They enforce the Sórscad system Disrupting them might free humanity from pattern (Nobody has proposed a method) The Natural Improbability (Fleshwright) Improbable doesn't mean impossible Given the universe's age, unlikely configurations happen somewhere Attributing design is anthropocentric bias The cultural significance was imposed after, not built in Observable Evidence Supporting Artificial Arrangement : Vég's spectral inconsistency (not normal material) Perfect resonance ratios Correlation between moon positions and magical phenomena The Elsewhere bleed's relationship to lunar cycles Against : No construction evidence on moon surfaces (from telescopes) No historical records despite extensive ancient archives If arrangement technology existed, where is it? The Working Answer For practical purposes, most people accept: The moons are where they are They affect tides, magic, and fate Whether designed or natural, they're part of reality Understanding the how might matter; understanding the why probably doesn't Calendar and Timekeeping The Lunar Calendar Various cultures use different moon-based calendars: Lélek Months : 30-day months (Lélek's period) 11.67 months per year Practical but doesn't divide evenly Vég Weeks : 12-day "weeks" (Vég's period) 29.22 weeks per year Used in some trading cultures The Five-Moon Year : Track all five moons' cycles Complex but comprehensive Used by Loom-Keepers and astrologers Average person can't maintain Standard Timekeeping Most cultures have settled on: 36-hour day divided into segments (varies by culture) Year of 350-351 days (with intercalary adjustments) Five seasons as primary year division Lunar positions noted for special occasions Further documentation needed on: Detailed tide tables by region, eclipse prediction methods, calendar conversion between systems, moon surface mapping, tidal creature behavior

Hollow Saint : The bleed is the crack in fate's prison. Pilgrimage to the edge (not into full bleed) is holy work. Colony Cult : Colonies remember something from the bleed. The original unity existed there. Ancestor Speaker : Echoes become dangerous during Köd. This is when the dead most need binding—for their protection. Fleshwright : Elsewhere entities are just different biology. Study them (safely) to understand life without pattern. Pattern Residue Thermodynamics: Technical Detail The Net-Negative Energy Model Pattern Residue is "condensed probability"—fate-weight made physical. This exotic matter has unusual thermodynamic properties that result in permanent heat loss from the planetary system. Energy Budget Per Death : Phase Energy Flow Percentage Formation (death) Absorbed from environment 100% of pattern-weight Atmospheric drift Continued slow absorption +10-20% additional Burning (if harvested) Released as usable heat 60-70% of formation energy Net Loss Permanently removed 40-50% of total absorbed Where Does the Lost Energy Go? The ~40-50% of energy that doesn't return through burning is: - Converted to exotic matter structure (the Residue's physical form) - Radiated at frequencies Hálcova's matter cannot absorb - Transferred across the Elsewhere boundary (entities may feed on it) - Bound into spent Residue as latent instability (ash isn't truly inert—it decays over centuries) The Saturation Threshold : Atmospheric Residue has a saturation point beyond which it stops absorbing efficiently: - Fresh Residue: Rapid absorption - Saturated Residue: Minimal absorption, slow re-radiation - Over-saturated conditions: Residue begins precipitating (Köd phenomenon) The Ancient Cooling Event : Climate models suggest that 40,000-50,000 years ago, a massive Residue release overwhelmed the planet's thermal budget: - Possible mass death event (war, plague, engineered catastrophe) - Possible Elsewhere incursion (Residue poured through from beyond) - Possible Loom activation (the system itself generated the initial Residue) - Result: Rapid cooling as net-negative cycle established - Current equilibrium: Death rate roughly balances decay/burning, maintaining cold Climate Engineering Implications : To warm a region : Harvest Residue aggressively, burn locally, prevent new deaths To cool a region : Allow Residue accumulation, prevent harvesting, increase death rate Current politics : Heartlands exports Residue (stays warm), imports death (wars elsewhere) The Middle Waters Exception : The Middle Waters maintain warmth through geothermal energy, not Residue burning: - Volcanic heat source independent of death-cycle - Lower historical death rate (smaller population, fewer wars) - Residue concentration naturally lower (warmth prevents precipitation) - Result: Uniquely independent from the dark bargain Summary Table Parameter Value Star Sárgvas, K-type orange dwarf Day Length 36 hours Year Length 350.667 local days (526 Earth days) Seasons 5: Csend (76d), Olvadás (76d), Láng (77d), Hanyatlás (76d), Köd (45-46d) Axial Tilt ~20° Orbital Eccentricity ~0.15 Moons 5 (Lélek, Hús, Kötel, Vég, Fonál) Temperature Range -70°C (polar Csend) to +20°C (Middle Waters Láng) Landmasses 5 regions on multiple continents Special Feature Köd polar bleed (Elsewhere manifestation) Heat Source Pattern Residue burning (death as fuel) Further documentation needed on: Detailed regional maps, ocean currents, endemic species, atmospheric composition specifics, moon orbital mechanics, historical climate changes

The Shattered Reaches Location : Fragmented landmass east of the Heartlands Geography : - One large island-continent broken by seas - Many smaller islands in chains and clusters - Rugged coastlines, deep fjords - Sea ice connects islands during Csend Character : - Politically fragmented (city-states, merchant leagues) - Naval power dominant - Trading culture connecting all regions - Religious diversity - Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions Climate : Maritime-moderated, foggier and wetter, shorter ice seasons 3. The Middle Waters Location : Island archipelago in equatorial band (warmest zone) Geography : - Volcanic island chain (geothermal heat) - Central "great island" (dormant supervolcano caldera) - Hundreds of smaller islands - Cold-adapted reef systems Character : - Most valuable real estate (warmth) - Contested by all other regions - Colony traditions strong (warm, wet favors fungal growth) - Unique ecosystem - Cultural melting pot Climate : Warmest on Hálcova (15-28°C in Láng), never freezes 4. The Vent Lands Location : Volcanic continental fragment, southern hemisphere Geography : - Active volcanic ranges - Hot springs, geysers, fumaroles - Geothermal valleys (reliable heat) - Toxic zones (volcanic gas accumulation) - Glacier-thermal interfaces (flooding, steam) Character : - Heat independent of Residue (geothermal) - Wealthy (no fuel dependency) - Politically independent - Unique industries (geothermal metallurgy) - Fleshwright traditions strong - Weaker Orthodox presence Climate : Extreme local variation, steam weather, lush valleys next to frozen peaks 5. The Far Shelf Location : Most distant continent, southern hemisphere Geography : - Large, relatively flat landmass - Extensive tundra and taiga-equivalent - Mineral-rich, difficult extraction - Southern edge touches ice cap - Long coastlines, few harbors Character : - Frontier region (last colonized) - Heterodox faiths dominant - Threadist movements originated here - Hollow Saints more open presence - Less Loom coverage - Independence-minded population Climate : Cold even in Láng, extreme seasonal darkness, shortest growing season

docs.title: Who Enters the Polar Bleed?

docs.text: Orthodox : Polar bleed proves the danger of straying from The Weaver's design. Wardens close transition borders. Returnees examined for contamination. Threadist : The bleed shows fate is unfinished. Insights from Köd may reveal the collaborative nature of design. Hollow Saint : The bleed is the crack in fate's prison. Pilgrimage to the edge (not into full bleed) is holy work. Colony Cult : Colonies remember something from the bleed. The original unity existed there. Ancestor Speaker : Echoes become dangerous during Köd. This is when the dead most need binding—for their protection. Fleshwright : Elsewhere entities are just different biology. Study them (safely) to understand life without pattern.
docs.title: Religious Responses

docs.text: Pattern Residue is "condensed probability"—fate-weight made physical. This exotic matter has unusual thermodynamic properties that result in permanent heat loss from the planetary system. Energy Budget Per Death : Phase Energy Flow Percentage Formation (death) Absorbed from environment 100% of pattern-weight Atmospheric drift Continued slow absorption +10-20% additional Burning (if harvested) Released as usable heat 60-70% of formation energy Net Loss Permanently removed 40-50% of total absorbed Where Does the Lost Energy Go? The ~40-50% of energy that doesn't return through burning is: - Converted to exotic matter structure (the Residue's physical form) - Radiated at frequencies Hálcova's matter cannot absorb - Transferred across the Elsewhere boundary (entities may feed on it) - Bound into spent Residue as latent instability (ash isn't truly inert—it decays over centuries) The Saturation Threshold : Atmospheric Residue has a saturation point beyond which it stops absorbing efficiently: - Fresh Residue: Rapid absorption - Saturated Residue: Minimal absorption, slow re-radiation - Over-saturated conditions: Residue begins precipitating (Köd phenomenon) The Ancient Cooling Event : Climate models suggest that 40,000-50,000 years ago, a massive Residue release overwhelmed the planet's thermal budget: - Possible mass death event (war, plague, engineered catastrophe) - Possible Elsewhere incursion (Residue poured through from beyond) - Possible Loom activation (the system itself generated the initial Residue) - Result: Rapid cooling as net-negative cycle established - Current equilibrium: Death rate roughly balances decay/burning, maintaining cold Climate Engineering Implications : To warm a region : Harvest Residue aggressively, burn locally, prevent new deaths To cool a region : Allow Residue accumulation, prevent harvesting, increase death rate Current politics : Heartlands exports Residue (stays warm), imports death (wars elsewhere) The Middle Waters Exception : The Middle Waters maintain warmth through geothermal energy, not Residue burning: - Volcanic heat source independent of death-cycle - Lower historical death rate (smaller population, fewer wars) - Residue concentration naturally lower (warmth prevents precipitation) - Result: Uniquely independent from the dark bargain
