docs.text: Criminal Underworld of Hálcova Overview Crime in Hálcova exists in complex relationship with legitimate power structures. Organized criminal enterprises fill gaps left by official systems, exploit pattern-based inequalities, and sometimes serve as the only recourse for those whom legal society has abandoned. Understanding Hálcova 's criminal underworld illuminates the world's social fractures, economic pressures, and the limitations of official authority. The criminal economy represents approximately 5-10% of legitimate economic activity—substantial enough to influence markets and politics, contained enough to avoid threatening system stability. This equilibrium reflects tacit accommodation between criminal organizations and authorities who find complete suppression neither possible nor desirable. Major Criminal Organizations The Silk Threads (Fonvárs) The dominant criminal organization in the Heartlands capital operates with sophistication matching legitimate institutions. Structure and Leadership The Silk Threads employ a hierarchical structure of approximately 500 active members. At the apex sits the Weaver—a position whose occupant's identity remains unknown to most members and all outsiders. The Weaver communicates through intermediaries, maintaining mystique that enhances authority and complicates law enforcement efforts. Below the Weaver, five Thread-Captains control distinct districts of Fonvárs criminal territory: the Docks, the Lower Markets, the Warehouse Quarter, the Craftsmen's District, and the Entertainment District. Each Thread-Captain maintains significant autonomy within their territory while coordinating major operations through the Weaver's intermediaries. Thread-Captains command Knots—groups of 10-20 enforcers who handle violence, collection, and territorial defense. Individual Knot leaders earn 1,000-3,000 marks annually; ordinary enforcers earn 500-1,500 marks. At the base, Loose Ends handle street-level crime: pickpocketing, small-scale theft, message running, and lookout duties. These individuals earn 50-300 marks annually and aspire to Knot membership. Primary Activities Protection Rackets : The Silk Threads' most reliable revenue stream. Businesses in controlled territories pay weekly fees (typically 5-10% of revenue) for "protection" from criminal activity—protection that would otherwise come from the Silk Threads themselves. Annual protection revenue: approximately 150,000 marks. Smuggling : Contraband enters Fonvárs through Silk Thread networks. Untaxed luxury goods, Threadist texts, illegal Elsewhere artifacts, and restricted substances move through warehouses and shops that appear legitimate. Smuggling revenue varies dramatically by year; average approximately 100,000 marks annually. Gambling Operations : Underground gambling houses offer games unavailable legally and serve customers who cannot access licensed establishments. House advantages and occasional rigging generate steady profits. Annual gambling revenue: approximately 75,000 marks. Prostitution : Unlicensed brothels operate throughout controlled territories. The Silk Threads provide protection to sex workers in exchange for substantial cuts of earnings. Revenue: approximately 50,000 marks annually. Pattern-Forgery : Perhaps the most lucrative per-transaction activity, the Silk Threads produce forged pattern-certificates allowing constrained individuals to access privileges reserved for higher pattern status. A quality forgery costs 500-5,000 marks; detection means execution for both forger and user. Annual forgery revenue: approximately 100,000 marks. Residue Theft : The most dangerous operation involves stealing Residue—the essence left when pattern-bearing individuals die—from Church collection or state storage. Residue has enormous value to certain buyers, but theft constitutes both crime and heresy. Revenue varies; major heists can net 50,000+ marks but occur rarely. Relationship with Authority The Silk Threads maintain corruption networks ensuring operational continuity. City Guard officers receive monthly payments (50-200 marks depending on rank and territory) for ignoring specific activities and providing warning of raids. Several mid-level Wardens accept payments for similar accommodation regarding pattern-crimes, though senior Wardens appear incorruptible. The Church's relationship with the Silk Threads is complex. Officially, the Church condemns all criminal activity. Unofficially, certain Church administrators purchase stolen Residue—the commodity's value creates irresistible temptation. This hypocrisy provides the Silk Threads leverage against Church interference. Total Annual Revenue : Approximately 500,000 marks, making the Silk Threads economically comparable to a major noble house. The Coral Syndicate (Reaches) Maritime crime in the Reaches operates through the Coral Syndicate—a decentralized network connecting criminal operations across major ports. Structure and Leadership Unlike the hierarchical Silk Threads, the Coral Syndicate functions as a confederation. Each major port has a Port Captain who controls local criminal activity autonomously. Port Captains answer to no central authority but coordinate through the Council of Tides—periodic meetings where leaders negotiate disputes, share intelligence, and plan major operations. The loose structure reflects Reaches culture: independence, practical cooperation, and suspicion of concentrated authority. It also makes the Syndicate difficult to destroy—eliminating one Port Captain merely creates opportunity for successors. Total Syndicate membership exceeds 1,000 individuals across all ports, though boundaries between members and associates blur significantly. Primary Activities Smuggling : The Syndicate's core business. Reaches geography—extensive coastline, numerous ports, complex maritime traffic—creates ideal smuggling conditions. Contraband includes untaxed goods avoiding Crown duties, prohibited items (Threadist materials, restricted substances, illegal weapons), and human cargo (fugitives fleeing pattern-enforcement, illegal immigrants, occasionally slaves despite official abolition). Smuggling operations range from small boats moving minor contraband to organized fleets running major cargo. A successful smuggling captain earns 2,000-10,000 marks annually; crew members earn 300-1,000 marks. Piracy : True piracy—attacking legitimate merchant ships—occurs but remains rarer than popular imagination suggests. Most "piracy" involves either organized intimidation (merchant captains paying "passage fees" to avoid trouble) or attacks on other criminal operations. When genuine piracy occurs, Syndicate ships target wealthy cargoes and avoid vessels likely to prompt aggressive response. Contraband Trade : The Syndicate connects producers and consumers of illegal goods throughout Hálcova. Drugs derived from Elsewhere-touched plants, stolen luxury items, weapons prohibited to pattern-constrained individuals—the Syndicate moves these goods with efficiency rivaling legitimate merchants. Pattern-Evasion Assistance : Individuals fleeing pattern-enforcement—those who refuse Correction, escape constrained labor, or commit pattern-crimes—seek Syndicate assistance in reaching safety. Some flee to Far Shelf resistance communities; others seek new identities in distant ports. This service combines humanitarian impulse with substantial profit (1,000-10,000 marks depending on risk and destination). Relationship with Authority The Reaches League tolerates the Coral Syndicate because complete suppression would require resources the League prefers to spend elsewhere—and because Syndicate activity generates economic benefits. Smuggled goods still circulate through Reaches markets; Syndicate spending supports local economies; and "piracy" that targets competitors more than League merchants creates perverse advantage. The Heartlands Crown opposes the Syndicate more actively but cannot project sufficient naval power to threaten Syndicate operations in Reaches waters. Border enforcement catches some smuggling; most passes through. Total Annual Revenue : Approximately 2,000,000 marks across all Syndicate operations—making it the wealthiest criminal organization in Hálcova by substantial margin. The Hollow Saints (Far Shelf) Part criminal organization, part resistance movement, the Hollow Saints blur boundaries between crime and political opposition. Structure and Leadership The Hollow Saints operate in cells of 5-15 members, each largely independent. Cell leaders know contacts in one or two other cells; no one knows the complete organizational structure. This security through compartmentalization protects the organization from infiltration—betrayal of one cell doesn't compromise others. Total active membership: 200-300 individuals. Support networks of sympathizers, safe houses, and occasional collaborators multiply effective strength significantly. Leadership operates by reputation and demonstrated commitment rather than formal hierarchy. The most respected members—those who've survived longest, accomplished most, or sacrificed most—command informal authority. Primary Activities Threadist Text Distribution : The Hollow Saints circulate writings the Church considers heretical—philosophical arguments against pattern-determinism, histories presenting alternative accounts of the Integration Century, theological works questioning Church authority. Production occurs in hidden locations; distribution uses dead drops, trusted networks, and embedded codes. Pattern-Certificate Forgery : Unlike commercial forgers who sell to individual buyers, the Hollow Saints produce documents for resistance purposes: false identities for hunted members, papers allowing travel through controlled areas, certificates enabling access to restricted resources. Targeted Violence : The Hollow Saints assassinate Wardens and Church officials responsible for persecution of Threadist communities. Such killings are rare, carefully planned, and intended to impose costs on oppression rather than trigger mass violence. Between five and fifteen such attacks occur annually across the Far Shelf. Sabotage : Destruction targeting infrastructure supporting pattern-enforcement: Loom relay stations, Church record repositories, Warden command posts. Sabotage operations require significant planning and risk substantial casualties; they occur when strategic value justifies danger. Harboring Fugitives : Perhaps their most common activity, the Hollow Saints maintain networks of safe houses and escape routes for individuals fleeing pattern-enforcement. A fugitive reaching Hollow Saint contacts has reasonable probability of eventual safety in remote Far Shelf communities beyond effective central authority. Relationship with Authority The Hollow Saints are actively hunted. Wardens prioritize their destruction above other criminal targets. Church officials consider them heretics deserving execution. Crown authorities view them as rebels threatening social order. Despite decades of persecution, the Hollow Saints persist because Far Shelf geography complicates pursuit, local populations often sympathize with resistance, and new members replace those captured or killed. The cycle of persecution and resistance appears stable—authorities cannot eliminate the Hollow Saints; the Hollow Saints cannot threaten regime survival. Funding and Economics Unlike commercial criminal organizations, the Hollow Saints don't pursue profit. Operating funds come from donations (both from committed supporters and from wealthy individuals hedging bets against regime change), occasional theft for operational needs, and contributions from Far Shelf communities that benefit from resistance activity. Individual members receive subsistence support rather than wages. Leadership distributes resources according to need and operational requirements. The organization's annual budget totals perhaps 50,000-100,000 marks—modest compared to other organizations but sufficient for their purposes. The Consortium's Shadow (Vent Lands) Within the Flesh Shaping Consortium's legitimate operations lurk activities that, while technically legal, constitute organized harm. Structure Unlike traditional criminal organizations, the Consortium's Shadow has no separate existence from the legitimate Consortium. Rather, certain Consortium members and facilities engage in activities the organization officially prohibits while enjoying protection from official Consortium structure. Participation requires both Consortium membership and willingness to cross ethical lines. Perhaps 100-200 individuals participate directly; many more benefit indirectly or maintain willful ignorance. Activities Illegal Flesh Shaping Experiments : Consortium regulations restrict modifications that create unacceptable risk, cause unnecessary suffering, or produce results deemed socially harmful. Some practitioners ignore these restrictions, conducting experiments on subjects unable to refuse (prisoners sold by corrupt authorities, desperate poor individuals, kidnapping victims). Results include medical advances that eventually become legitimate and failed experiments disposed of quietly. Body Trafficking : The Consortium officially permits Flesh Shaping only on willing subjects with appropriate documentation. Underground operations modify individuals without consent—typically creating workers, fighters, or pleasure servants for wealthy buyers. A modified slave can sell for 5,000-50,000 marks depending on modifications. Elsewhere Contact Research : Official Consortium position holds that direct Elsewhere contact is impossible and undesirable. Unofficial research pursues exactly such contact, seeking advantages from direct interaction with the alternate reality underlying pattern and Flesh Shaping. Results of this research remain closely held; rumors suggest both catastrophic failures and disturbing successes. Corporate Crimes : The legitimate Consortium engages in practices that, while legal, constitute harm: monopolistic pricing, suppression of competition, manipulation of regulatory bodies, blackmail of officials who threaten Consortium interests. These activities blur the line between aggressive business practice and organized crime. Protection and Impunity The Consortium's Shadow benefits from institutional protection unavailable to other criminal organizations. The legitimate Consortium's economic power and political influence shield members from prosecution. Internal discipline handles problems without external investigation. Even Wardens hesitate to pursue cases against Consortium members with powerful allies. This protection is not absolute—egregious violations can trigger response, and enemies within the Consortium may use Shadow activities against rivals. But the margin for misconduct is substantially wider than that enjoyed by ordinary criminals. Criminal Activity Categories Smuggling Contraband movement constitutes the largest criminal activity by economic volume. Goods Smuggled Threadist texts and other prohibited materials enter Hálcova through Reaches ports, hidden in legitimate cargo or carried by dedicated smuggling vessels. Distribution networks move materials to final consumers. Illegal Elsewhere artifacts—objects created through or affected by Elsewhere contact—command high prices among collectors and practitioners seeking power outside official channels. Most such "artifacts" are frauds; genuine items are extraordinarily rare and dangerous. Untaxed luxury goods avoid Crown duties that add 20-40% to legitimate prices. Wine, fine textiles, exotic foods, and quality metalwork all move through smuggling channels. Restricted substances—drugs derived from Elsewhere-touched plants, compounds with magical properties, addictive materials prohibited for social control—reach consumers through smuggling networks. Human Smuggling Pattern-fugitives fleeing Correction or constrained labor seek passage to safety. Smugglers charge 1,000-10,000 marks depending on risk and destination. Success rates vary; captured fugitives face execution, captured smugglers face severe punishment. Illegal immigration—people seeking to enter Hálcova or move between regions without documentation—uses similar channels at lower prices. The slave trade, officially abolished throughout Hálcova, persists through criminal networks. Victims include war captives from border conflicts, debtors sold by creditors, and kidnapping victims. Slaves move through the same channels as other contraband. Pattern-Crimes Crimes against the pattern system carry extraordinary penalties and generate extraordinary profits. Certificate Forgery Quality pattern-certificate forgery requires specialized skills: knowledge of official document formats, access to appropriate materials, ability to create convincing verification marks. Professional forgers charge 500-5,000 marks per certificate; amateurs produce documents likely to fail inspection. Detection rates for quality forgeries remain low—perhaps 10-20% of forged certificates eventually trigger investigation. The penalty for both forger and user is execution, creating strong incentive for quality work and careful use. Pattern-Reading Fraud Fraudulent fortune-tellers claim ability to perceive pattern information they cannot actually access. This crime against both individual victims and pattern system integrity carries Correction as standard penalty. More sophisticated fraud involves false interpretation of genuine pattern information—readers who can perceive patterns but deliberately misinterpret them for profit. Detection is nearly impossible without catching the fraudster in explicit deception. Loom Manipulation Attempts Attempts to manipulate the Loom itself—to alter fate rather than merely predict it—constitute the most serious pattern-crime. Success is extraordinarily rare; most attempts produce no effect, trigger dangerous backlash, or attract Warden attention. Those caught attempting Loom manipulation face execution after extensive interrogation. The possibility of actual Loom manipulation drives both criminal enterprise and enforcement intensity. If fate itself could be bought, current social order becomes meaningless. This existential threat justifies extreme measures. Soul Procurement and Substitution Trafficking The darkest criminal enterprise on Hálcova: acquiring pattern-weighted individuals for pact substitution. The Market Demand Pact Summoners owe entities payment in pattern-weight. They can pay with their own cores, or they can substitute others. Entities don't care whose pattern they consume—only that it has sufficient weight. This creates demand for heavy patterns that far exceeds voluntary supply. The wealthy don't sell themselves. The desperate poor have light patterns. The gap between demand and willing supply is filled by coercion. Procurement Methods Kidnapping Operations : Organized crews identify heavy-pattern individuals (the pattern-privileged, successful merchants, minor nobility) and abduct them. Targets are held in secure locations until sold to entity-brokers. A successful kidnapping operation might net 10,000-50,000 marks for a truly heavy pattern. Security details exist specifically to prevent this. Some security personnel have been known to turn on their employers when the price is right. Debt Conversion : When pattern-privileged individuals fall into debt, creditors sometimes accept substitution rights as collateral. If the debt isn't repaid, the creditor can sell those rights. This is legal in most jurisdictions—a debt is a debt. Criminal organizations purchase distressed debt specifically to acquire substitution rights. Family Sales : Some families sell members—usually younger children with heavy patterns, spare heirs, or disgraced relatives. Gray-market in most jurisdictions, openly legal in a few. Brokers specialize in facilitating these transactions, providing discretion and documentation. Death Row Speculation : Condemned criminals' patterns become state property. The state auctions substitution rights for serious crimes. Speculators buy these rights and resell to summoners. Heavy-pattern criminals are worth more than light-pattern ones—creating incentives to ensure heavy-pattern individuals commit capital crimes. The Broker Networks Specialized intermediaries connect supply and demand: Matchmakers : Identify summoners with approaching payment deadlines and match them with available substitutes. Charge 10-20% of transaction value. Holders : Maintain secure facilities where kidnapped individuals are held pending sale. Charge per-day fees plus percentage of eventual sale. Transporters : Move substitutes from procurement to holding to final delivery. Critical for maintaining chain of custody and preventing escape or rescue. Legitimizers : Produce documentation making coerced substitution appear voluntary. Forged consent documents, fabricated debt records, falsified family authorization. Pricing Substitution prices reflect procurement difficulty, not pattern-weight alone: Category Typical Price Notes Light pattern, voluntary 50-500 marks Abundant supply, limited demand Medium pattern, voluntary 500-2,000 marks Some demand for routine pacts Medium pattern, coerced 2,000-5,000 marks Procurement costs included Heavy pattern, coerced 5,000-20,000 marks Significant risk premium Exceptional pattern 20,000-100,000 marks Rare, dangerous acquisition Law Enforcement Substitution trafficking occupies a legal gray zone: Voluntary substitution is legal (if documented) Kidnapping is illegal, but proving the connection to substitution is difficult Debt conversion is legal (contract law) Family sales vary by jurisdiction Entities don't testify about where their patterns came from Wardens investigate pattern-trafficking when it intersects their mandate—forced substitution violates pattern-integrity. But enforcement is selective. Heavy resources go to protecting the pattern-privileged; pattern-constrained victims receive less attention. The Silk Threads operate procurement networks in Fonvárs. The Coral Syndicate moves substitutes between regions. Even the Consortium's Shadow engages in body trafficking that sometimes ends in substitution rather than modified slavery. The Moral Horror This is a literal soul trade. The purchased individual will have their core consumed by an Elsewhere entity. They will die without residue, without the possibility of echo-binding, without any continuation. They will simply cease. And yet the market exists because the demand exists because pacts exist because Elsewhere exists. The horror isn't that evil people do evil things—it's that the system creates the incentives and the transactions follow. Violence Criminal violence ranges from individual attacks to organized warfare. Contract Killing Professional killers available through criminal networks charge rates based on target difficulty. A vulnerable pattern-constrained individual might cost 100-500 marks. A protected merchant costs 1,000-5,000 marks. A minor noble or official costs 5,000-15,000 marks. Killing a major figure—high noble, senior Church official, prominent Warden—requires 20,000+ marks and may simply be refused as too dangerous. Success rates for professional killers exceed 80% for accessible targets, dropping significantly for protected individuals. Investigation intensity following killings varies with victim status—pattern-constrained deaths often go uninvestigated. Protection Violence Criminal organizations maintain territory through demonstrated willingness to use violence. Businesses that refuse protection payments suffer arson, assault, or destruction of goods. Rival criminals who encroach on territory face assault, maiming, or death. This violence is usually instrumental rather than sadistic—enough to establish credibility, not so much as to trigger authority response. The most successful criminal organizations minimize violence while maximizing fear. Gang Warfare Conflicts between criminal organizations occasionally escalate to open warfare. Territory disputes, personal vendettas, and competition for lucrative operations can trigger sustained violence. Such conflicts attract authority attention and usually end through negotiation once costs exceed benefits. Warden Assassination Killing Wardens represents the most dangerous violent crime. Wardens protect each other, investigate murders intensively, and impose collective punishment on communities harboring assassins. Successful Warden assassination requires exceptional skill, planning, and luck—or willingness to sacrifice the killer. The Hollow Saints conduct most Warden assassinations. Commercial assassination of Wardens is theoretically possible but practically rare—the risks and costs exceed what most clients will pay. Vice Criminal provision of pleasure follows predictable patterns. Illegal Gambling Underground gambling houses offer games unavailable legally (higher stakes, forbidden betting targets, rigged outcomes) and access unavailable legally (pattern-constrained individuals excluded from licensed establishments). House profits come from standard gambling advantages plus occasional manipulation. Losers who cannot pay face violence or debt bondage. Unlicensed Prostitution Legal prostitution requires licensing, inspection, and substantial fees. Unlicensed operations avoid these costs while accepting risks: violence from customers without legal protection, disease without mandatory medical checks, exploitation by criminal organizations providing "protection." Most unlicensed sex workers are pattern-constrained individuals with limited economic alternatives. Some choose the work; others are coerced or trafficked. Drug Trade Substances derived from Elsewhere-touched plants or created through restricted processes circulate through criminal networks. Effects vary: some merely intoxicate, others enable perception of pattern information, others facilitate Flesh Shaping or other magical effects. Prices range from 1-5 marks for common intoxicants to 100+ marks for rare substances with magical properties. Addiction creates reliable customers; overdose deaths create investigatory problems. Theft Property crime ranges from opportunistic to organized. Residue Theft Stealing Residue—the essence of dead pattern-bearers—combines extraordinary value with extraordinary risk. Residue has legitimate uses in Church ritual and Loom maintenance; it also has prohibited uses including Elsewhere contact attempts and Flesh Shaping enhancement. Thieves target Residue during collection (immediately after death), transportation (moving from death site to Church storage), or storage (Church facilities, state repositories). Each presents different challenges and risks. Successful Residue theft can yield 10,000-100,000 marks depending on quantity and quality. Detection and capture yields execution after torture for information about buyers and methods. Art and Artifact Theft Wealthy Hálcovans accumulate valuable objects that can be stolen and sold. Pattern-woven tapestries, religious artifacts, historical items, and fine art all have criminal markets. Theft from noble houses requires overcoming security—guards, locks, and sometimes magical protections. Theft from Church facilities adds heresy to property crime. Successful thieves either have specific buyers arranged or sell through criminal networks at substantial discounts. Cargo Theft Goods in transit—whether overland by wagon or maritime by ship—present theft opportunities. Pirates attack ships; bandits attack wagon trains; dock workers pilfer cargo during loading and unloading. Most cargo theft involves ordinary goods resold at discount. High-value cargo (expensive manufactures, restricted materials) attracts more sophisticated theft with correspondingly higher risks and rewards. Law Enforcement Response City Guard Urban police forces handle ordinary crime: theft, assault, public disorder, and minor vice. Guard effectiveness varies by city, district, and individual officer. In practice, City Guards focus on crimes affecting pattern-privileged individuals and major disruptions to public order. Pattern-constrained victims often find Guards uninterested in investigation. Corruption is endemic—Guards supplement inadequate salaries with payments from criminals, victims, and both simultaneously. Guards investigating organized crime face limited resources, active obstruction, and personal danger. Most focus on manageable problems rather than challenging powerful criminal organizations. Wardens The Warden Order prioritizes pattern-crimes: certificate forgery, Loom manipulation attempts, and crimes by or against Elsewhere-touched individuals. Ordinary crime falls outside their mandate except when it intersects pattern concerns. Wardens bring superior resources, training, and determination to investigations within their scope. Criminal organizations avoid triggering Warden interest when possible; those who attract Warden attention face serious consequences. However, Warden capacity is limited. They cannot investigate every pattern-crime, cannot operate everywhere simultaneously, and cannot entirely overcome corrupt officials who protect criminal operations. Wardens are a threat to criminal enterprise, not an absolute barrier. Church Authorities Church investigation focuses on heresy and Residue theft. Crimes without religious dimension rarely attract Church attention; crimes threatening Church interests bring intensive response. Church investigators have access to resources—including pattern-readers and Elsewhere-touched individuals—unavailable to secular authorities. They also operate under different legal constraints, sometimes extracting confessions through methods secular courts would reject. Criminal organizations selling Threadist materials or stolen Residue face dual threats: secular criminal prosecution and Church heresy proceedings. The latter often proves more dangerous. Private Security Wealthy individuals and organizations hire private protection ranging from individual bodyguards to armed companies. This creates two-tier crime response: those who can afford protection receive it; those who cannot rely on inadequate public systems. Private security sometimes cooperates with criminal organizations—purchasing immunity rather than fighting threats. The line between private security and criminal enforcement blurs in some contexts. Criminal Codes Major criminal organizations maintain internal rules governing member behavior. Silk Thread Code Members of the Silk Threads follow rules enforced by internal discipline: No killing civilians without permission from Thread-Captains. Unauthorized violence attracts attention and disrupts operations. Violators face punishment ranging from fines to execution depending on consequences. Pay tribute to the Weaver. All operations contribute percentage of profits upward through the hierarchy. Failure to pay brings escalating pressure culminating in removal from the organization—often violently. Protect territory. Members defend assigned areas against rival criminals and maintain order ensuring continued profitable operation. Abandoning territory without permission constitutes serious offense. No cooperation with authorities. Informants face death—slowly, publicly, and as warning to others. Even members arrested and tortured are expected to reveal nothing. Coral Syndicate Code The Syndicate's decentralized structure produces looser rules: Honor contracts. Agreements between members are binding. Violation destroys reputation necessary for continued operation. The Council of Tides arbitrates disputes and punishes contract breakers. Share intelligence. Information affecting multiple Port Captains must be shared. Hoarding valuable intelligence violates the confederation's foundation. Don't betray Port Captains. Whatever conflicts exist within the Syndicate, external threats to Port Captains affect all. Members who cooperate with authorities against Port Captains face universal condemnation. Hollow Saint Code The resistance movement's code reflects political rather than commercial priorities: Protect Threadists. The organization exists to defend those persecuted for belief. Members risk themselves before risking protected individuals. Target only oppressors. Violence against uninvolved civilians violates organizational principles and provides propaganda for enemies. Even in operations against legitimate targets, civilian casualties must be minimized. No innocent casualties. Operations likely to harm bystanders require exceptional justification. Members accept mission failure rather than innocent deaths when possible. Accept martyrdom if necessary. Captured members are expected to reveal nothing regardless of torture. Many carry means of suicide to ensure silence. Integration with Legitimate Society Criminal organizations don't exist separate from legitimate Hálcova—they're embedded within it, exploiting gaps and contradictions in official systems. Pattern-constrained individuals denied legal economic opportunity find criminal employment. Goods and services prohibited by law but desired by markets reach consumers through criminal channels. Corruption connects criminal operations to legitimate authorities. This integration makes criminal activity extraordinarily difficult to eliminate. Suppressing one organization creates opportunity for others. Removing corrupt officials proves temporary as successors face the same pressures. Prohibiting goods and services creates the criminal markets that supply them. For narrative purposes, criminal organizations provide characters operating outside legal constraints but within comprehensible structures. Crime bosses, smugglers, resistance fighters, and corrupt officials all inhabit spaces defined by both criminal and legitimate rules—spaces where stories of loyalty, betrayal, survival, and moral complexity naturally unfold. Further documentation needed: specific criminal figures and their histories, maps of criminal territories, detailed economics of particular criminal operations, investigation and prosecution procedures.
docs.title: Criminal Underworld

docs.text: Crime in Hálcova exists in complex relationship with legitimate power structures. Organized criminal enterprises fill gaps left by official systems, exploit pattern-based inequalities, and sometimes serve as the only recourse for those whom legal society has abandoned. Understanding Hálcova 's criminal underworld illuminates the world's social fractures, economic pressures, and the limitations of official authority. The criminal economy represents approximately 5-10% of legitimate economic activity—substantial enough to influence markets and politics, contained enough to avoid threatening system stability. This equilibrium reflects tacit accommodation between criminal organizations and authorities who find complete suppression neither possible nor desirable.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: The dominant criminal organization in the Heartlands capital operates with sophistication matching legitimate institutions. Structure and Leadership The Silk Threads employ a hierarchical structure of approximately 500 active members. At the apex sits the Weaver—a position whose occupant's identity remains unknown to most members and all outsiders. The Weaver communicates through intermediaries, maintaining mystique that enhances authority and complicates law enforcement efforts. Below the Weaver, five Thread-Captains control distinct districts of Fonvárs criminal territory: the Docks, the Lower Markets, the Warehouse Quarter, the Craftsmen's District, and the Entertainment District. Each Thread-Captain maintains significant autonomy within their territory while coordinating major operations through the Weaver's intermediaries. Thread-Captains command Knots—groups of 10-20 enforcers who handle violence, collection, and territorial defense. Individual Knot leaders earn 1,000-3,000 marks annually; ordinary enforcers earn 500-1,500 marks. At the base, Loose Ends handle street-level crime: pickpocketing, small-scale theft, message running, and lookout duties. These individuals earn 50-300 marks annually and aspire to Knot membership. Primary Activities Protection Rackets : The Silk Threads' most reliable revenue stream. Businesses in controlled territories pay weekly fees (typically 5-10% of revenue) for "protection" from criminal activity—protection that would otherwise come from the Silk Threads themselves. Annual protection revenue: approximately 150,000 marks. Smuggling : Contraband enters Fonvárs through Silk Thread networks. Untaxed luxury goods, Threadist texts, illegal Elsewhere artifacts, and restricted substances move through warehouses and shops that appear legitimate. Smuggling revenue varies dramatically by year; average approximately 100,000 marks annually. Gambling Operations : Underground gambling houses offer games unavailable legally and serve customers who cannot access licensed establishments. House advantages and occasional rigging generate steady profits. Annual gambling revenue: approximately 75,000 marks. Prostitution : Unlicensed brothels operate throughout controlled territories. The Silk Threads provide protection to sex workers in exchange for substantial cuts of earnings. Revenue: approximately 50,000 marks annually. Pattern-Forgery : Perhaps the most lucrative per-transaction activity, the Silk Threads produce forged pattern-certificates allowing constrained individuals to access privileges reserved for higher pattern status. A quality forgery costs 500-5,000 marks; detection means execution for both forger and user. Annual forgery revenue: approximately 100,000 marks. Residue Theft : The most dangerous operation involves stealing Residue—the essence left when pattern-bearing individuals die—from Church collection or state storage. Residue has enormous value to certain buyers, but theft constitutes both crime and heresy. Revenue varies; major heists can net 50,000+ marks but occur rarely. Relationship with Authority The Silk Threads maintain corruption networks ensuring operational continuity. City Guard officers receive monthly payments (50-200 marks depending on rank and territory) for ignoring specific activities and providing warning of raids. Several mid-level Wardens accept payments for similar accommodation regarding pattern-crimes, though senior Wardens appear incorruptible. The Church's relationship with the Silk Threads is complex. Officially, the Church condemns all criminal activity. Unofficially, certain Church administrators purchase stolen Residue—the commodity's value creates irresistible temptation. This hypocrisy provides the Silk Threads leverage against Church interference. Total Annual Revenue : Approximately 500,000 marks, making the Silk Threads economically comparable to a major noble house.
docs.title: The Silk Threads (Fonvárs)

docs.text: Maritime crime in the Reaches operates through the Coral Syndicate—a decentralized network connecting criminal operations across major ports. Structure and Leadership Unlike the hierarchical Silk Threads, the Coral Syndicate functions as a confederation. Each major port has a Port Captain who controls local criminal activity autonomously. Port Captains answer to no central authority but coordinate through the Council of Tides—periodic meetings where leaders negotiate disputes, share intelligence, and plan major operations. The loose structure reflects Reaches culture: independence, practical cooperation, and suspicion of concentrated authority. It also makes the Syndicate difficult to destroy—eliminating one Port Captain merely creates opportunity for successors. Total Syndicate membership exceeds 1,000 individuals across all ports, though boundaries between members and associates blur significantly. Primary Activities Smuggling : The Syndicate's core business. Reaches geography—extensive coastline, numerous ports, complex maritime traffic—creates ideal smuggling conditions. Contraband includes untaxed goods avoiding Crown duties, prohibited items (Threadist materials, restricted substances, illegal weapons), and human cargo (fugitives fleeing pattern-enforcement, illegal immigrants, occasionally slaves despite official abolition). Smuggling operations range from small boats moving minor contraband to organized fleets running major cargo. A successful smuggling captain earns 2,000-10,000 marks annually; crew members earn 300-1,000 marks. Piracy : True piracy—attacking legitimate merchant ships—occurs but remains rarer than popular imagination suggests. Most "piracy" involves either organized intimidation (merchant captains paying "passage fees" to avoid trouble) or attacks on other criminal operations. When genuine piracy occurs, Syndicate ships target wealthy cargoes and avoid vessels likely to prompt aggressive response. Contraband Trade : The Syndicate connects producers and consumers of illegal goods throughout Hálcova. Drugs derived from Elsewhere-touched plants, stolen luxury items, weapons prohibited to pattern-constrained individuals—the Syndicate moves these goods with efficiency rivaling legitimate merchants. Pattern-Evasion Assistance : Individuals fleeing pattern-enforcement—those who refuse Correction, escape constrained labor, or commit pattern-crimes—seek Syndicate assistance in reaching safety. Some flee to Far Shelf resistance communities; others seek new identities in distant ports. This service combines humanitarian impulse with substantial profit (1,000-10,000 marks depending on risk and destination). Relationship with Authority The Reaches League tolerates the Coral Syndicate because complete suppression would require resources the League prefers to spend elsewhere—and because Syndicate activity generates economic benefits. Smuggled goods still circulate through Reaches markets; Syndicate spending supports local economies; and "piracy" that targets competitors more than League merchants creates perverse advantage. The Heartlands Crown opposes the Syndicate more actively but cannot project sufficient naval power to threaten Syndicate operations in Reaches waters. Border enforcement catches some smuggling; most passes through. Total Annual Revenue : Approximately 2,000,000 marks across all Syndicate operations—making it the wealthiest criminal organization in Hálcova by substantial margin.
docs.title: The Coral Syndicate (Reaches)

docs.text: Part criminal organization, part resistance movement, the Hollow Saints blur boundaries between crime and political opposition. Structure and Leadership The Hollow Saints operate in cells of 5-15 members, each largely independent. Cell leaders know contacts in one or two other cells; no one knows the complete organizational structure. This security through compartmentalization protects the organization from infiltration—betrayal of one cell doesn't compromise others. Total active membership: 200-300 individuals. Support networks of sympathizers, safe houses, and occasional collaborators multiply effective strength significantly. Leadership operates by reputation and demonstrated commitment rather than formal hierarchy. The most respected members—those who've survived longest, accomplished most, or sacrificed most—command informal authority. Primary Activities Threadist Text Distribution : The Hollow Saints circulate writings the Church considers heretical—philosophical arguments against pattern-determinism, histories presenting alternative accounts of the Integration Century, theological works questioning Church authority. Production occurs in hidden locations; distribution uses dead drops, trusted networks, and embedded codes. Pattern-Certificate Forgery : Unlike commercial forgers who sell to individual buyers, the Hollow Saints produce documents for resistance purposes: false identities for hunted members, papers allowing travel through controlled areas, certificates enabling access to restricted resources. Targeted Violence : The Hollow Saints assassinate Wardens and Church officials responsible for persecution of Threadist communities. Such killings are rare, carefully planned, and intended to impose costs on oppression rather than trigger mass violence. Between five and fifteen such attacks occur annually across the Far Shelf. Sabotage : Destruction targeting infrastructure supporting pattern-enforcement: Loom relay stations, Church record repositories, Warden command posts. Sabotage operations require significant planning and risk substantial casualties; they occur when strategic value justifies danger. Harboring Fugitives : Perhaps their most common activity, the Hollow Saints maintain networks of safe houses and escape routes for individuals fleeing pattern-enforcement. A fugitive reaching Hollow Saint contacts has reasonable probability of eventual safety in remote Far Shelf communities beyond effective central authority. Relationship with Authority The Hollow Saints are actively hunted. Wardens prioritize their destruction above other criminal targets. Church officials consider them heretics deserving execution. Crown authorities view them as rebels threatening social order. Despite decades of persecution, the Hollow Saints persist because Far Shelf geography complicates pursuit, local populations often sympathize with resistance, and new members replace those captured or killed. The cycle of persecution and resistance appears stable—authorities cannot eliminate the Hollow Saints; the Hollow Saints cannot threaten regime survival. Funding and Economics Unlike commercial criminal organizations, the Hollow Saints don't pursue profit. Operating funds come from donations (both from committed supporters and from wealthy individuals hedging bets against regime change), occasional theft for operational needs, and contributions from Far Shelf communities that benefit from resistance activity. Individual members receive subsistence support rather than wages. Leadership distributes resources according to need and operational requirements. The organization's annual budget totals perhaps 50,000-100,000 marks—modest compared to other organizations but sufficient for their purposes.
docs.title: The Hollow Saints (Far Shelf)

docs.text: Within the Flesh Shaping Consortium's legitimate operations lurk activities that, while technically legal, constitute organized harm. Structure Unlike traditional criminal organizations, the Consortium's Shadow has no separate existence from the legitimate Consortium. Rather, certain Consortium members and facilities engage in activities the organization officially prohibits while enjoying protection from official Consortium structure. Participation requires both Consortium membership and willingness to cross ethical lines. Perhaps 100-200 individuals participate directly; many more benefit indirectly or maintain willful ignorance. Activities Illegal Flesh Shaping Experiments : Consortium regulations restrict modifications that create unacceptable risk, cause unnecessary suffering, or produce results deemed socially harmful. Some practitioners ignore these restrictions, conducting experiments on subjects unable to refuse (prisoners sold by corrupt authorities, desperate poor individuals, kidnapping victims). Results include medical advances that eventually become legitimate and failed experiments disposed of quietly. Body Trafficking : The Consortium officially permits Flesh Shaping only on willing subjects with appropriate documentation. Underground operations modify individuals without consent—typically creating workers, fighters, or pleasure servants for wealthy buyers. A modified slave can sell for 5,000-50,000 marks depending on modifications. Elsewhere Contact Research : Official Consortium position holds that direct Elsewhere contact is impossible and undesirable. Unofficial research pursues exactly such contact, seeking advantages from direct interaction with the alternate reality underlying pattern and Flesh Shaping. Results of this research remain closely held; rumors suggest both catastrophic failures and disturbing successes. Corporate Crimes : The legitimate Consortium engages in practices that, while legal, constitute harm: monopolistic pricing, suppression of competition, manipulation of regulatory bodies, blackmail of officials who threaten Consortium interests. These activities blur the line between aggressive business practice and organized crime. Protection and Impunity The Consortium's Shadow benefits from institutional protection unavailable to other criminal organizations. The legitimate Consortium's economic power and political influence shield members from prosecution. Internal discipline handles problems without external investigation. Even Wardens hesitate to pursue cases against Consortium members with powerful allies. This protection is not absolute—egregious violations can trigger response, and enemies within the Consortium may use Shadow activities against rivals. But the margin for misconduct is substantially wider than that enjoyed by ordinary criminals.
docs.title: The Consortium's Shadow (Vent Lands)

docs.text: Contraband movement constitutes the largest criminal activity by economic volume. Goods Smuggled Threadist texts and other prohibited materials enter Hálcova through Reaches ports, hidden in legitimate cargo or carried by dedicated smuggling vessels. Distribution networks move materials to final consumers. Illegal Elsewhere artifacts—objects created through or affected by Elsewhere contact—command high prices among collectors and practitioners seeking power outside official channels. Most such "artifacts" are frauds; genuine items are extraordinarily rare and dangerous. Untaxed luxury goods avoid Crown duties that add 20-40% to legitimate prices. Wine, fine textiles, exotic foods, and quality metalwork all move through smuggling channels. Restricted substances—drugs derived from Elsewhere-touched plants, compounds with magical properties, addictive materials prohibited for social control—reach consumers through smuggling networks. Human Smuggling Pattern-fugitives fleeing Correction or constrained labor seek passage to safety. Smugglers charge 1,000-10,000 marks depending on risk and destination. Success rates vary; captured fugitives face execution, captured smugglers face severe punishment. Illegal immigration—people seeking to enter Hálcova or move between regions without documentation—uses similar channels at lower prices. The slave trade, officially abolished throughout Hálcova, persists through criminal networks. Victims include war captives from border conflicts, debtors sold by creditors, and kidnapping victims. Slaves move through the same channels as other contraband.
docs.title: Smuggling

docs.text: Crimes against the pattern system carry extraordinary penalties and generate extraordinary profits. Certificate Forgery Quality pattern-certificate forgery requires specialized skills: knowledge of official document formats, access to appropriate materials, ability to create convincing verification marks. Professional forgers charge 500-5,000 marks per certificate; amateurs produce documents likely to fail inspection. Detection rates for quality forgeries remain low—perhaps 10-20% of forged certificates eventually trigger investigation. The penalty for both forger and user is execution, creating strong incentive for quality work and careful use. Pattern-Reading Fraud Fraudulent fortune-tellers claim ability to perceive pattern information they cannot actually access. This crime against both individual victims and pattern system integrity carries Correction as standard penalty. More sophisticated fraud involves false interpretation of genuine pattern information—readers who can perceive patterns but deliberately misinterpret them for profit. Detection is nearly impossible without catching the fraudster in explicit deception. Loom Manipulation Attempts Attempts to manipulate the Loom itself—to alter fate rather than merely predict it—constitute the most serious pattern-crime. Success is extraordinarily rare; most attempts produce no effect, trigger dangerous backlash, or attract Warden attention. Those caught attempting Loom manipulation face execution after extensive interrogation. The possibility of actual Loom manipulation drives both criminal enterprise and enforcement intensity. If fate itself could be bought, current social order becomes meaningless. This existential threat justifies extreme measures.
docs.title: Pattern-Crimes

docs.text: The darkest criminal enterprise on Hálcova: acquiring pattern-weighted individuals for pact substitution. The Market Demand Pact Summoners owe entities payment in pattern-weight. They can pay with their own cores, or they can substitute others. Entities don't care whose pattern they consume—only that it has sufficient weight. This creates demand for heavy patterns that far exceeds voluntary supply. The wealthy don't sell themselves. The desperate poor have light patterns. The gap between demand and willing supply is filled by coercion. Procurement Methods Kidnapping Operations : Organized crews identify heavy-pattern individuals (the pattern-privileged, successful merchants, minor nobility) and abduct them. Targets are held in secure locations until sold to entity-brokers. A successful kidnapping operation might net 10,000-50,000 marks for a truly heavy pattern. Security details exist specifically to prevent this. Some security personnel have been known to turn on their employers when the price is right. Debt Conversion : When pattern-privileged individuals fall into debt, creditors sometimes accept substitution rights as collateral. If the debt isn't repaid, the creditor can sell those rights. This is legal in most jurisdictions—a debt is a debt. Criminal organizations purchase distressed debt specifically to acquire substitution rights. Family Sales : Some families sell members—usually younger children with heavy patterns, spare heirs, or disgraced relatives. Gray-market in most jurisdictions, openly legal in a few. Brokers specialize in facilitating these transactions, providing discretion and documentation. Death Row Speculation : Condemned criminals' patterns become state property. The state auctions substitution rights for serious crimes. Speculators buy these rights and resell to summoners. Heavy-pattern criminals are worth more than light-pattern ones—creating incentives to ensure heavy-pattern individuals commit capital crimes. The Broker Networks Specialized intermediaries connect supply and demand: Matchmakers : Identify summoners with approaching payment deadlines and match them with available substitutes. Charge 10-20% of transaction value. Holders : Maintain secure facilities where kidnapped individuals are held pending sale. Charge per-day fees plus percentage of eventual sale. Transporters : Move substitutes from procurement to holding to final delivery. Critical for maintaining chain of custody and preventing escape or rescue. Legitimizers : Produce documentation making coerced substitution appear voluntary. Forged consent documents, fabricated debt records, falsified family authorization. Pricing Substitution prices reflect procurement difficulty, not pattern-weight alone: Category Typical Price Notes Light pattern, voluntary 50-500 marks Abundant supply, limited demand Medium pattern, voluntary 500-2,000 marks Some demand for routine pacts Medium pattern, coerced 2,000-5,000 marks Procurement costs included Heavy pattern, coerced 5,000-20,000 marks Significant risk premium Exceptional pattern 20,000-100,000 marks Rare, dangerous acquisition Law Enforcement Substitution trafficking occupies a legal gray zone: Voluntary substitution is legal (if documented) Kidnapping is illegal, but proving the connection to substitution is difficult Debt conversion is legal (contract law) Family sales vary by jurisdiction Entities don't testify about where their patterns came from Wardens investigate pattern-trafficking when it intersects their mandate—forced substitution violates pattern-integrity. But enforcement is selective. Heavy resources go to protecting the pattern-privileged; pattern-constrained victims receive less attention. The Silk Threads operate procurement networks in Fonvárs. The Coral Syndicate moves substitutes between regions. Even the Consortium's Shadow engages in body trafficking that sometimes ends in substitution rather than modified slavery. The Moral Horror This is a literal soul trade. The purchased individual will have their core consumed by an Elsewhere entity. They will die without residue, without the possibility of echo-binding, without any continuation. They will simply cease. And yet the market exists because the demand exists because pacts exist because Elsewhere exists. The horror isn't that evil people do evil things—it's that the system creates the incentives and the transactions follow.
docs.title: Soul Procurement and Substitution Trafficking

docs.text: Criminal violence ranges from individual attacks to organized warfare. Contract Killing Professional killers available through criminal networks charge rates based on target difficulty. A vulnerable pattern-constrained individual might cost 100-500 marks. A protected merchant costs 1,000-5,000 marks. A minor noble or official costs 5,000-15,000 marks. Killing a major figure—high noble, senior Church official, prominent Warden—requires 20,000+ marks and may simply be refused as too dangerous. Success rates for professional killers exceed 80% for accessible targets, dropping significantly for protected individuals. Investigation intensity following killings varies with victim status—pattern-constrained deaths often go uninvestigated. Protection Violence Criminal organizations maintain territory through demonstrated willingness to use violence. Businesses that refuse protection payments suffer arson, assault, or destruction of goods. Rival criminals who encroach on territory face assault, maiming, or death. This violence is usually instrumental rather than sadistic—enough to establish credibility, not so much as to trigger authority response. The most successful criminal organizations minimize violence while maximizing fear. Gang Warfare Conflicts between criminal organizations occasionally escalate to open warfare. Territory disputes, personal vendettas, and competition for lucrative operations can trigger sustained violence. Such conflicts attract authority attention and usually end through negotiation once costs exceed benefits. Warden Assassination Killing Wardens represents the most dangerous violent crime. Wardens protect each other, investigate murders intensively, and impose collective punishment on communities harboring assassins. Successful Warden assassination requires exceptional skill, planning, and luck—or willingness to sacrifice the killer. The Hollow Saints conduct most Warden assassinations. Commercial assassination of Wardens is theoretically possible but practically rare—the risks and costs exceed what most clients will pay.
docs.title: Violence

docs.text: Criminal provision of pleasure follows predictable patterns. Illegal Gambling Underground gambling houses offer games unavailable legally (higher stakes, forbidden betting targets, rigged outcomes) and access unavailable legally (pattern-constrained individuals excluded from licensed establishments). House profits come from standard gambling advantages plus occasional manipulation. Losers who cannot pay face violence or debt bondage. Unlicensed Prostitution Legal prostitution requires licensing, inspection, and substantial fees. Unlicensed operations avoid these costs while accepting risks: violence from customers without legal protection, disease without mandatory medical checks, exploitation by criminal organizations providing "protection." Most unlicensed sex workers are pattern-constrained individuals with limited economic alternatives. Some choose the work; others are coerced or trafficked. Drug Trade Substances derived from Elsewhere-touched plants or created through restricted processes circulate through criminal networks. Effects vary: some merely intoxicate, others enable perception of pattern information, others facilitate Flesh Shaping or other magical effects. Prices range from 1-5 marks for common intoxicants to 100+ marks for rare substances with magical properties. Addiction creates reliable customers; overdose deaths create investigatory problems.
docs.title: Vice

docs.text: Property crime ranges from opportunistic to organized. Residue Theft Stealing Residue—the essence of dead pattern-bearers—combines extraordinary value with extraordinary risk. Residue has legitimate uses in Church ritual and Loom maintenance; it also has prohibited uses including Elsewhere contact attempts and Flesh Shaping enhancement. Thieves target Residue during collection (immediately after death), transportation (moving from death site to Church storage), or storage (Church facilities, state repositories). Each presents different challenges and risks. Successful Residue theft can yield 10,000-100,000 marks depending on quantity and quality. Detection and capture yields execution after torture for information about buyers and methods. Art and Artifact Theft Wealthy Hálcovans accumulate valuable objects that can be stolen and sold. Pattern-woven tapestries, religious artifacts, historical items, and fine art all have criminal markets. Theft from noble houses requires overcoming security—guards, locks, and sometimes magical protections. Theft from Church facilities adds heresy to property crime. Successful thieves either have specific buyers arranged or sell through criminal networks at substantial discounts. Cargo Theft Goods in transit—whether overland by wagon or maritime by ship—present theft opportunities. Pirates attack ships; bandits attack wagon trains; dock workers pilfer cargo during loading and unloading. Most cargo theft involves ordinary goods resold at discount. High-value cargo (expensive manufactures, restricted materials) attracts more sophisticated theft with correspondingly higher risks and rewards.
docs.title: Theft

docs.text: Urban police forces handle ordinary crime: theft, assault, public disorder, and minor vice. Guard effectiveness varies by city, district, and individual officer. In practice, City Guards focus on crimes affecting pattern-privileged individuals and major disruptions to public order. Pattern-constrained victims often find Guards uninterested in investigation. Corruption is endemic—Guards supplement inadequate salaries with payments from criminals, victims, and both simultaneously. Guards investigating organized crime face limited resources, active obstruction, and personal danger. Most focus on manageable problems rather than challenging powerful criminal organizations.
docs.title: City Guard

docs.text: The Warden Order prioritizes pattern-crimes: certificate forgery, Loom manipulation attempts, and crimes by or against Elsewhere-touched individuals. Ordinary crime falls outside their mandate except when it intersects pattern concerns. Wardens bring superior resources, training, and determination to investigations within their scope. Criminal organizations avoid triggering Warden interest when possible; those who attract Warden attention face serious consequences. However, Warden capacity is limited. They cannot investigate every pattern-crime, cannot operate everywhere simultaneously, and cannot entirely overcome corrupt officials who protect criminal operations. Wardens are a threat to criminal enterprise, not an absolute barrier.
docs.title: Wardens

docs.text: Church investigation focuses on heresy and Residue theft. Crimes without religious dimension rarely attract Church attention; crimes threatening Church interests bring intensive response. Church investigators have access to resources—including pattern-readers and Elsewhere-touched individuals—unavailable to secular authorities. They also operate under different legal constraints, sometimes extracting confessions through methods secular courts would reject. Criminal organizations selling Threadist materials or stolen Residue face dual threats: secular criminal prosecution and Church heresy proceedings. The latter often proves more dangerous.
docs.title: Church Authorities

docs.text: Wealthy individuals and organizations hire private protection ranging from individual bodyguards to armed companies. This creates two-tier crime response: those who can afford protection receive it; those who cannot rely on inadequate public systems. Private security sometimes cooperates with criminal organizations—purchasing immunity rather than fighting threats. The line between private security and criminal enforcement blurs in some contexts.

docs.title: Integration with Legitimate Society

docs.text: Economics and Class in Hálcova Overview Economics in Hálcova cannot be separated from fate . The Sórscad pattern determines access to credit, employment, insurance, and opportunity. Pattern Residue—the energy of dissolving fates—fuels magic and industry. Death is literally productive. This creates an economy where some people are worth more dead than alive, where peace is expensive, and where the institutions that predict your future have financial stakes in that prediction coming true. The Fate Market Pattern as Asset Your Sórscad is not just identity—it's capital. Pattern-Weight Some patterns are "heavier" than others: More fate-significance More likely to impact events More valuable as Pattern Residue when released Heavy patterns belong to: Those born into consequential circumstances Those whose choices ripple outward Those predicted for significant outcomes (positive or negative) Light patterns belong to: Those born into marginal circumstances Those whose choices affect few others Those predicted for unremarkable outcomes The Market Implications Heavy patterns command higher prices in substitution deals (Pact Summoning) Heavy patterns produce more valuable Residue upon death Heavy patterns are worth more to The Loom (more data value) Heavy patterns are targets for various exploitation This creates a hierarchy: some lives have more market value than others, calculated and priced. Pattern Speculation Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Pattern Arbitrage Some patterns are mispriced. The Loom's predictions, while accurate on average, have errors in individual cases. Arbitrageurs look for: Patterns undervalued by The Loom (capable people dismissed as low-potential) Patterns overvalued by The Loom (impressive readings masking actual mediocrity) Situations where environmental change will shift pattern-outcomes They invest in undervalued people—education, opportunity, resources—and profit when those people outperform predictions. This is legal. It's also morally ambiguous: you're betting on people, treating lives as investments, profiting from the gap between predicted and actual humanity. Credit and Debt Pattern-Based Lending All credit decisions incorporate Sórscad data: Interest Rates Pattern-privileged: Low rates. The Loom predicts they'll repay. Pattern-constrained: High rates. The Loom predicts elevated default risk. Pattern-illegible (practitioners): Variable. Their patterns are too contaminated for reliable prediction. Collateral What can you pledge? Physical assets (traditional) Future earnings (income garnishment) Pattern Residue rights (if you die, the lender harvests) Pact-substitution rights (you can be offered to an Elsewhere entity) Echo-binding rights (you can be bound after death) The last three are where lending gets dark. Poor borrowers often have nothing to pledge but themselves—their deaths, their souls, their eternal servitude as echoes. Debt Spirals The pattern-constrained start with high rates, struggle to repay, take on more debt to service existing debt, and eventually pledge increasingly extreme collateral. docs.text: Entertainment System of Hálcova Overview Entertainment in Hálcova reflects and reinforces the world's fundamental structures: pattern-based stratification, the Church of the Weave's influence, regional identity, and the economic principles that govern daily life. From gladiatorial combat in Fonvárs to naval battles in the Reaches, from high-stakes board games to street performances, entertainment serves as both social pressure valve and mechanism of control. Competitive Formats Mintaharc (Arena Combat) The premier entertainment spectacle of the Heartlands, Mintaharc ("Pattern-War") takes place in Fonvárs Grand Arena, a massive stone structure capable of holding 15,000 spectators. Combat follows strict ceremonial formats that have evolved over centuries. Structure and Participants Arena fighters fall into two categories: voluntary combatants (typically pattern-privileged individuals seeking glory and wealth) and condemned fighters (pattern-constrained criminals offered combat as alternative to execution or Correction). The asymmetry is intentional—watching the privileged test their skills against the desperate reinforces social hierarchies while providing the illusion of opportunity. Professional gladiators train at licensed schools, each associated with noble patrons. The most famous schools include the Iron Thread Academy (Crown-sponsored), the Crimson Weave (Church-affiliated), and the Merchant's Edge (Trade Guild-funded). Fighters sign contracts ranging from one to ten years, receiving housing, training, and a share of winnings in exchange for exclusive combat rights. Combat Categories Traditional matches employ period weapons: swords, spears, nets, and tridents. Armor varies by fighter class—heavily armored "Anchors" face lightly equipped "Threads" in asymmetric contests that test different skills. Team battles pit groups of three to twelve against each other in choreographed scenarios representing historical conflicts. Exhibition matches during major festivals feature Flesh Shaped combatants—individuals who have undergone physical modification specifically for arena performance. These fighters command the highest fees and attract the largest crowds, though Church doctrine officially disapproves of such "vanity modifications." Economics of the Arena Betting forms the financial backbone of Mintaharc. Licensed betting houses accept wagers from 1 to 1,000+ marks, with the largest bets placed by noble houses seeking both profit and prestige through their sponsored fighters. The Crown takes a 10% cut of all legal betting revenue; the Church receives the Residue of any combatants who die in the arena. Fighter compensation varies enormously. A novice condemned fighter receives only the possibility of eventual freedom. A mid-tier professional earns 200-500 marks per bout. Champion fighters command appearance fees of 5,000+ marks plus a percentage of betting revenue on their matches. Deaths occur but are not required—most matches end at first blood or submission. However, certain holiday exhibitions and "justice matches" (condemned criminals facing each other) have higher fatality rates. The Church's Residue collection rights create economic incentive for deaths, though this is never stated publicly. Social Function Mintaharc serves multiple purposes beyond entertainment. It provides visible proof that pattern-privileged status confers genuine advantages (better training, nutrition, equipment). It offers pattern-constrained individuals a theoretical path to freedom and wealth, reinforcing the system's supposed meritocracy. It channels violent impulses into controlled spectacle. And it generates substantial revenue for Crown, Church, and nobility alike. Tengerjáték (Naval Combat) The Reaches' signature entertainment, Tengerjáték ("Sea-Game") stages ship-to-ship combat in protected harbor arenas. Purpose-built vessels crewed by 20-50 sailors engage in battles that combine naval tactics, individual combat, and theatrical spectacle. Venue and Format Major Reaches ports maintain combat harbors—protected basins where spectators watch from surrounding cliffs, towers, and floating platforms. The largest venue, Vízkapu's Grand Harbor, can accommodate battles involving up to six ships simultaneously, with viewing capacity for 8,000 spectators. Ships are purpose-built for combat entertainment rather than actual naval warfare. Hulls are reinforced for ramming but designed to break apart dramatically. Fire weapons use controlled substances that burn impressively without spreading uncontrollably. Boarding ramps deploy with theatrical flourish. Combat Elements Matches typically begin with maneuvering phases where crews demonstrate sailing skill, followed by ranged engagement (ballistae, fire pots, grappling hooks), ramming attempts, and finally boarding actions where crew-to-crew combat determines the victor. Ships may be captured, sunk, or burned depending on match stakes. Crews include both professional naval entertainers and condemned sailors (typically smugglers or pirates captured by League patrols). Professional crews earn shares of prize money and betting revenue. Condemned crews fight for reduced sentences or freedom. Seasonal Structure Tengerjáték follows a seasonal championship format aligned with sailing weather. Spring trials determine which crews qualify for summer tournaments. Autumn championships crown seasonal victors. Winter sees reduced schedules focused on smaller vessels and individual combat rather than full fleet actions. Betting on Tengerjáték reaches staggering volumes during championship events. The Reaches League officially sanctions betting and takes substantial regulatory fees, making naval combat entertainment a significant source of League revenue. Fonálháló (Strategic Board Game) The intellectual counterpart to physical combat sports, Fonálháló ("Thread-Net") is an abstract strategy game representing Loom manipulation. Played on a 19x19 grid using pattern stones and thread tokens, the game has evolved from religious meditation aid to competitive sport over centuries. Rules and Play Fonálháló's core mechanics derive from ancient territory-control games (mechanically similar to Earth's Go), but Hálcovan development has added layers of thematic complexity. Basic Rules : Two players alternate placing stones on grid intersections Stones of the same color connected orthogonally form "pattern groups" Groups must maintain at least one empty adjacent intersection ("breath") to survive Groups with no breath are "dissolved" and removed from the board The player who controls more territory when neither player wishes to continue wins The Thread Modification : Where pure Go ends, Fonálháló adds "thread tokens"—a limited supply (typically 5-7 per player) of special pieces that modify gameplay: Anchor Threads : Placed on owned stones, prevent dissolution for three opponent turns. Represents Core Binding's resistance to pattern-disruption. Binding Threads : Connect two owned groups across empty space, sharing breath. Represents Cóitcai connections. Fate Threads : Placed on empty intersections, reserving them for later placement. Represents Sórscad trajectory-claiming. Dissolution Threads : Placed adjacent to opponent groups, reducing their effective breath by one. Represents Hálmaht death-pressure. Thread tokens add strategic depth beyond pure territory control. Managing thread reserves, timing thread deployment, and countering opponent threads creates decision trees that exponentially multiply game complexity. Scoring : Territory (empty intersections surrounded by your stones) plus captured stones minus thread tokens spent. The thread cost creates interesting sacrificial calculations—spending threads for tactical advantage may cost victory if the margin is close. Complexity Analysis The 19x19 grid alone creates approximately 10^170 possible board positions. Adding thread token decisions multiplies complexity further. Professional players estimate Fonálháló exceeds Go's complexity by roughly an order of magnitude due to thread management. Games between masters can last hours. Tournament matches employ time controls and adjudicators who rule on disputed positions. Professional players dedicate decades to mastering strategic principles—even lifelong study doesn't exhaust the game's depth. Professional Circuit Noble houses sponsor professional Fonálháló players, providing stipends, housing, and access to prestigious tournaments. Professional players earn between 500 marks (regional competitors) to 50,000+ marks annually (Crown Champions).
